PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 9 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Select Committee on Superannuation has raised with me a matter of privilege pursuant to standing order 81. This matter is also the subject of the 11th report of the committee.

PARA.TAB: The committee, pursuant to paragraph (18) of resolution 1 of the Senate's privilege resolutions, relating to the protection of witnesses, has concluded that two witnesses who gave evidence before the committee may have been subject to penalty or injury in respect of their evidence. The adverse treatment of the witnesses which is alleged is that they were removed from membership of a credit union.

I am required to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence over other business, having regard to criteria laid down by the Senate. I have indicated to the Senate in past cases how I interpret these criteria. Past reports of the Privileges Committee and decisions by the Senate indicate that any suggestion that a witness has been penalised because of his or her evidence is regarded as a very serious matter. I therefore determine that a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee may have precedence.
As the Senate is not expected to have any further sitting during this period of sittings, Senator West may now move a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee.
Motion (by Senator West) agreed to:
That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Having regard to the 11th report of the Select Committee on Superannuation, whether witnesses who gave evidence to the select committee were subjected to any penalty or injury in respect of their evidence, and whether any contempt was committed in relation to those witnesses.

PROCTEXT.PARA: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Clauses 1 and 2—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 13—by leave—taken together.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1993HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be opposing these clauses. The reason is that the bill, in these clauses, is increasing from two years to three years the period of notice that non-government schools need to give for changes and for proposals. This is too burdensome on non-government schools, and it is erecting yet another barrier that will hinder and, I think, prevent some non-government schools from being able to operate. This extra penalty being too burdensome, the Liberal and National parties wish to see this potential barrier removed from the bill. Accordingly, we are opposing these clauses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —If no-one else is going to speak, I just want to say that the opposition is correct in saying that the period of notice is being extended. However, I believe that the minister's department discussed this with representatives of the non-government schools, and they have no objection to it. In fact, it brings the period of notice forward from February, when schools are busy with the start of the new year, to the previous October, when they are doing their forward planning in any case.

PARA.TAB: The other clauses cover things such as schools that start enrolling secondary students on a year-by-year basis rather than all at once. This is not a new idea, and it helps schools that are not in a position to open a complete level of education at once. Opposing these clauses does not upset the new schools policy, as the opposition apparently wishes to. They are basically for the efficient administration of an existing government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to say that that is not my understanding of the attitude of the National Council of Independent Schools or of individual independent schools. They see this as a penalty which, it is to be preferred, should be removed from the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been informed that the body that Senator Teague just mentioned represents about one-third of all independent schools in Australia. I think that ought to be put in that context. My advice is that the majority of the independent schools have no objection to this clause.

—Then the minister would not mind telling the committee with whom, with which organisations, and with which independent schools this agreement took place. Was there an agreement? On what dates were those agreements made? I make it perfectly clear that, in any event, this chamber has the responsibility of examining legislation such as this and coming to a proper and considered conclusion about it in the best interests of the people concerned.

PARA.TAB: I am perfectly well aware of the leverage that the government can exert over schools in order to obtain agreements. In this particular area of education, it has been shown time and time again that it can come to agreements from a position like that. Therefore, it is particularly the job of the Senate to examine objectively the measures such as this that are coming before us. I am inclined at this juncture at least to oppose the clauses as Senator Teague has suggested.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised the National Catholic Education Commission supports the government's proposal, and other smaller Christian education school organisations also support the proposal.

—Let me rise very briefly to say that I also consult carefully with representatives of the Catholic systemic schools in the states. The Liberal and National parties want those schools to flourish. We want to see the whole spectrum of schools in this country able to manage their affairs and to have maximum autonomy and we want to allow the parents of Australia freedom of choice to see their children educated in the way in which each family determines.

PARA.TAB: There is a difference in operations between systemic schools. There is a flexibility for the central organisers of a system in each state to receive moneys and disperse moneys, to have their own rolling plans over quite a long period. I can understand that the systemic schools would see less objection in having to give the notice that is required by the government to be three years. However, it is not any surprise that that other group of non-government schools has not the same ability. They are the non-systemic schools that are more individual and more independent; they are dealing for the most part with only one school, not a range of schools in any one state. They have not as big a flywheel in continuous momentum. This additional time the government is proposing is a difficulty for them. It is in the light of the overall picture and the balance of how this would affect all non-government schools that we will oppose these clauses. I therefore acknowledge that a fair degree of what the minister has said is his feedback from systemic schools. We persist with our opposition to these clauses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty we have with these clauses and with the points of view that have been expressed, both by the coalition and by the minister, is that, as with many bodies that deal with government instrumentalities and policies, some representative bodies when I spoke to them seemed to have a very clear understanding of the new schools policy, its genesis, its process through this place and through the cabinet, and its development through the department. For anybody to have a full understanding of that is miraculous, but some of the representative bodies I spoke to seemed to have an understanding of it. There were other groups and individual schools that I spoke to which were merely confused and were not able to resolve their confusion simply by referring to what the government planned to do. There was a question of why: why should this be done; how will it affect us; what do we have to do now?

PARA.TAB: Before coming here I had some experience in local government as an elected member. In the situation of a flywheel of planning that Senator Teague was describing, what I found was that established schools with established representative bodies—the ones that have been going for 100 years—knew how to deal with local government, planning requirements, filling out the forms when making application for an extension, where to put the toilets, whether the school oval had appropriate car parking and that sort of thing. The established schools were well aware of how to deal with that. Those which were new, more flexible and seeking to establish themselves were having great difficulty with local government and, of course, with Commonwealth government and with state government.

I understand and endorse the comments of Senator Teague about attempting to meet a need that is expressed through the community, which recognises failings in the government system and recognises special requirements of the non-government system—even perhaps failings of the non-government system—and seeking to address that by bringing to it an independent approach. In seeking to do that, communities of people are finding ever increasing barriers and difficulties. What is proposed here seems to be another one of those. It is very difficult to reach common ground in what should be done and how it should affect groups.

As far as we can see, the expression of opposition to this, while not universal, is well entrenched within both the established systems of non-government schools and the newer alternative, independent schools—some of which are perhaps even non-denominational. The opposition is not based entirely on confusion but is based on well-reasoned requirements to be flexible and to work on plans that apply to the rules as they stand. To change them in this way merely provides further barriers. So the Democrats will be joining with the coalition in the opposition of these clauses.
Clauses negatived.
Remainder of bill—by leave—taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 15, page 10, after proposed subsection 55(3), add the following subsection:

"(4) For the purposes of paragraph (3)(a), a student is not to be taken as not attending school on a daily basis if on any day the student, while remaining enrolled at the school, is reasonably in attendance at another location for educational purposes or for educationally significant cultural purposes.".

This amendment relates to clause 15 and it is a genuine amendment in that it seeks to add a subsection. This is to remove any doubt that this bill would place on the number of enrolled students in any school, any doubt arising with regard to a student or students being absent from the actual school campus on an excursion or for any other legitimate school related reason. It is because that is in doubt and because schools have, in consultation with us, put the view that this non-sensible and impractical possibility of distorting the enrolled numbers could arise, that these additional words make it quite explicit. A student enrolled at the school, who happens to be absent for a day, or even two, on an excursion related to the school is still an enrolled student.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the amendment from the opposition. The purpose of our proposal, proposed new section 55(3)(a), is to place in legislation what was previously an administrative provision. The intention of the new clause is not that a student attend school every day before the school is eligible for Commonwealth general recurrent funding in respect of the student. What is necessary is that the student attend on a daily basis as opposed to a regular but infrequent basis such as once a month or once a term. A student who attends on a daily basis but is temporarily absent from the school would not be affected.

PARA.TAB: The proposed new section 55(3)(b) also allows the minister to exercise discretion in favour of students who would normally attend on a daily basis but are absent from school in special circumstances. The minister will use this discretion to formally cover the situation the opposition raised in the House of Representatives, that is, students absent from the school to attend TAFE receive special education, participate in school excursions and, in the case of Aboriginal students, participate in ceremonial occasions.

I point out to Senator Teague that the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training has considered the sorts of concerns raised by the opposition in examination of the bill and has expressed itself satisfied without dissent that the mechanisms for counting student enrolment numbers make provisions for such events.

The opposition amendment is imprecisely drafted; it could allow the school to receive funding for students who never actually attend the school at which they are enrolled or are infrequent attendees. It also has the effect of making what is `reasonably in attendance' in another location for educational purposes a question of law without providing any guidance as to the meaning of `reasonably'.

On the basis of that information I ask Senator Teague to reconsider his amendment. I think he would understand that there is always pressure under funding arrangements, and if there is any suggestion that a school is taking an advantage by counting its numbers in a way which is not open and fully transparent to everybody, that can easily create division within the system.

From my recollection, two or three years ago within the state school system of South Australia there were several controversial cases of principals being admonished by the education department for using a very liberal interpretation of the correct ways of counting enrollees so that they received extra staff in their allocation.

That indicates to me as a lay person in this debate—this is not my area of ministerial responsibility, even in the Senate—that we should be very cautious about allowing a liberal interpretation by a minority of people, while those who play the game properly do not get the same advantage. I think that the honourable senator's amendment is unnecessary and that that is why the Senate standing committee expressed itself satisfied without dissent. With that information Senator Teague may now not proceed with the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science (Senator Schacht) very sincerely for the assurances that he gives for what we would call a sensible definition of enrolment. I agree with the minister to the extent that we of course want to see transparency and we want to see proper accountability and very clear, universally consistent recognition of the way to count enrolments.

PARA.TAB: The opposition will, nevertheless, persist with its amendment, because I do not believe that it is imprecisely worded. It is a very clear sentence. It makes it all the clearer in the legislation, by this amendment being added to it, that we are not putting in doubt those students who are reasonably in attendance at another location for educational purposes or for educationally significant cultural purposes.

Nothing that the minister said is in any way, in the government's intention, contradictory to what is meant by those words. Accordingly, to put this matter beyond doubt—and in the spirit of having these words and all the other parts of the bill consistently interpreted around Australia—the bill is improved by the opposition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats shared the concern of many people who were initially alarmed by what was proposed in the bill. To explore that concern, we sought assurances from the minister about the manner in which the discretion under this clause would be used. We received essentially the same advice that the Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science (Senator Schacht) has given us here today.

PARA.TAB: Upon reflection, it seems to me that there would be a number of particular circumstances which are not mentioned in the opposition's amendment which would need to be addressed and which would need discretion to consider. If it is appropriate for an Aboriginal person to be absent for a significant cultural purpose, and if that needs to be defined, then there may be many, many other cultural purposes which would need to be defined. Where would we stop? There could be bar mitzvahs and goodness knows what! I might have a difficulty in imagining the various significant cultural purposes.

The ministerial discretion, of course, should be competent and capable of arriving at that conclusion. I would hate to try to define that here in legislation. With some experience of trying to work out full-time equivalents and enrolments—not, I hasten to add for the minister's benefit, within the attendance of the Democrats in this place—but in previous experience in educational administration, I spent some time trying to work out enrolment statistics for TAFE at one stage. A great deal of discretion is required for that sort of administration, and it would be wrong to attempt to remove or reduce that discretion. What is proposed in the bill—especially with the minister's assurance—is appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science (Senator Schacht) will give the Senate an assurance that the ability to be absent for cultural types of reasons is not going to be simply for Aboriginals. I should hope the minister will make that clear to the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give the Senate the assurance that, when I gave that information, it was an example. It is not limited to the Aboriginal community. I am advised that the process of the minister's discretion will be a public and transparent arrangement whereby people can put submissions to the minister and publicly find information about why the discretion has been used in certain ways. If there is a concern in the community about the use of the minister's discretion, then that will be publicly available to be debated. If there are complaints about it, then there will be a public debate. I think that alone should be a major reassurance to the Senate: it is publicly available.

PARA.TAB: I want to emphasise to Senator Teague a point about the definition of `reasonably'. As he is probably aware, I have expressed concern, as have many others, about lawyers getting involved in these areas. It will be a field day for them to determine what is `reasonably'. I suppose schools will end up paying lawyers to argue over this, when that money should be spent on the education of children. So the bill should stand as printed. I appreciate the comments of all honourable senators, but particularly those of Senator Harradine and Senator Bell.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will need to call a division on this matter, although I do not wish to delay the committee. We have tried to consult the Green senators because, if they were to support our amendment—and we will only know that by their attendance here—the amendment would get up. We therefore need to have some indication from them. I imagine that they are distracted by some other matter at the moment.

—I have not indicated to the chamber how I am going to vote on this matter. I will do so now. For the time being, I will accept the proposals that have been put forward by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) and see how that works. Under those circumstances, there will be no need for a division.
—In that case, having heard the arguments put by other senators, including my friend Senator Harradine, there is no need for a division because it is clear that this amendment will be lost.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 24, page 17, proposed subsection 72A(5), omit the proposed subsection.
4.Clause 24, page 17, proposed subsection 72A(6), omit the proposed subsection.
5.Clause 24, page 17, proposed subsection 72A(7), omit the proposed subsection.
6.Clause 24, page 18, proposed subsection 72B(6), omit the proposed subsection.
7.Clause 24, page 18, proposed subsection 72B(7), omit the proposed subsection.
8.Clause 24, page 18, proposed subsection 72B(8), omit the proposed subsection.
9.After clause 24, page 18, add the following clause:
"24A. After section 73 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

`73A. It must not be a condition of an agreement between the Commonwealth and a State, or the Commonwealth and an authority, in relation to section 70, 71A, 72, 72A, 72B or 73, that some or all of the financial assistance paid to the State or authority for expenditure in connection with the education of students in prescribed country areas, or geographically isolated areas, in the State is to be applied other than in connection with such education.'.".

These amendments all relate to clause 24. They have the very honourable objective, which is supported by honourable senators from the Liberal Party and the National Party, of preserving the country areas program. As I said in the second reading debate on this bill, the government wishes to broadband the country areas program with the disadvantaged schools program. About one-quarter of the total money will be involved in the country areas program and three-quarters of it will be involved in the disadvantaged areas program.

PARA.TAB: There is a genuine fear in country areas that what has been seen to be a very successful country areas program is in jeopardy. It is in the hands not only of this government but, more particularly, of local initiatives to shift money away from the bush into the city; away from an area of great need—that is, the beneficial effects of the country areas program on rural children—and into that other area of need, disadvantaged schools in the cities. It is with this in mind that these amendments are moved by the opposition in order to preserve the country areas program.

I will make one political point. Senator Bell, in his speech on the second reading debate, indicated that, whilst he had been convinced of this position when he was helping to write a Senate report about the country areas program, a matter of weeks afterwards he had his mind changed. He no longer has the same view as his colleagues about the need to preserve the country areas program.

This is a great disappointment for Australians in the bush. I am aware that this will cause a great deal of controversy for Democrat senators in country areas. Many of my Liberal and National Party colleagues will want to make it quite clear, in rural areas, that the people have been let down by the Democrats in this assessment.

I do have an expectation that a majority will form for the passing of these amendments. I am very glad that Senator Margetts is here to address this matter. A majority of us in the committee have as our objective the aim of ensuring that those children least served at the moment for schooling, those in rural areas, will not be short-changed, will not have resources diverted from them, but that, rather, a majority in the committee will ensure that the country areas program remains to serve them in every area of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —As foreshadowed during the second reading stage, the Democrats have had great concern about this particular proposal. The amount of evidence received during the committee of inquiry—the evidence that was put by the department—and the incredible amount of time invested in considering all aspects of this have led to a situation which is a considerable improvement upon that which we first understood to be applying. The improvement was caused by the fact that the Democrats indicated an unwillingness to support the government's proposal. That is the very purpose of this chamber—to consider legislative proposals and their effects and, having considered them, to indicate where this chamber is dissatisfied. The committee of inquiry was intended to identify what the problems were. The questions I asked were intended to determine what was wrong with CAP. I asked myself, `Why fix something that isn't broke?' That is the question that is often asked when government propositions come before us to suggest that a change is necessary.

PARA.TAB: The answers given to the committee were not satisfactory. The department was unable to demonstrate at that stage the need for change. Therefore, the next process was put in place whereby I was unable to sign the majority report, which contended that the legislation should proceed unchanged. That was probably the biggest tool that could be used on behalf of this chamber by the Democrats. We believe that that has forced a consideration and a great deal of negotiation to take place. That is what it is all about. There is no point in signing a minority report and then sitting on it. There is no point in expressing dissatisfaction with a legislative proposal and then saying, `Right, I have done my job'. The job then starts. To be satisfied simply by opposing something is to ignore the incredibly weighty responsibilities that come in this place. To oppose something and then say that that is good enough, that that will fix it, is to me naive in the extreme.

The work we then undertook was to ensure that the country areas program did maintain its integrity and was preserved. To characterise our position and the government's position, even worse, as a position which will—that is the word that has been used—dismantle the undoubtedly and demonstrably excellent CAP program is misleading in the extreme and is almost immoral.

Fears have been expressed by people who have been led to believe that such a threat exists. Those fears are real and they should concern us all. They certainly concern me. The motivation for our involvement in this debate is not just because it is there. The motivation for the involvement of the Democrats is that we believe that geographically isolated people, on the question of equity, should be able to access the same facilities and level of education that is available in urban Australia. By supporting the amendment, we will certainly not guarantee that equity of access. The government is proposing to ensure that the CAP continues to deliver educational opportunities and does not just spread money around in a way that has been properly criticised in some instances and does not offer the opportunity for proper evaluation of what it is achieving.

A little has been said about the bush as a place where people suffer geographical isolation. As one who has to travel across the water to get to this place, I have some experience in isolation. I can tell the committee that there are places across the water from Tasmania that are particularly advantaged by the present application of the CAP funds. Those offshore islands from Tasmania are places that desperately need the sort of funding that is provided here.

I wish to add that I have considerable personal experience with the provision of education in places such as Hungerford. I actually administered a centre in Victoria, which was very closely involved with the CAP program at that time in the early 1980s. The idea that there are only a few people in here who know about this because they talk about the bush a lot is an idea that should be discounted very quickly. We all have access to information and to people who tell us how valuable the CAP program is. I think it is very misleading to characterise this legislation as legislation that will discontinue this program. It is misleading for people to contact us and say that the CAP will no longer apply in their area.

The path we followed to find out whether this was the case is a path that leads us to believe that the state ministers, whether or not they be of the same political persuasion as this government, have considered this long and hard. I did refer to some agreements that were in draft and some agreements that have been signed and some agreements that are almost ready to be signed between the Commonwealth and the state ministers. These guarantee the delivery of CAP programs. In the second reading stage I referred to them in particular and quoted from parts that require that the state governments deliver. In those circumstances, I cannot see how anybody can honestly come in here and say that the CAP program will stop unless this amendment is agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —It preserves the CAP.

—Preserve the CAP by signing an agreement with the state that it will continue. What more can be done to demonstrate that it will happen? I will not quote the name of the person who sent this letter to me; I will simply say that this letter is representative of several that have come to me from people who are particularly involved in the priority country areas program. This person writes from the administrative body of one of these organisations.

PARA.TAB: One of the claims is that `broadbanding does not require states to develop structures to encourage or protect the best practices learned under the existing CAP structure'. That is an assertion which has been common to a lot of the correspondence that we have received, and the person who wrote that was fearful of the continuation of the CAP program. I am sorry that that person does not have access to the agreements that I quoted. These are agreements which are in the process of being signed and there are a growing number which have been signed. I have only five in my possession but there are others, I understand. They do precisely what it is claimed here that they do not do, and I am sorry that the person who wrote this could not have had access to the content of these agreements. If that person had had that access, he or she would have understood that it is precisely that that is being guaranteed by these agreements.

I cannot fly in the face of such agreements. I cannot deny the existence of them. They are here, they are tangible and they are at the level of state government to Commonwealth government. They are also at the level of other state systems such as the Independent Schools Board National Equity Program Authority Inc. and the Queensland Catholic Education Commission. What I am saying here is that bodies which have it within their responsibility to deliver these programs are now in the process of making agreements with the Commonwealth to guarantee the continuation, and that is a tangible process which neither I nor nobody else, I suggest, can deny the existence of.

To suggest that it is all doomed because of an increased requirement for evaluation and an increased supervision from the Commonwealth and a regulation of the system, to suggest that that will by definition lead to decline and deterioration, is a very strange path to follow. When there was insufficient evidence, when there was a lack of evidence, as was the case in the committee of inquiry, I was concerned and expressed my concern at that stage through the minority report, the dissenting report. But since then the considerable amount of work that has been done has revealed the evidence which I have referred to several times. Therefore the Democrats will not be supporting the amendments of the coalition in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the time, it is not appropriate for me to speak for long, but I will say that it seems to me that the proposition that has been put forward by Senator Bell could quite adequately be put forward if he were to vote with the opposition and maintain the CAP structure. I am not really prepared, as a senator representing the state of Tasmania, to just simply leave this in the hands of the agreements between the state and the Commonwealth. Because the Commonwealth has got money and has got the whip hand, it can get the states to sign anything. We know that. Getting particularly to the point Senator Bell made, I want to refer to a letter addressed to me personally. I am sure that the person would not mind. It is from the Mitta Murray Country Education Project, and it says this in paragraph 2:

SPEECH.PARA: The Victorian State Government's decision to dispense the CAP funds to individual schools as part of their push to self-managing schools causes concern in many of our rural communities. While existing structures can always be improved, to allow the States to dispense with a system that includes processes and incentives for clustering is an extremely retrograde step. Just giving money to an isolated school does not overcome isolation. In fact it can make schools more isolated. Isolation is not overcome by spending say a $3,000 grant just on books or a computer, in the same way that these items reduce socioeconomic disadvantage as in the DSP program. However, schools working and planning together, sharing joint programs, working with their communities and accessing ideas and information from other parts of the State does help address isolation issues. `Broad banding' does not require States to develop structures to encourage or protect the best practices learnt under the existing CAP structure.

And so it goes on. I think it is a very important illustrative factor. We can all stand here and talk about the bush. I went to a bush school—and probably that shows at times. It was an isolated bush school in South Australia, as a matter of fact. But I do not want to get into that situation.

PARA.TAB: We have a program that, everyone appears to agree, is a good and worthwhile program. All of these other matters and agreements can improve the situation perhaps, but why change the priority program and leave it in the lap of agreements between the state and the Commonwealth, with the Commonwealth holding the whip hand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that I rise immediately to deal with the matter addressed by Senator Harradine because it impinges upon the case that I was putting for non-support of the amendments. Senator Harradine quoted the same letter that I was quoting from, and it is the perception in that letter that I need to address. Early in Senator Harradine's contribution he quoted from the letter where it read:

SPEECH.PARA: The Victorian State Government's decision to dispense the CAP funds to individual schools as part of their push to their push to self-managing schools—

The minister may be able to elaborate on this, but I think that is precisely why I do not have before me an agreement with the Victorian state government. It is the Victorian state government's propositions which would not be supported in an agreement because of the style of agreement which is necessary. I quote from another agreement I have, under the heading `Priority country area component':
Schools in declared country areas are the only schools eligible for PCAP funds.

In other words, a school in an urban area would not be able to access PCAP funds. That is the accusation that is made time and time again to support the case that is being put by the coalition—that they will be drained off to a more streetwise, shall we say, submission group from an inner urban area which may demonstrate disadvantage. That disadvantage may well be there, but it is not disadvantage through isolation. It is the disadvantage through isolation being addressed through the CAP funds that is being treated by those people who are receiving it; and they want to keep it.

PARA.TAB: Schools in declared country areas are the only schools eligible for PCAP funds. That is the basis of an agreement; that is where it starts and it continues. These schools apply for funds through submissions. Submissions are assessed at local area cluster committees which may also apply for funds for the cluster through submissions. Declared country areas in this particular agreement are regionalised into four areas; management committees in the four areas assess submissions from clusters and approve grants. Area committees may also allocate notional amounts for cluster committees. The state management committee oversees the operation at the area committees and meets three to four times a year.

At the moment there are no such safeguards. At the moment there are no such regulations covering how it will be done. At the moment there has been some evidence—I do not want to dwell on this because that is not the important point—that the intention of the PCAP to provide for education needs is in fact being avoided to some extent, and the needs that are being met are community needs. I will not elaborate there because that is not the point of the argument; it does not really matter. The improvement as I see it is an improvement in regulation and certainty that the PCAP funds will be used by rural schools. They will meet educational needs and they will be evaluated.

At the moment the evaluation process is most suspect. The same letter that Senator Harradine quoted from said that this year around $300,000 was hived off for a gender equity program but for next year about $400,000 has been allocated. Fluidity benefits some, but generally not all, students in rural areas. It is precisely for that reason that I think evaluation should be tighter and agreements should be signed. Senator Harradine is right. The Commonwealth has got the money; it can make the states sign anything and I am convinced that it should. It should. I believe the criticism contained in the same letter Senator Harradine referred to illustrates why we need to make sure that the PCAP program stays, but that it is properly evaluated and agreements for its delivery are entered into.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rather than argue the point, I seek leave to have the whole letter incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mitta Murray
Country Education Project

PARA.TAB: C/- The Hub,
TALLANGATTA, 3700
Telephone: (060)712 682

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Brian
RE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

The Mitta Murray Country Education Project Area Committee is a part of the Country Areas Program (CAP), known as the Country Education Project in Victoria. East of Albury/Wodonga many of the 21 schools are located in essentially dead-end finger-like valleys.

The Victoria State Government's decision to dispense the CAP funds to individual schools as part of their push to self-managing schools causes concern in many of our rural communities. While existing structures can always be improved, to allow the States to dispense with a system that includes processes and incentives for clustering is an extremely retrograde step. Just giving money to an isolated school does not overcome isolation. In fact it can make schools more isolated. Isolation is not overcome by spending say a $3000 grant on just books or a computer, in the same way that these item reduce socioeconomic disadvantage as in the DSP program. However, schools working and planning together, sharing joint programs, working with their communities and accessing ideas and information from other parts of the State does help address isolation issues. "Broad banding" does not require States to develop structures to encourage or protect the best practices learnt under the existing CAP structure. Left alone man tends to degenerate not aspire.

Schools in this Area are very concerned with the "Broad banding" proposal and the flexibility and fluidity allowed between the various Targeted Program groups. This year around $300,00 was hived off for a Gender Equity Program and next around $400,00 has been allocated. Fluidity benefits some, but generally not students in rural areas. Rural students are much fewer in number than their counterparts in programs such as DSP and by nature of geographic isolation more vulnerable to deprivations.

Rural disadvantage or isolation is unique as a targeted parameter, as many of the services accessible to city and regional centre students are not readily available to rural students. Existing State services are being cut back continually as is demonstrated by the recent replacement of State District education workers in large central schools and not in rural schools. (It has been suggested that CAP schools could use their CAP funds to pay travel for these workers to service rural schools!!!) Rural communities and their students need to create their own solutions to overcome the tyranny of distance and CAP funds to Areas with the resulting development of cluster models has allowed this. The Victoria State appears not to have liked the innovation and new ideas (and activities) that have resulted from schools and their communities accessing CAP funds to collectively address their needs.

Rural schools are appreciative of CAP support and they do not want to see the State Governments hijack an equity program that has been suitably targeted to assist rural students in overcoming educational disadvantage resulting from rural living.

You are urged to give due consideration to the points we have raised and to not sell out a program that addresses the unique needs of rural students. Please vote for the Amendment and support rural Australia.
Thanking you
Your faithfully
Fay Whitehead
Chairperson
Mitta Murray Country Ed Project.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put the government's view on the record on this issue about the opposition's amendment. The opposition apparently wants to amend this bill in the belief that geographically isolated students will somehow be disadvantaged by its provisions. The flexibility of broadbanding in no way diminishes the rights of rural and isolated children to Commonwealth equity funding. The reality is that it will allow funds to be much more effectively targeted to the most needy students—those who are both poor and isolated, including Aboriginal students. This intersection of the disadvantaged is not properly handled or targeted under existing separate programs; the new, more flexible arrangements recognise the need and allow schools to help a broader range of students, especially those in greatest need.

PARA.TAB: The opposition senators seem to think that their colleagues in the states are not to be trusted with greater flexibility to administer this part of the equity program. I just want to point out that I am advised that the states have indicated, including a number of states with coalition governments, that they are willing to sign the agreements which Senator Bell is talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one has signed. What about Queensland?

—The reason they have not signed is they are waiting for this bill. As I understand it, the carriage of this bill will then lead to the actual signing. I imagine if I were on their side, I would wait to see what was in the bill before I agreed to sign. Nevertheless, I am advised the indication is they are willing to sign once the bill is carried as is, without the opposition amendment.

PARA.TAB: The new arrangements have some other benefits as well. The new arrangements for the states and non-government authorities will make commitments to objectives, targets and the reporting of student outcomes for all equity target groups. They will also limit the funds which can be diverted for administration. For the first time, the country will know how much in total, Commonwealth, state and non-government sector, we are investing in the education of disadvantaged students.

The government has listened very carefully to the interest groups and has been strongly influenced by them in the development of the NEPS. It rejected the advice of the broadbanding task force to amalgamate the old disadvantaged schools and country areas programs, recognising the integrity of the needs of rural and isolated students. It not only kept the programs separate but it kept the indices separate as well in further recognition of the concerns of country people.

It is introducing flexibility with responsibility by requiring, for the first time ever, public accountability and reporting, something we have never really had. All this reflects the government's intention to keep faith with its country clients. The government is firmly committed to the view that broadbanding in the equity program is in the best interests of both poor and isolated students and it does not intend to depart from that view.

The intention of item 9, one of the clauses in Senator Teague's amendments, appears to be to prevent the inclusion in NEPS agreements between the Commonwealth and states and non-government education authorities of conditions which allow the movement of funds between country areas and disadvantaged students. The wording of the proposal does not achieve this intention. It prohibits conditions which require the authority to apply country area funds to other than geographically isolated students. The amendment is also technically incorrect in referring to section 73, which refers to a component relating to literacy and learning which ceases at the end of 1993.

I will just get the information the honourable senator asked for about Queensland. The advice I have just been given is that the draft is ready to sign. The education minister in Queensland, Mr Comben, has publicly said CAP would not change in Queensland. This is reflected in the draft agreement which will become a public document.

I want to take up Senator Harradine's and Senator Bell's remarks. They said that this is a Commonwealth funded program, whether it is under NEPS, whether it is the country areas program or the disadvantaged schools program, which is a tied-grant funded arrangement from the Commonwealth government. They are both right. If people have got the money, in the end they can achieve a lot because they can allocate the resources how they see fit and it is our money that is being allocated. I have to say that that is the bottom line and always will be. I am very pleased that arrangement is there. I am very pleased that the Commonwealth taxpayer has that power and that strength and that position for negotiating with the states and that ability to say, `If you do not agree in the end, there may not be any money'. I think all honourable senators—

TALK.START.PARA: —That goes for independent schools; it goes for everything.

—I think what it means is people have a better influence over Commonwealth funding under tied grants than if they were untied. Senators can rise in parliament and ask questions of ministers, such as me, about what is happening to the Commonwealth outlays in particular programs, whether it is education or whatever. I would have thought Senator Harradine would appreciate that. It is better than allowing state governments with untied grants to allocate money that we have contributed to revenue. This chamber would have no direct influence on how the money is being spent.
—Don't talk about me. What about the people?

—Of course, and you represent the people of Tasmania. Under tied grants you get the opportunity to have an influence in the parliamentary process of the Australian parliament to say how that money ought to be spent. Whether you think you are effective or not is a matter of personal judgment, but you certainly have the potential to be more effective than if it is just given as an untied grant to a state government. And remember, as I say, that you are responsible, like all of us, for carriage of legislation that raises the problem of revenues. Therefore, in my view, you should have an equal right to say in debates in this chamber.
—That is an interesting observation about constitutional responsibility. I will remind you of it.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Senator Harradine, order, please. Minister, would you direct your comments through the chair, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Madam Temporary Chairman. I should not encourage him by responding directly to his interjections, but I think Senator Harradine raises an issue that is of fundamental importance about the constitutional responsibility of the federal government vis-a-vis the states. I make no bones about it: I am very pleased that in a whole range of areas the Commonwealth, through the constitution, has the ability, through tied grants, to ensure that we get good outcomes for the expenditure of Commonwealth money, even those that are administered by state programs and state ministers, because we get agreements. Whether it is the country areas program or the disadvantaged schools program, they are both in the overall NEPS and that is a tied grant.
—Minister, you are not convincing.

—I was going to use the word `recalcitrant'. States righters such as Senator Teague are not convinced that the Commonwealth should use this exercise, but I would have to say that in recent years I think the Australian public—
—I am talking about parental rights and educational diversity, not centralist control.

—I think that Senator Harradine and I are talking at cross purposes here. I agree with him that this deals with parental matters and, as a result of our tied grants, he has an effective say here in the parliament about how that should be discharged.

PARA.TAB: I want to conclude these remarks by saying that, irrespective of the issue about the broadbanding structure itself, what the government proposes in here is a much more open and transparent evaluation program for how the money is being spent, whether it is in the disadvantaged schools program or in the country areas program. As I remarked earlier, these proposals by the government will mean that this parliament, this chamber, will be able to have a better monitoring role in looking at the evaluation of the effectiveness of these programs and how the money is spent.

I would have thought one of the areas that everybody in the Senate seems to agree on is that it should be a role of the Senate, through the estimates committees, to argue about effective evaluation of government expenditure. Here we are putting in these proposals, for the first time under this broadbanding arrangement, that effective evaluation that is more open and more transparent. I should have thought all of us would welcome that, particularly members of the opposition, because it gives them the chance to raise these issues in estimates committees and in the parliament.

I believe that the proposal before us is an excellent step forward in getting a more open and transparent outcome that improves the ability of isolated and disadvantaged children, whether they are in the city or in the country, to be better served by this program; and we are all able to see the effectiveness of those programs.

As a person who, like Senator Harradine, spent most of my childhood and teenage years growing up in a country area, I am more than sympathetic to the view that rural areas have special circumstances in isolation that have to be addressed by a national government to ensure that, in terms of equity, children in rural areas get the same access to decent education as those in the city. That always has to be the bottom line of a national government with a national objective of equity. Therefore, I think that the proposal on broadbanding goes a long way to improving that outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very difficult decision for the Greens. Basically, it is an issue of responsiveness versus safeguards. There is a need for states to be more responsive to filling communities' needs. The government has the right motive but probably the wrong thinking. It thinks the states are closer to the communities than is the Commonwealth for decision making. It will be interesting to replay during the Mabo debate some of these arguments between the coalition and the Labor Party. It seems quite extraordinary; but fine, the government should not usurp community decision making to meet its ends, which seems to defeat the purpose.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, we are concerned about the safeguards; we want to make sure that they are responsive to communities for DSP and CAP ratios. A parent, teacher or school council voicing opposition can take it up with the state DEET. The only way a minister can overturn it is if they can prove the states do not have satisfactory arrangements in place. If the structure is in place, it would be very difficult for that program to be adjusted. If DEET can back its decision with statistics, then it is in the clear. On the whole, it has been a difficult decision but, in the final analysis, we have decided to support the opposition's amendment, and the status quo, in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must reiterate that the Democrats have come to this conclusion because we asked the very same questions Senator Margetts asked and found that, at present, those safeguards do not exist. That is what this legislation is proposing. We support it because it guarantees the continuation of the PCAP's aims. For somebody to conduct a campaign around Australia which says, `PCAP is threatened, it is going to stop; vote against it', is so simple, so primitive, so crude and so wrong. We investigated those claims. We found them to be dishonest, misleading and thoroughly to be condemned, because they have alarmed country people throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: Everybody is claiming that they grew up in the country and so on. I have been associated with this sort of business at the receiving end, at the administrative end, and at the representative end, and I treasure what the PCAP is giving to Australian students. To say that it is threatened and that it is going to stop has alarmed and frightened so many people around this country that the campaign has worked. Those campaigners ought to be jolly well proud of themselves to have achieved that fear. What it has delivered is a stop to any chance of properly evaluating this program to ensure that what it is trying to deliver gets delivered. The faults Senator Harradine described in the famous letter that we have now had incorporated, where one state government is able to hive off $300,000 to an unassociated program, should stop. That is what we are trying to do. Putting this unfounded fear into people, suggesting that they ought to preserve a system which allows $300,000 to be taken from them and suggesting that that ought to be continued, is stupidity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my deep concern that this proposition by the government might not be supported by the committee because it fundamentally goes to the issue of accountability. It fundamentally goes to the issue of substitution. Those who are concerned about a national equity program have to be concerned about the capacity of state governments to transfer resources away from people who need them to people whom they believe, for political purposes, should get them. What this government proposal does is, for the first time, to provide a mechanism whereby there can be accountability.

PARA.TAB: In Western Australia today so-called joint programs for national equity consist entirely of Commonwealth money. This proposal by the government allows for the documentation of state inputs. The Commonwealth does not currently have that power in the present arrangements. It provides an opportunity to hold state politicians accountable for where they are allocating money. It undermines fundamentally those attacks upon equity programs by reactionary forces in Victoria who have closed 141 rural schools and we have not heard a word about that. We have heard great concern expressed about rural communities, but we have not seen any protest about what has been happening in terms of the on-the-ground situation. This government proposal advances equity, and the proposals that the opposition have presented in this place reinforce inequity.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of very quick concluding points. The government believes that this overall issue of broadbanding and better evaluation of this program is important. We will call a division, even though, I suspect, we are going to go down. When it goes back to the House of Representatives, it will be a matter for Mr Beazley or Mr Free to decide whether they want to insist on the position or not. It is a matter for them to make that judgment.

PARA.TAB: I want to point out, as Senator Carr has in general pointed out and as others have said—including, I must say, strong remarks by Senator Bell—that the issue in this amendment is not so much the broadbanding arrangement itself but the evaluation that we are getting value for our money in equity for disadvantaged and isolated children. I have been advised, for example, that under the program in Queensland $17,000 was spent on providing floodlights for a polo field. I have to say that, if that is true, that ought to be properly evaluated.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking like Senator Kelly. I don't think you should bring that up. You are talking about responsible use of Commonwealth money.

—I find Senator Tierney's interjection astonishing. I have pointed out in the Senate on a number of occasions, as the minister representing Mrs Kelly in the Senate, there are letters from honourable senators opposite supporting the allocation of funds for those particular projects and supporting community funds. The evaluation of these programs is very important. If it is true that $17,000 was spent on floodlights for a polo field in Queensland under the CAP program, I think that is a reasonable question that ought to be looked at and evaluated. I would think that Senator Tierney, with his interest and background in education, would, like me, at least want to find out the justification for that grant. Questions are asked endlessly about such matters in the estimates committees, and I fully support that process. It has to be open and transparent.

PARA.TAB: We believe it is not just an issue of the broadbanding of the two programs together; it is also an issue of evaluation to ensure that Commonwealth money, through the tied grants administered by the states, is spent effectively within the principles of the program to get equity for all children in the Australian education system, no matter where they live. As a result, we will call a division on this and we may come back to the committee in the next day or so as a result of the decision that, I suspect, unfortunately the committee is about to make

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition continues to call on all honourable senators to support the amendment to preserve the country areas program. The last plea of the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) was on the 2 a grounds of evaluation. Nobody is standing in the way of evaluation. No-one is standing in the way of the CAP moneys being used for the best outcomes for country children. There is nothing stopping that evaluation. Reference has been made to there being state guarantees that there will be undiminished moneys for the CAP. That is a `hope so' intention of this government. No agreements are in place; no intention to sign an agreement is in place.

PARA.TAB: What we have before us is one issue: will the amount of resources for the country areas program be preserved? Will the country areas program be preserved, or will it be lost, submerged, broadbanded flexibly into an unknown? That is the issue, and that is why I believe that a majority of the committee has adopted the correct position, and the wisest position on behalf of children in rural areas, to ensure that, by this set of amendments, the country areas program is retained.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Teague's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 20, page 13, after proposed subparagraph 6(4)(b)(ii), add:
"or (iii) non-government disadvantaged schools;".
2.Clause 23, page 15, after proposed paragraph 71A(2)(b), add:
"or (c) non-government disadvantaged schools;".
3.Clause 24, page 18, after proposed paragraph 72B(2)(b) add:
"; or (c) non-government schools:
(i)if a ministerial determination in respect of that State under section 13 is in force—in prescribed country areas in the State;

TAB.TAB: or
(ii)if such a determination is not in force—in geographically isolated areas in the State.".

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 30, page 20, after proposed paragraph 65A(2)(b), add:
"or (c) non-government schools;".
5.Clause 30, page 21, proposed subsection 65A(5), line 5, after "an approved school system" add "or non-government schools".
6.Clause 30, page 22, after proposed subsection 65B(2)(b), add:
"or (c) non-government schools;".
7.Clause 30, page 22, proposed subsection 65B(5), line 19, after the words "an approved school system" add "or non-government schools".
8.Clause 33, page 24, proposed paragraph 68A(2)(c), after "non-government centres" add "or non-government schools".
9.Clause 34, page 26, proposed subsection 69B(1), line 28, after "non-government centre" add the words "or non-government school".
10.Clause 34, page 26, proposed subsection 69B(2)(b), line 33 after "non-government centre" add "or non-government school".

The bill before us provides that funds for various equity programs are to be allocated by the minister to either a nominated authority in connection with non-government schools or the approved authority of an approved school system. Funds cannot be allocated by the minister to individual schools, as is the case at present and as has long been the case. This is a change that is putting in place an authority in each state to allocate moneys to independent non-government schools.

PARA.TAB: We do not support this innovation. It is undesirable. It is objected to by non-government schools. It will force independent schools to act as if they are a system, not individual schools. They have to be a part of some authority to which they will have to be very responding because that will be the authority that will distribute moneys from the taxpayer to those individual schools. The minister himself, by this innovation, would be avoiding having to make decisions about allocating funds to individual schools by handing that task over to a nominated body. We believe this task should remain with the minister and that the minister should be, in the normal way, accountable to the parliament and to the community for decisions about these allocations of moneys.

I note that a number of independent schools have put this argument to us, an argument that we fully accept. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a two-page letter from the Association of Independent Schools of Victoria.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: ASSOCIATION OF INDEPENDENT SCHOOLS OF VICTORIA INCORPORATED
20 Garden Street,
South Yarra. Victoria 3141
9 December 1993
Senator Baden Teague
Parliament House
CANBERRA VIC 2600
Dear Senator
RE: STATE GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993.

I write on behalf of the Association to request that you give consideration to moving amendments to the above Bill, to ensure that the Minister retains responsibility for the National Equity Program (NEPS) funding decisions relating to Victorian independent schools.

The proposed sub-sections 67A(2), 67A(3), 67A(6), 69A(2) and 69A(7) dealing with Special Education programs, preserve the option for the Minister to make a determination approving funding for schools as distinct from the nominated authority. However, the proposed sub-sections 6(4) and 71A(2)—Disadvantaged Schools Program, 65A(2) and 65B(2) and 65B(2)—ESL, 72B(2)—Country Areas Program, and 68A(2)—Intervention Support, totally preclude leaving the final decision with the Minister.
These subsections require amendments similar to the wording in the subsections relating to Special Education programs. A non legal summary of amendments is attached as a guide.

The reason for seeking this amendment goes to the heart of the democratic process. Without this amendment the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, as an elected member of the Federal Government, absolves himself of his responsibility for management and decision making over taxpayers' funds.

In the words of DEET staff, the purpose of the amendments is to ensure that "there is no scope for blaming the Minister for decisions". That blame will be shifted to "nominated authorities" such as AISV, a voluntary user pay service organisation for Victorian independent schools.

It is interesting to note that the Federal Minister retains decision-making power in relation to the National Students at Risk Program because again according to Department of Employment Education and Training staff, this is a program of significance. In light of the Discussion Paper and the White Paper on Employment Opportunities to be released in December 1993 and June 1994 respectively, it would appear that the Minister wants to be associated with these decisions, but not with others affecting, students in the Disadvantaged Schools, Country Education, English as a Second Language and other programs.
AISV notes your Party's concern about the broad banding approach to targeted programs such as the Country Areas Program and Disadvantaged Schools Program and your intention to seek amendments.

AISV believes that unless the above amendments are introduced, the Federal Minister has the capacity to further remove himself from public and parliamentary scrutiny and more seriously to exercise Ministerial discretion and political expediency by transferring funds from programs such as CAP and DSP to the National STAR Program, at the time of the release of the Employment Opportunities papers. The recent Parliamentary debate over sports grants highlights the importance of Ministerial accountability for public funding and the need for the amendments AISV requests.

The Association would appreciate the opportunity of discussing this matter with you and/or your advisers before the Bill is reintroduced to the House of Representatives in the week beginning 13 December 1993.
With best wishes,
Yours sincerely
FIONA OGILVY-O'DONNELL
Executive Director

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the committee. I just say, by the way, that this letter could have been delayed to other honourable senators. I have certain knowledge of other letters, important to this debate, that have not reached us in the past week, unfortunately, because there has been a deliberate postal boycott on the mail of members of parliament, including senators. This letter was posted on 9 December. I received it yesterday afternoon, a week later. Yet it is a vital matter that has been quite reinforcing to the way we were formulating this amendment yesterday. I quote two paragraphs. The first states:

SPEECH.PARA: I write on behalf of the Association to request that you give consideration to moving amendments to the above Bill, to ensure that the Minister retains responsibility for the National Equity Program (NEPS) funding decisions relating to Victorian independent schools.
Another paragraph states:

The reason for seeking this amendment goes to the heart of the democratic process. Without this amendment the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, as an elected member of the Federal Government, absolves himself of his responsibility for management and decision making over taxpayers' funds.

I commend the whole body of that letter. It is exactly parallel with the Liberal and National parties moving these quite similar amendments. There are 10 of them, all relating to clauses that have to do with this allocation of money. I conclude by saying that this government should not be forcing independent schools to be systemic against their wishes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting this set of amendments. We have been advised, and we are informed by a variety of individual schools and associations that the case, as Senator Teague has put it, of independent schools being able to remain independent of each other as well as independent of the state government education provisions is a very important matter for independent schools and is compromised by the government's proposal.

PARA.TAB: The method of applying equity programs at the moment is a method which ensures that independent schools, regardless of their association with each other, regardless of their level of acceptance by their peers or their association with the `establishment'—the group which establishes itself as the traditional providers of independent non-government education—have the opportunity to apply on merit to the minister and not be influenced by their degree of association with each other or with any other system. As far as we are concerned, that opportunity guarantees the access there should be under this equity program. I think Senator Teague has expressed the argument with clarity and accuracy, and we support that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what has been said by Senator Teague and Senator Bell. It is important, as far as I am concerned, because this is a matter for decision particularly by parents with children attending independent schools. They should not as a condition, in order to get access to the program, have to be associated with a systemic system. That is tautologous, I know, but I do not know how to put it otherwise. I will be supporting the Opposition's and the Democrats' position on this.
—The Greens (WA) will also be supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation gives effect to arrangements which bring decision making closer to the students and their schools by giving non-government education authorities in the states and territories responsibility for administering NEPS in their states. The further amendments moved by Senator Teague, in our view, seek to undermine these arrangements.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought many people, particularly ideologically, in the Opposition would have been more than happy to support non-government schools and education authorities being given the responsibility for administering NEPS in their states. They are closer to it. The argument many opposite use is that Canberra is too remote, the minister is too remote. Here is an opportunity for them to put their hands up for something that devolves responsibility to people closer to running the education systems in the non-government area.

If the committee is of the view that devolution should not occur, so be it. It is probably an interesting observation about people who are not willing, when the crunch is on, to devolve authority, to give some authority back to the grassroots of education, to those actually administering NEPS and taking that responsibility. Of course, even under what we are proposing, the minister would still be ultimately responsible if people were complaining about what was going on. That would be an open and transparent process. Nevertheless, if that is the committee's view, it will be referred back to the minister, and I will take advice from him about what he wants to do in view of the committee's position.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
