TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 11, page 4, paragraph (e), line 13, omit the definition of "basic course of study".

This is the first of three amendments which will abolish the double rate of higher education contribution charges the government proposed in the budget and which have passed the House of Representatives. That, of course, is in this bill before us now. The opposition opposes this new double HECS rate that would apply ordinarily in our universities. I have outlined half a dozen reasons why the Liberal and National parties have taken this position. I am very glad that a majority of senators will see the end of double HECS for the students of our universities.

PARA.TAB: In brief, we do not want to see penalties on women, on the handicapped, on those from overseas with a first degree, on those with any kind of difficulty in defining whether they have a first degree or not. We do not want to see any difficulty for combined degrees where two specialties are put together in the one person's ability to help in the profession and to help the whole nation. We want the clever country; we want to see no penalties being placed upon Australians gaining two degrees if that is going to help them to be more competent to serve in Australia.

This is a recognition that we want to have a major encouragement for Australians to improve their educational foundation for professional work. We do not want to see the signal this government is proposing that says, `Don't do a second degree. We will punish you for it with a higher charge'. We want to see a signal that gives encouragement for Australians to take on that second degree. With all the anomalies and all the difficulties of definition that the government has been proposing, we say that we have no confidence in the government's proposal. We reject it utterly.

I know that the final point is that the government will say, `We are going to save some money and apply that money to some who are, at the moment, not able to gain admission to a university'. That is their main argument. I say that we must find a better solution than this. We must not put penalties on those who will strive for excellence. Rather, let us adopt a proposal such as the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee has put, such as the opposition has put, such as we put at the last election, that would open the doors for these extra enrolments and not deny any Australian access to enrolling in a university. This is not the signal we should be giving to Australia. I am very glad that there will be support for this and the other two amendments. There will be no double HECS in our universities.

TALK.START.PARA: —We welcome this amendment from the coalition. We will not be precious by arguing about who thought of it first and who moved it first. We believe that this is a cake which deserves to be baked, and whether the eggs went in first or the flour came in second is irrelevant to the final product. While enthusiastically supporting the notion of removing barriers to participation in higher education, Senator Teague has identified the very next step the coalition needs to take to arrive at true enlightenment in education policies. That step is to remove all barriers to those who have the capacity, those who have the merit, those who have the need to participate in education.

PARA.TAB: The removal of all barriers would be an endorsement of the Democrats' philosophy that education should be available to all, regardless of their socio-economic background, their race, their religion, their creed or any other personal characteristics. Therefore, the concept of user pays, which delivers education only to those who can afford to pay for it, is a concept that should be recognised as providing the ultimate barrier and finally dismissed from all education policies of all political parties.

We will be interested to watch the passage of this new enlightenment through the coalition's approach and the recognition that to be consistent with the stance today would be to recognise that need for true equity in education policy. In doing that, there would be the need to dismiss the sort of attitude we saw promoted at the last election, when user pays reigned supreme.

However, I want to dwell not on that area but rather on the pleasant prospect of getting rid of this double HECS proposition, the double curse in education, and to enjoy and savour this moment of the combination of Democrats' support for a coalition amendment that is identical to the Democrats' amendment in my name, which honourable senators have before them. The coalition amendment, which expresses exactly the same purpose as our amendment, is to be supported; and I am enjoying every moment of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will also be supporting the opposition amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments moved by the opposition and supported by the Democrats and the Greens. The HECS changes announced in the bill are designed to ensure that as many Australians as possible have access to higher education. The proposed changes are equitable as they will ensure that those who have a chance to participate should contribute to the cost of that benefit in the fairest way possible.

PARA.TAB: The measures acknowledge that in a climate of budgetary restraint the opportunities for newcomers to the system, including recent school leavers, have to be protected. While places have increased significantly since 1988—and I think it is a major achievement of the government to increase the number of places in higher education by 95,000 since 1988—a substantial proportion of those places have gone to graduates undertaking further undergraduate qualification or to postgraduate students.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a terrible thing to happen!
—Let me finish, Senator Tierney, before you make a prejudicial judgment. Opportunities for school leavers have fallen by 8.1 per cent between 1990 and 1993.
—Provide more places; don't take them away from the others.

—Of course. Will those opposite vote to put more money into higher education? As a permanent opposition, they would probably say yes because they do not have the responsibility for raising the revenue, and in the budget process this year they voted against every measure to raise revenue to pay for government outlays.
—You had no mandate for more taxes.

—Here they are interjecting, rather stupidly, that more money should be put in when they will not vote for the revenue to pay for it. That leads me to the conclusion that Senator Tierney actually supports full paying fees to raise the money.
—That's more lies like you were telling before the last election.

—I cannot work it out. Members of the opposition are now getting to the stage that they have been in opposition so long that they believe in one basic economic policy: spend more money, reduce taxation and balance the budget. That is the economic level those opposite have sunk to in their long period in opposition. That is the only thing they can think of and that is what they are raising here. Senator Tierney is saying to me, `Yes, there is more demand, spend more money', but he will not tell us—
—Fund it in a different way.

—Members opposite want to put full fees on. That is what they want to do and that is what they will do. All of the dry economic rationalists in the Liberal Party, led by David Kemp in the lower House, want to put full fees on. That is what they are all about. That will be Liberal Party policy.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: we should be debating the clause. Senator Schacht is throwing around wild assertions that have no foundations in truth. I think, with respect to relevance, you have got to exert some authority on the minister. We have allowed him a lot of latitude, but I think he should come back to debating the clause before the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—I think it has been a fairly free ranging debate, but I would appreciate it if the minister could finish up. I would like to get home before next Christmas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you filibustering?

—I am not filibustering at all. I am trying to respond to some assertions from the opposition. I want to emphasise that opportunities for school leavers have fallen by 8.1 per cent between 1990 and 1993. That is obviously reducing the opportunities for people to have access. We are trying to deal with the issue of how we open up positions. We believe that doubling the HECS amount for a second degree will make people think seriously about whether they want to do that degree, and whether they are doing it for other purposes not directly related to a career benefit for themselves. They have to make that judgment. I cannot think of anything more rational or reasonable to put to people. It will help the overall macro situation of the system when judgments are being made about the allocation of resources and who does what.
—Ask your own Labor Party branches. They will not agree with you.

—I do not know how many Labor Party branches Senator Teague has been to, but I think he ought to go to a few Liberal branches and talk to them about putting full fees on higher education and see how well he does.
—They do not support it.

—No student will be required to pay up front. Therefore, it should not prevent them from undertaking further study. As for normal HECS, they will pay it after they leave and start earning an income. I think the formula is based on above average weekly earnings. To say that this is an enormous imposition is just a distortion. We are saying to people that they ought to make some judgments about the value they are going to get from doing further undergraduate study, realising that, overwhelmingly, the community still funds all undergraduate studies. HECS does not raise a large proportion of the funding that is needed for higher education in Australia. It is a reasonable proportion, and it has been a very successful program. I must say to Senator Teague that when this was debated in the Labor Party at the national conference, I was a very strong proponent of HECS.
—Not double HECS.

—Let us take it one by one. I was a strong proponent of HECS because I believe that, until it is shown that everybody in the community is going to have access to higher education, those who have access to it, such as Senator Teague and I, should make some contribution. I think we have pointed out that students will not have to pay up front. In no case will any of the students cited by the opposition as being disadvantaged be required to pay up front. If they overcome the claimed disadvantage and attain average salary or above, they will be required to pay double HECS. There will also be exemptions to certain students, including students who acquire a disability after they have completed their first qualification and who are required to retain it in order to change their field of employment.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, migrants with overseas qualifications not recognised as being equivalent will not be charged double HECS. Also, students in combined or double degree courses will not pay double HECS. In conclusion, I point out that this obviously has revenue implications. Therefore, although every other party in the committee has indicated its opposition, we will still be calling a division.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not spoken so far on the amendments because I have been hoping that we would move this through fairly quickly, but that has not been happening. I must place on the public record a response to some of the most outrageous things the minister has said in relation to the opposition's position on double HECS. As the minister is well aware, the double HECS was never a proposition in our policy before the last election.
—Full fees were.

—No, full fees were not. I thank the minister for that interjection. Let me hit that right on the head straight away, particularly as far as his colleague in the electorate of Robertson is concerned. At a public meeting in Gosford, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Walker) made the most outrageous statements and lied about the opposition's position in front of an audience of 660 Catholic parents. They had to be refuted at that spot. At no point was that our policy. Those misrepresentations around the countryside were just part of the Labor Party's campaign of lies which helped it get into government this time on a very misleading sort of campaign.

PARA.TAB: At no point did we support doubling HECS. I search in vain through the ALP policy of that time to find any whisper or any mention of even increasing HECS at all, let alone doubling it in one hit to probably some of the most disadvantaged groups in the community, who are the ones being hit with this proposal. One would wonder why the government is doing it. It is going to raise $10 million a year, which is hardly a huge amount of money in a $4 billion budget. Why a party that is supposed to be about social justice, about access and equity, would hit the groups that really need access and equity is totally beyond me at this point.

I believe the government stands condemned with the student community for doing this. Let me assure the minister that, in the run-up to the next election, aided and abetted by the Democrats, we will be pointing out to the student groups around this country that they cannot trust a Labor government; they should not believe anything it says in its policy. It lied to students last time. It was duplicitous, and it will be this time. The Labor Party has given us a great opportunity to give it a big serve in the next election.
With the Democrats, we support the amendments. It seems as though yet again on this matter the Labor Party is on the wrong track. It will be rejected by the committee.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Teague's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 12 and 14—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will oppose these two clauses. All the arguments have been put abundantly in the debate already.

—The Democrats also will be opposing these clauses, as indicated on our amendment sheet. I agree with Senator Teague about the arguments that have been put—not all of them, because the minister did assert that what was proposed in the bill was the way to increase education funding. However, there are many ways to increase funding for education. One of them is to spend more money in education by reducing expenditure on things such as submarines and things for which it is very difficult to indicate a real and tangible benefit. We will not go into that argument because the argument itself has been rehearsed. I just indicate that the Democrats also oppose clauses 12 and 14.

PARA.TAB: Clauses negatived.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments have the effect of altering the government's proposal to increase the rate of taxation repayment of the HECS debt and also lowering the income threshold at which that repayment begins. Although this argument has been rehearsed, and it was mentioned clearly in the second reading debate, I note that it is indicative of the approach the government has taken to those who study at tertiary level. The approach is that it is a personal benefit that is derived and that those who are engaging in study have to pay for it because it is their benefit.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats' attitude and approach to this is that the community benefits greatly. Those who are able, and have the capacity to study at that level, do their country a great service by giving up their time and foreshortening their careers by continuing to study and develop fully their particular talents. The community as a whole benefits directly, indirectly, in the short term and in the long term from investing in the education of its citizens.

This is an effect that is not apparent to some people in decision making areas. This is an effect that some people find it hard to come to grips with because they cannot see the cash money benefit; they cannot see the community flow-on as easily as they can when somebody cuts down a tree and says, `There is an export; we can make a dollar out of it'. The effect was illustrated recently when we had the little fiasco with regard to Malaysian trade. There was a threat to Malaysia's participation in Australia's education system, for which Malaysian students are paying. The multimillion dollar purchase of Australian education by Malaysian students was identified while that little fiasco was taking place, and that purchase was identified as an immediate, direct, export benefit for Australia. Because of that, there has been an increase in community appreciation of the tangible value of a good education system and of proper investment in education.

The point is now a little easier to make that we should not penalise those who develop their given talents to the fullest extent. We should encourage them because it brings community benefit. Because that point is a little easier to make, I have moved this block of amendments in the wistful hope that the government will recognise that its proposals are penalising that participation and that the Democrats' proposals would reduce that penalty and encourage people to participate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, the government opposes these amendments from the Democrats.

—I have listened carefully to Senator Bell, as we do with the Democrats. I think in every year since HECS was introduced they have consistently argued against there being any user-pay element for the students of Australia. This is not the view of the Liberal and National parties; it is not the view of the government; so they are in a small minority.

PARA.TAB: The corollary of the Democrats' position is that the taxes on all Australians will be considerably increased. The corollary of the Democrats' position is a high tax approach to the decisions we make in this chamber. The Liberal and National parties reject. We want a responsible balance in what should be a small user-pay element for the students in our universities—20 per cent. Even then, it is not paid compulsorily up front. It is a debt to be paid when employed, and only if employed.

Senator Schacht has said that he argued for the HECS approach on the floor of the national conference of the Labor Party. The Liberal and National parties now have, in a very similar way, a commitment to the HECS mechanism as being a fair one. In fact, I am confident that a majority of students believe that this is a fair thing. A majority of students regard this as being their appropriate contribution to their own education. It is for these reasons—it is now a settled consensus by an overwhelming majority in the parliament—that we reject the Democrats' amendments with regard to the whole idea of HECS. Of course, that is the way Senator Bell would put it—`the whole idea of HECS'. We respect his minority views, but they are not acceptable to us.

I raise one additional matter. I refer to my colleague the Liberal member for Sturt, Mr Chris Pyne, who is the youngest member of the parliament and not far away from having been a student himself. He is one of the few in this parliament to have actually paid HECS. This good new Liberal member for Sturt has in our party discussions contributed an argument that I wish to refer to, that is, that the government has without warning, without including it in the election campaign, increased the rate of repayment of HECS for the students of Australia.

It is after consultation with students that the member for Sturt objects to that in principle. He has been able to put his views, and it has been a matter of judgment within the Liberal and National parties whether or not the government's initiative to increase the rate of payment on the students of Australia unilaterally and without warning—a one-sided contract where the government has all the signatures—is a fair thing in principle.

Some months ago, when Mr Pyne put that view, it was Senator Bell who moved a motion in this chamber congratulating Mr Pyne and urging that that be the view taken by all honourable senators. I do not imply that Senator Bell was wishing to embarrass the honourable member for Sturt because his views did not eventually prevail within my parties, but I want to recognise that this is the kind of consultation with students, with vice-chancellors and with all the education industry, all education institutions, we commend. There is no embarrassment, only plaudits, for Liberal members such as Mr Pyne and the consultation he takes on matters such as this.

This is not what the Liberal and National parties would have done in government. This is a decision that has been taken by the Labor government. It is the elected government. This is an integral and substantial part of the budget, and we traditionally allow the elected government its budget.

This Labor government has deceived the students of Australia by not only doubling HECS for some students, wanting to put a one-and-a-half times HECS on other students and increasing the rates of repayments of students, when none of these proposals, all of which were in the budget, was in any way referred to by the Labor Party prior to the last election. Rather, government members went around the campuses of Australia scaring students into not supporting the Liberal and National parties by putting forward the lie that we would introduce full fees for all students. It was a lie; it remains a lie. They scared a lot of students into supporting them.

Let it be understood that we have not gone back on anything we have said prior to an election. We were honest in the election. The Labor Party was not honest. The Labor Party has deceived the students of Australia. It is on the Labor Party's head that the matters that are before us right now are being placed upon the students of Australia.

I conclude by referring to the letter I received this week from the National President of the National Union of Students. Mr Ken Fowlie wrote to my colleague Dr Michael Wooldridge, and in this letter he made five requests. He asked whether, in this final debate in the Senate, the Liberal and National parties would seek to achieve those five objectives. All I can say is that every one of those objectives has been achieved by our votes today. I think the National Union of Students should read every word of these education debates and students should judge for themselves that the Labor Party has been the deceiver of the students of Australia. If they want an honest broker, if they want a policy that will increase participation in our universities for those who are currently missing out, the way to do that is through the policies we put forward honestly before the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —The running sheet for this committee stage confuses me a little, but I know what I am moving at the moment and I think the committee understands what I am moving at the moment. It is important that I remind the committee that we are considering a block of amendments that oppose the government's intention to increase the rate of repayment of HECS and to decrease the threshold of income at which those repayments begin. Senator Teague made considerable play of the fact that the coalition was opposed to that trend. In fact, the first part of Senator Teague's speech addressed the Democrats' philosophy that HECS payments in general ought to be opposed. I do not deny that, and I do not deny his party's position. What I do find very strange is that, having said that, Senator Teague then spent some time congratulating the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) on his opposition to any change in the rate of repayment and the time at which repayments ought to start.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague spent a considerable amount of time addressing the fact that the government did not refer to this new impost, this alteration to the HECS situation, in the lead-up to the election. If Senator Teague does endorse HECS as well-established—I forget the actual words, but the impression was a consolidated approach—and if he endorses the status quo of circumstances which govern this scheme, then why deny the passage of amendments that seek to remove the changes? If Senator Teague supports what the government has done in the past with HECS, why support its changes? Why oppose the honourable member for Sturt, who eloquently argued that the government had betrayed students? Why does Senator Teague not support his own party member, whom he lauded in this place not five minutes ago? Why is he opposing his well-founded criticisms of the government's plans to change HECS to increase the penalty on students?

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is entitled to its major budget measures.

—I accept Senator Teague's interjection because that was the point of his contribution from that point on. If it is appropriate to oppose double HECS, if it is appropriate to make other changes, this minuscule fiddling about at the edges, which has an immeasurably small effect on the government's budget, has a huge effect on those people to whom it applies.

PARA.TAB: The excuse Senator Teague has given that the government has the right to expect the major direction of its budget is one that is shared by Senator Kernot and the Democrats. Senator Kernot expressed it very well on our behalf and achieved that. Within days of the budget we guaranteed the government the thrust of its intentions. This fiddling little amendment has a minuscule effect on the government's overall budget strategies. It is very difficult to remain consistent with the argument that it is important to change double HECS, an argument I congratulate the coalition upon. I cannot see that it can say that it is important to oppose that and yet not important to oppose this one, especially when so much time is spent congratulating the honourable member for Sturt for pointing out the inequities this proposal could bring to individuals. I think it is the height of hypocrisy to say that one aspect is worth opposing and the other one is not.

The point has been made; the argument has been run. I think it is very important that those people whom Senator Teague implored to read every word of this debate do so, because the words reveal quite readily what the problem is. The problem is one of picking and choosing which aspect will be easily understood and easily saleable. Double HECS is a phrase which has readily gained currency in the lines of student opposition. It is the sort of line that is easy to deliver at a street rally; it is the sort of concept that is easily saleable in a campaigning sense. Try describing this one. One look at the amendments is enough to put off anybody trying to explain exactly what is being achieved. We know. It is not easy to sell, and so it is not a particularly attractive amendment to agree with.

To put it simply, we are opposing the government's sleight of hand, the government's intention to increase the rate of HECS repayments and to reduce the threshold at which those repayments begin. I implore the coalition to see the sense of that. I implore it to recognise the consistency in doing that and in opposing the double HECS, and the consistency in doing that and in agreeing with the oft quoted honourable member for Sturt, the youngest Liberal member of parliament. He had his moment of glory at a student rally in Adelaide which I attended. He received the accolades of the students listening to him until it was realised that, even though he was wise for his years, he might not carry the clout to get through the very changes that ought to be got through shadow cabinet and the coalition. The students there were sceptical of his chances, and their scepticism was rightly observed.

The scepticism was similarly applied to the Labor member for Bass, with whom I also participated in a debate on a student campus. The honourable member for Bass, Silvia Smith, said in so many words before the budget that it would not happen because she did not think it would happen; the changes were not official; she did not know anything about them and therefore the students should not be worried. They knew what was going on; they knew what was proposed; they were ready for it; they were opposed to it; they wanted something done about it. But the emu mentality prevailed, and here we have the government proposing to increase the rate and decrease the threshold. I think it is very important that students read this debate and realise that they were conned before the election and they were conned after the election.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a speech I should have incorporated yesterday on the report of the Australian delegation to the 90th conference of the IPU. I mentioned this matter to Senator Faulkner earlier and he has no objection. I would like to incorporate the speech congratulating the staff in this place for the amount of work they did during the conference.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President

As one of the two permanent delegates from Australia who has recently participated in the 90th conference of the Interparliamentary Union held in Canberra, it is a pleasure to make some comment on what was a unique and historical conference from Australia's point of view.

It was historical for Australia because although it was the 90th conference of the I.P.U., it was the first time that it had ever been hosted in Australia. There is no doubt that this gave Australia an ideal opportunity to not only reinforce its leading position on the I.P.U., but also to give the delegates from some 95 countries the opportunity to see our national capital in all its splendour.

I must say it has made me very proud to hear comments that have been passed on to me by delegates since the conference praising not only the organisation of the conference, but praising Australia and Canberra in particular.

The conference as the report shows, concentrated on many areas, but it would be fair to say that the major topic was the unfortunate conflict that is occurring in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The former Yugoslav crisis was the major topic not only in the plenary sessions, but also at the committee meetings.

Resolutions pertaining to the external displacement of refugees in former Yugoslavia and other wars and civil wars were adopted and as the new delegate from Australia, I was astounded at the toing and froing and negotiating between countries to come up with agreeable forms of words.

But with the disasters that are occurring in this conflict it was no surprise that another resolution relating to respect for international humanitarian law and support for humanitarian action in armed conflicts was adopted by the conference. This motion was also as a result of the aforementioned conflict.

Another topic that received a fair amount of attention was a resolution concerning the health and wellbeing of the elderly. This was rather topical as we all know the health and wellbeing of the elderly is a matter of great concern within Australia.
There was a general debate on the political, economic and social situation in the world and I was pleased to have had the opportunity to speak on the importance of Antarctica.

The 90th conference saw the retirement of one of our permanent delegates, Mrs Kathy Sullivan and I must say this parliament owes her a great debt of gratitude for the tireless efforts she has put in on behalf of Australia at I.P.U. conferences over the years.

I was very proud of my colleague and the way she was received by her friends from many countries around the world and as an Australian politician, it was very gratifying to hear the glowing comments which were made about her efforts by other politicians from around the world.

It is also appropriate that I make comment on the excellent contribution of our other permanent delegate and executive member of the I.P.U., Mr Leo Macleay. There is no doubt that the efforts of Mr Macleay and Mrs Sullivan over the years have lifted Australia's profile in the I.P.U. organisation to a very high level.

It was unfortunate that during the conference the dozens of countries represented were mainly occupied with the rightful concerns of us all concerning the conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina. At the same time, little did we realise that a tragic conflict was also being played out in Angola.

I regret Mr President, that this matter was not discussed at the conference because there was a delegation there from Angola, but I believe the vast majority of delegates from all around the world would have wanted to make their concerns known about the tragic loss of life and destruction being caused by the internal conflict in Angola. It was only a few weeks after the conference that we in Australia learned of the tragic events that have been happening there. No doubt at the 91st conference being held in Paris in March next year, the Angolan situation will be discussed at length.

The report that is being presented today is a very good record of the conference and contains many of the major speeches that were made. I was very pleased to see the prominence at the conference of women parliamentarians and in fact, they have their own conference to discuss matters of concern to women.
Topics such as the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women and the international year of the family were discussed at some length.

In fact 67 women parliamentarians from 50 countries took part in a one day meeting of women parliamentarians and this was chaired by our representative, Mrs Kathy Sullivan. May I congratulate Mr. Geir Haarde from Iceland on his re-election as chairman of the twelve plus group. The Twelve Plus group plays a very important part as does the Asia Pacific group in regional matters.
Another significant speech was the report by the honourable Andrew Peacock M.P. on the I.P.U. mission to observe the recent elections in Cambodia.

Mr President, there is no doubt that the International Parliamentary Union plays a significant role in international affairs and one of the major side benefits from these conferences are the friendships and acquaintances one makes amongst countries from all around the world.

The conference in Canberra was attended by 415 parliamentarians from 95 countries representing many different religions and cultures and many different political views. Countries large and small were all represented and it was a magnificent spectacle to see all delegates seated in the Great Hall during the plenary sessions. I believe it was most unfortunate that the members of the press gallery only two floors above paid little or no attention to what was happening below them two floors down.

I have vivid memories of the delegate from Kuwait making a very strong speech about the invasion of their country by Iraq and whilst this was happening, the Iraqi delegate was pounding the table with his nameplate. It was shades of Kruschev in the United Nations in the 1960s.

The social events which were held in conjunction with the conference were exceptional and in particular, the gala concert held at the Canberra Entertainment Centre was of world standard. In fact I believe it will be televised around the entire nation on Australia Day.

In conclusion, may I once again congratulate all those hardworking staff members who worked so hard and made this conference such a successful one. Special thanks must go to the conference co-ordination unit that was so ably led by Ms Anne Hazleton and to all those other members of staff whether they be attendants, whether they be from Joint House, Sound and Vision, Department of the Library or wherever, they were a wonderful team and produced a memorable conference.

DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993OVERSEAS STUDENTS TUITION ASSURANCE LEVY BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill and the Overseas Students Tuition Assurance Levy Bill are the final education-related bills before the Senate this session. The levy bill is a brief one-page bill that is entirely contingent on and interrelated with the first.

PARA.TAB: These bills, which regulate education services for overseas students, follow a basic bill adopted a couple of years ago when, unfortunately, there was a collapse of a number of private colleges in Australia that were giving tuition to overseas students, mainly from China but also from other places. Because of discontinuities in expected enrolments and other matters very much related to that period, there was a collapse of colleges, which put Australia in a fairly bad light.

The debate about this whole matter has been whether the government's attempts to give regulation so that this would not happen again, so that this would not reflect upon Australia, are excessive or just right.In the earlier debate, the matter having been referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, some 29 substantial amendments were brought forward that moderated the degree of regulation the government was proposing. That is the case again. We have had one college in Western Australia collapse and, as a result, the government has brought forward this amendment bill, which will, in the government's mind, strengthen the regulations still further with regard to education services for overseas students, the registration of providers and the financial regulation of those colleges.

This whole matter has been, as on the earlier occasion, referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. The committee, which includes my colleagues Senator Tierney and Senator Bell, and the chairman, Senator Zakharov, from the government, has given the matter very careful consideration and consulted with the industry involved. I am moved considerably by the findings of the committee, which are unanimous. The import of the findings particularly struck me in the second to last paragraph on page nine, where the unanimous view of the committee is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee reserves its judgment on the matter until such time as a more definitive proposal is forthcoming.

This matter that is referred to by the committee, unanimously, is what is called the tuition assurance scheme. The concept is a good one. Where there is a failure of a college to provide completion of the delivery of a course to students, the other colleges that are part of the scheme will enrol the students and give them, as close as possible to the original course, a completion of the course for which they were originally enrolled. This is, therefore, tuition assurance, and the way in which this would operate would be called a tuition assurance scheme.

PARA.TAB: The point the Senate committee makes is that we have not any kind of description as to how this would work. We do not have any regulations that would be built upon the government's devising how this would work. The regulations will come after. The main bill that is before us has in clause 8, a substantial clause, the reference that to a tuition assurance scheme. The second bill is a levy bill to raise the moneys to make this provision for tuition assurance. I share the same doubts and the same anxieties as in the unanimous finding of the Senate committee. Accordingly, the opposition will be moving amendments. The amendments are in a form which is an alternative to opposing the levy bill and opposing clause 8 in the ESOS bill.

Those who first look at this, particularly those in the industry whom it directly concerns, say that the government has not got anything worked out on this matter. So the first reaction is to knock out clause 8 of the main bill and allow the other improvements to ESOS to stand and knock out the whole levy bill. The alternative to that is a little more sophisticated and, to us, convincing. It gives a way ahead to the government, to a degree. That is, we are saying that clause 8 and the whole levy bill will collapse if by June 1994—in six months time—a scheme has not been determined to the satisfaction of the Senate. If the regulations that describe tuition assurance are not to the satisfaction of the Senate, they will be disallowed by the Senate. The amendments I move on behalf of the opposition say that, if the regulations are disallowed, then clause 8 and the whole levy bill collapse automatically.

I wish to refer to those concerned members of the industry who have written to me. I seek leave to incorporate the 2 1/2-page letter I have received from Kathleen Newcombe, the Chairperson of the Australian Council for Private Education and Training.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Council for Private Education and Training
TO ALL AUSTRALIAN SENATORS
Re:Provisions of the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulations) Bill 1993
Overseas Students Tuition Assurance Levy Bill 1993
Dear Senator
We understand that the above Bills may be debated in the Senate during the early part of December.

Clause 8 of the Provisions of the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulations) Bill 1993 (ESOS Act) and the Overseas Student Tuition Assurance Levy Bill 1993 (TAS Bill) do not have any industry support and we write to seek your assistance to defeat clause 8 of the ESOS amendments and the TAS Bill on the following grounds:

1.The TAS Bill is not necessary. The proposed amendments to the ESOS Act, which (with the exception of clause 8) follow industry recommendation and have full industry support, coupled with effective monitoring by DEET, these changes are more than sufficient to ensure overseas students will not lose funds.

2.The TAS Bill lacks detail as to implementation and cost. It is proposed such detail will be provided in regulation form at some future time and the amount of any levy be delegated to a Board to determine. This is a matter of serious concern. We submit that imposition of levies of this kind, which is effectively a tax, should be dealt with by Act of Parliament and not by regulation.

3.The administrative complexity of a TAS. The consultants are yet to arrive at any position which the joint industry/DEET working group believe is practical. It is envisaged there may be a multiplicity of Tuition Assurance Schemes which will result in additional administrative complexity and cost. A number of Colleges have indicated they may be forced to refuse entry to overseas students due to the additional administrative burden.

4.The additional cost of a TAS will make Australian education uncompetitive. Any Tuition Assurance Scheme will be costly and additional costs will have to be passed on to students through fee increases. Overseas students have many alternative destinations in which to study and cost is one of the major factors. Australian education, which operates in a highly competitive international market place, will be less attractive to overseas students.
Conclusion

The only argument put forward by DEET to support this Bill is that "even with the strengthening of the ESOS Act, international students may still lose funds because a provider fails to put money into a trust account or wrongly takes it out".
The industry has proven over the past few years that they are more than capable of ensuring no overseas student is disadvantaged as a result of a College closure.

The Government's claim that they were forced to "bail out" students as a result of the closure of the ABC College in W.A. is not correct. Industry offered positions to all affected students but Government and the liquidator chose alternative action.

Virtually all College closures over the past few years have been as a direct of indirect result of the sudden change in Government policy in respect to Chinese students entering this country. We would all hope such a scenario will never be repeated.

Members of the Australian Council for Private Education and Training, the industry association to which my College subscribes, have agreed to run a placement scheme to ensure continuity of tuition for students should a College fail.

However, our Council strongly rejects the DEET stance that placement should be accompanied by extra travel expenses incurred by students, cost of new course development if necessary and reimbursement of other expenses.

The education export industry is generating a lot of export dollars for Australia and providing thousands of jobs for Australians. The industry cannot remain competitive if it is to absorb an additional Levy for a Tuition Assurance Scheme as well as the administrative cost implications of the proposed regulations to the Bill.
Yours sincerely
Kathleen Newcombe
Chairperson
ACPET

I have read this letter very carefully. I have spoken very happily with Kathleen Newcombe, who is representative of this whole industry. I agree with every paragraph of the letter I have just incorporated. I say that in a considered way because the principles set out represent exactly where the Liberal and National parties are and, I believe, where the unanimous finding of the senate committee is.

PARA.TAB: I should clarify just one element. This letter calls for clause 8 to be now opposed and for the levy bill to be now opposed. I should make that clear. I do not support that, for the reasons I have just outlined. I want to make it clear that I believe these contentious areas will collapse by June 1994. The reason I put is this, and I commend this to the government: I have had discussions with the industry on the basis of there being a voluntary tuition assurance arrangement whereby all of those who are registered under the act—all the colleges, in every part of Australia—have their own ethic, their own well thought out and written code, which is not requiring legislation at all, which is not requiring any kind of exchange of money by way of a levy, and which is honourably lived up to by the colleges in the industry. Should a college fail, the other colleges will enrol the students that are left high and dry and give those students the completion of the course, even if there is a marginal cost that falls upon the college that does it. Of course, where there are any recoverable moneys for the tuition at the original college, they would be paid to the college where the student went on to complete the course.

What we would gain is an industry-wide agreement of their own devising, and one devised to the satisfaction of those of us with an interest in this matter—even with this proposition being put to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I believe that this is a much better way ahead than to require legislation, as in clause 8 of the first bill before us and the levy in the second.

The Lorraine Martin College has written in exactly the same terms; Kathleen McKenzie, principal of the Cambridge Business College; Laurier Williams, principal of the Williams Business College; Mr Jim Fung, the principal instructor of the International Wing Chun Academy; and Mr Colin Weekley, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Sydney Missionary and Bible College are samples of the industry that concur with this approach.

I refer to the other part of our amendments relating to notified trust accounts. We do not believe that the provisions in proposed new section 6A, enacted by clause 2 of the ESOS bill, ought to proceed at this time. That is why we will be moving in No. 2 of our amendments that subclauses (2A), (2B) and (2C) be inserted in clause 2 to qualify the notified trust accounts. That also has a deadline with regard to June 1994.
I summarise for the opposition by saying that these are important matters. We wish to be entirely responsive to the industry and to the Senate committee report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I have copious notes which express the approach the Democrats have to the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulations) Bill and express support for some of the coalition amendments. As we are seeking to save time, I seek leave to incorporate my copious notes in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Overseas Students Tuition Assurance Levy Bill 1993
The Education Services for Overseas Students Amendment Bill 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills:
strengthen current protection of education services for overseas students by requiring private providers to

PARA.TAB: maintain trust accounts for student pre paid funds;

SPEECH.PARA: adhere to limits regarding the draw down from those trust accounts to ensure that if default occurs that there is enough money for refunds;
introduce more prescriptive refund provisions if the course is not provided or a student withdraws; and
start of an industry-led tuition assurance scheme to guarantee that international students receive the courses paid for if a provider defaults.
The Australian Democrats feel that Australia still has many lessons to learn in the area of export education.
We have never supported the exploitation of overseas students as "milking cows"—a term the National Liaison Committee has used—as an endless revenue source.
We have constantly raised questions about quality of overseas students courses, fee levels and the lack of bridging and orientation courses available.
We recognise the valuable benefits that overseas students bring to this country—not just financial benefits but the essential cultural exchange that takes place.

We accept that internationalisation of our education system involves more than overseas coming to our soils, and the benefits are wider than just education exchange—cultural benefits, et cetera, income from trade and intercourse.
In order to facilitate this exchange of cultures, knowledge, ideas and concepts it is important the rights of students and of institutions, including private and public providers, are protected.
Despite the fact that since federation we have been the recipients of overseas students it has taken a long time for us to recognise our obligations in this regard.

In 1986 the full cost fee recovery program in Australia was introduced and since then there has been rapid growth in this sector. To ensure that these overseas students receive the education that they paid for the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 was introduced.

This provides a legal basis for requirements for the registration of all courses offered to students from overseas and for requiring participating institutions to take steps to assure the financial security of fees.
We have also seen an Industry Commission Report into overseas students with some recommendations designed to assist overseas students, some of which were implemented last year.

I have followed the progress of this debate, having been involved since I was previously Education Spokesperson, and have played a role in a review into the operations of the effectiveness of the ESOS Act by the Department which was taken up by the Senate Standing Committee and took place last year.

The Australian Democrats have a fundamentally different philosophy towards education from that of the other parties. We are committed to an education system that is accessible and equitable for all Australians—we do not support fees and charges for domestic students and we have expressed reservations and indeed outright opposition at times to fee increases for overseas students fees when those fee increases have not been matched with quality assurance or control.

It is unfortunate that, despite a plethora of reports and submissions on the issue of education services for overseas students, from groups ranging from the Industry Commission to the National Liaison Committee for Overseas Students (NLC) and private providers in the sector, it has taken so long for some basic recommendations to be implemented.

I recall my earlier days on the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training when this issue was first raised. At that point many of the suggestions made then have only just been recognised as valid and reasonable ideas.

The Democrats will be supporting, with some amendments, the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill 1993 which seeks to strengthen the ESOS Act and the Overseas Student Tuition Assurance Levy Bill 1993.
We share concerns regarding the implementation of the Tuition Assurance Scheme, namely the role of regulations, the level of consultation that has taken place and the nature of those regulations.

The Australian Democrats have traditionally had problems with the concept of delegated legislation. The process by which legislation is moved by regulation is of concern to us as it is on the increase and once regulations are moved they can only be disallowed NOT amended and, even then, it takes careful scrutiny of the notice paper to ensure that the Government does not let them simply slip by.
In regard to the TAS Bill, we will be alert for the regulations and we believe the Opposition amendment rectifies this.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of explanation, I indicate that we will have the discussion in the committee stage and, because there is so much unanimity about the purpose of the ESOS bill, I think we could proceed rather rapidly in doing that.

—I would like to comment on the Overseas Students Tuition Assurance Levy Bill. I am pleased that at last some action is being taken to address the problems that came about earlier this year with the collapse of the college in Perth. Many people were seriously affected by that, and many of them came to me at the time to see what they could do about getting their money returned. It was a very dismal situation. People had come to Australia in good faith to be educated here, only to find that the whole thing collapsed around their ears. They were left very much out of pocket. Some of those people did not even have the money to return home. It took some time for the government to act in that matter and there was a lot of heartache for many months.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to note that Senator Teague has moved amendments on behalf of the opposition to tighten up the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill. This bill intends to strengthen further the protection of overseas students, their prepaid tuition fees and other fees that students are required to pay to undertake a course. I commend that to the people of Australia. It is particularly important that people are protected and that someone is answerable for what is going on. The government's intention with this bill is to safeguard Australia's international reputation in the area of education services for overseas students. While this action is commendable, I, like many others, have been greatly concerned by the activities in recent weeks of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who further aggravated our relationship with Malaysia.

It should be noted that some Malaysian students were affected earlier this year by the collapse of the college in Perth. The Prime Minister's activities in the last few weeks have certainly done our reputation a lot of damage. From what I have heard, the Prime Minister's comments, on top of the collapse, on top of the slowness with which the government acted at that time, have really worked against the interests of Australians trying to market effectively a very saleable commodity overseas. We are talking about the Australian Business College collapse that affected approximately 350 overseas students in Australia and 100 offshore students, who lost a combined total of about $2.2 million. The government, as I said, intervened on behalf of the students and provided financial assistance to those whose study had been interrupted. While that is commendable, there was certainly a great time delay before it actually happened.

The government has received advice that the overseas students tuition assurance levy could be seen as a new form of taxation. That is why it has been drafted as a separate bill, but the government maintains, I believe, that the providers must join a tuition assurance scheme to guarantee that international students receive the courses they have paid for if the provider defaults.

I do not wish to make any further comments on this other than to say that I hope this is the end of a very unfortunate saga that has been repeated a couple of times here in Australia. I hope we will now be able to build a reputation among those who wish to come and be educated in Australia that we are a reliable source of education and protection will be offered to people who do pay up-front fees. I hope they will ultimately be very happy not only with the tuition they get but also their time in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill and the Overseas Students Tuition Assurance Levy Bill. This matter is extremely important. In this country we have an industry that is booming; it is an industry that raises about a billion dollars a year for our economy. We are exporting a value-added service—educational provision—and it is something Australia is very good at and it should be encouraged. For this reason, the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training has taken a considerable interest in the matter and has had a watching brief on what is happening with regulation of overseas students for at least the three years I have been in this parliament.

PARA.TAB: Back in 1991, as a response to the collapse of certain colleges, the government tried to bring in draconian legislation. I will summarise very quickly what happened with that legislation. The Senate standing committee held a major inquiry; the government backed off, accepted about 30 amendments to the bill, and brought in a more deregulated system. I believe that system was, broadly, the correct way to go at that time. It has obviously created a number of problems in that there have been collapses, such as the one Senator Knowles referred to in Perth. It was fairly obvious that what was needed was a tightening up of the legislation in a number of ways.

The committee held a number of hearings and had a number of briefings from the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The outcome was that the need to tighten was really something that appropriately should have been done through a number of minor modifications. At the time, before we realised what the government was going to do with this so-called tuition assurance scheme, we thought that might be a good idea, but as time unfolded we realised the government was trying to create yet another bureaucratic monster and to solve a fairly minor problem with a major piece of legislation that was going to create problems for the industry.

The general view of the committee, particularly after hearing the evidence, was that just a minor tightening up at this stage would probably do the job. We need to strengthen and protect the act to protect overseas students. We need to make sure that the trust accounts of pre-paid funds are kept properly. We need to limit the draw-down conditions on trust accounts and we need, under this federal legislation, to extend the sunset clause beyond the start of next year to 1997, to give the states the opportunity to bring their legislation into place. We could roll back the federal legislation, which was always the intent of regulation in this industry. The government has agreed to that last provision. After hearing the evidence, most of us on the committee thought that really was all that was needed, and at this point in time that is probably all that should happen.

The government has put into the legislation, however, a tuition assurance scheme. Perhaps people on the committee and in the parliament would be more relaxed about this scheme and prepared to be convinced of its necessity if they knew what on earth it was about. I find it an extraordinary position that, on the very last day of this parliament, we are debating something called the tuition assurance scheme. We do not know what it is. Governments often do things by regulation, but this has really got to be the daddy of them all. We do not know what those regulations are and we do not even know what the principles of the bill really are.

We do not know how the government will set up and structure this scheme, how much people will have to put into this fund, what the effect will be on competitiveness in the industry as a result of the impost of this cost, and how diverse the scheme is. The government originally started with the idea of having a unified scheme but, as has become increasingly obvious, it needs a decentralised one.

So we are in the extraordinary position of having a piece of legislation, with no idea of what the government wants to do with it. Why has this happened? The government says, `We're waiting for a consultant's report'. Yet the people from DEET admitted to us in a hearing that the first consultant's report had some serious problems in it, and it became fairly obvious to us that this consultant, whoever he was, did not really have a full appreciation of all the issues involved. That does not give us a lot of confidence that, when he brings down his final report, it will be appropriate for the legislation that is to be put forward on this scheme.

As a matter of fact, the other evidence we heard in the hearing was that many areas of the industry were extremely unhappy about what is happening with this scheme. Despite DEET's claims that it consulted widely in the scheme and took the views of industry into account, that is not what we are hearing from people from ELICOS and the Australian Council of Private Education and Training, for example. They are very disturbed by the prospect of this tuition assurance scheme, and want to see a lot more detail.

It is strange the sorts of groups that the scheme hits. The government, when it set up this grand idea, obviously had no idea of some of the peculiar effects a tuition assurance scheme would have. For example, theological colleges get caught in this net. In the hearing, DEET people said, `Well, we'll consider whether different groups have exemptions, but it is not clear to us whether they will'. The theological colleges are affected because sometimes they train, as ministers, people from the islands. In colleges that have 200-odd students, often this will be only five or six students—but, because they have five or six students, they get caught in this government bureaucratic net. It is having an effect on an institution which, as one of them said, has been operating for 167 years and has never had any problem with student fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Longer than the government.

—It is longer than the government. Yet this bureaucratic government initially wants to catch such schemes in its net. The Ansett flying college at Tamworth is another group caught in this net, and our international competitiveness may be affected in aerospace.

PARA.TAB: The scheme is very poorly thought through; it is taking an enormous amount of time. There is not very much detail available to the parliament. Really, what the government should do at this point, if it has any sense, is tighten up the current act, as the industry wants and as the Senate standing committee has suggested, and leave this scheme in place until it has some idea of the principles of the act, how it is to be set up and run, what the regulations are, how it affects different groups and how much it will cost these industries. It is vital that this be done.

As I said at the start, we have a $1 billion industry. It is marginal in the sense that it is in a highly competitive business. Other countries are coming in and there is the possibility that they will take our markets. Even though we must assure funds for students, one of the big costs of doing so might be that our providers will become uncompetitive because there is this serious cost imposition on them.

For that reason we are suggesting a sunset clause for 30 June next year. The government really has to get its act together with the tuition assurance schemes. It has offered to bring the regulations forward in one bundle, but we really need to see the whole package.

I will be suggesting that the Senate standing committee have a very good look at this whole package when we get it. Although we support broadly the idea that there should be a tuition assurance scheme, we certainly do not want to buy a pig in a poke; we want to see what it is, what its impact is likely to be, and we will make a judgment on whether that is the appropriate way to go at that point.
The other thing the 30 June date will do for us is give us an opportunity to see how the strengthened act, which we support, works. That could be all that is needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the time, we should move straight to the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table supplementary explanatory memorandum to the government amendment to be moved to the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 2, page 2, after subclause (2) insert the following subclauses:
"(2A) Subject to subsections (2B) and (2C), section 6A of the Principal Act commences on the date on which regulations are made under that Act to provide for the operation of notified trust accounts.

"(2B) If regulations under the Principal Act to provide for the operation of notified trust accounts are disallowed by either House of the Parliament, section 6A of that Act is deemed to have been repealed on the date of the disallowance.
"(2C) If regulations under the Principal Act to provide for the operation of notified trust accounts are not made by 30 June 1994 section 6A of that Act is deemed to have been repealed on that date.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two concepts in the amendments that I have circulated on behalf of the opposition. I will move amendment No. 2 in two parts, and they can be put separately. Amendment No. 1 is entirely consequential on the first half of amendment No. 2. So by putting the first half of amendment No. 2—I do not think it will succeed—I will have no need to put amendment No. 1. We will put the second half of amendment No. 2 and it will get up. Then there is a government amendment which I think will be supported by everybody.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the two amendments, are we not, to the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill?

—Yes. I have put the first half of amendment No. 2, appearing only on the first page, separately from what is appearing on the second page. The amendment that I am moving first is listed in a circulated paper as amendment No. 2 and it relates to the first half of that printed amendment—that is, amendment No. 2, but only as referring to additional clauses (2A), (2B) and (2C). I do not believe there is a majority in the Senate to support that. If it is put now, it will test that proposition.

—To reinforce Senator Teague's belief, the Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. We are fully aware of which one is being put and we will not support it because it affects the trust accounts, which we believe it is very important to maintain the integrity of, as expressed in the legislation. To make it clear, Senator Teague is right in his belief that there will not be a majority. We do not support the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of that amendment not being passed, I will not move amendment No. 1 standing in my name. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 2, after subclause (2) insert the following subclauses:

PARA.TAB: "(2B)If regulations under the Principal Act to provide for the establishment of a tuition assurance scheme for the purposes of section 7A of that Act are disallowed by either House of the Parliament, section 7A of that Act is deemed to have been repealed on the date of the disallowance.

"(2C)If regulations under the Principal Act to provide for the establishment of a tuition assurance scheme for the purposes of section 7A of that Act are not made by 30 June 1994, section 7A of that Act is deemed to have been repealed on that date.".

SPEECH.PARA: I am confident there will be a majority for these three additions to the bill. This amendment relates to the tuition assurance scheme. They provide that these matters will collapse in the main bill if everything is not to the satisfaction of the Senate by 30 June 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague is correct, for good reason in this case, that there will be support from the Australian Democrats for these proposals. The track record of this move towards presenting amendments at this stage is a long and tortuous one.

PARA.TAB: As I mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage, which has been incorporated, the Democrats have had a longstanding tradition of being very wary of legislation by regulation. This series of amendments quite elegantly restores to the Senate some real authority over just what is being proposed. As Senator Tierney rightly said, it is quite perturbing to be asked in this place to endorse a legislative proposal which is as indefinite as the one we have before us without these amendments.

We support the amendments because they relate to the tuition assurance scheme. The amendments simply mean that reference to the relevant section of the act, 7A, is deemed to have been repealed if the regulations are not ready or if they are not sufficiently and properly addressing the problem in a way for which Senate approval is given. We think with that very substantial safeguard the bill will become much more supportable.

For all the many reasons Senator Tierney rightly mentioned in his contribution—I must acknowledge Senator Knowles's concerns also—we believe it is important that we assure that the tuition assurance scheme is properly promulgated, that it is not just assembled within the bowels of bureaucracy and it is here revealed for the Senate to properly scrutinise. With this amendment as proposed here we have the opportunity to properly scrutinise it. Therefore, the Democrats support this amendment.

PARA.TAB: The whole reason we want a sunset clause—and now this sunset clause is being retained in the legislation and put out to 1997—is that we are very cautious not to have government interference beyond reasonable limits in an industry which we would want to be successfully self-managing and also in an area where the states have a lot of responsibilities anyway. The reason to which my colleague Senator Knowles has referred, and the reason for the whole government proposal from the beginning, is that we are not happy that in these middle years of the 1990s we can just rely upon those other mechanisms. That is why we have the legislation before us, with the sunset clause to be in place until 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleague's remark in support of what the government is suggesting in this matter. It was a unanimous recommendation of the Senate standing committee that the sunset clause be extended. The basic reason is that it has always been thought that the states are the ones most appropriate to regulate in this area and that the only reason we have federal legislation is to put something in place to protect students until the states get their act together, which they are slowly doing.

PARA.TAB: When we originally moved a sunset clause back in 1991, it was for the start of 1994, which is next month. The states have not got their act together. The government at one stage did propose to remove the sunset clause totally. The committee felt that this was the wrong way to go, because what we really needed to do was to put some pressure on the states to get their act together, and that if we took the sunset clause away then that pressure would also go. TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think this matter should go by without the point being made that the Senate committee system is very important. This amendment is to give effect to recommendation No. 10 of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I commend the people on that committee, who have worked very hard. I am not on it, thank goodness. It helps people like me in my understanding of legislation such as this. I commend the committee. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While not wishing to prolong this process, I must acknowledge that Senator Tierney has indicated the very long path that this matter has taken through the committee. As a previous member of the committee—and now again—I have an appreciation of how difficult it has been to negotiate the right path on this whole matter. It is important to recognise that it became apparent only at the inquiry stage, when the committee was actually hearing evidence from affected parties, that the need for consultation in this area is great.

PARA.TAB: Both Senator Teague and Senator Tierney gave examples of what we believe could well have been unintended consequences of legislation in this area. Education providers of long standing in Australia were caught up with a provision designed to protect themselves against what can only be described as fly-by-night operators—recent arrivals—entering into an industry which was based on the idea of providing good education for people from overseas. These are people who come to Australia to take advantage of our education system and its tradition, history, values and competence, but who might be adversely affected by operators who want to operate for a short period of time, take some money and run. In an attempt to deal with that situation, it was revealed in our inquiry that the government's measure had an inadvertent effect on the well-established and the well-credentialled operators who were operating without problems or an adverse effect on their clients.

I support Senator Harradine's contention that it is important that we in this place recognise the value of the committee system because it is the committee system which revealed some of the inadequacies of the government's approach. It is also the committee system which revealed the unanimity of senators who, when acquainted with all the facts surrounding this issue, were ready to support the need for real scrutiny of what the department was translating from government intentions. With all that approval of the committee's role in this matter, we have to acknowledge that the government is trying to do this properly, and that the parliament is playing a very important role in helping the government to do that.

—I rise briefly at this final point of our consideration of the six education bills to say to the chamber, those who will read this Hansard and those in the gallery that what we have seen in the few hours last evening and in these few hours this morning is, in my view, the chamber at its best.

Finally, I commend the Senate committee process. We have seven standing committees of the parliament. One of them covers employment, education and training.
