DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993SOCIAL SECURITY (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURERS) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motions by Senator Faulkner:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 and Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. The Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) seeks to give effect to a number of changes announced in the 1993 budget.

PARA.TAB: It provides for a $3 a week increase in the newstart allowance from March 1994. This increase recognises the disadvantaged position of the long-term unemployed, whose numbers have risen so alarmingly under this government. As a result of a deal done by the government in order to have its budget passed, this increase will now apply also to recipients of the jobsearch allowance.

This bill also introduces a tighter income and assets test for family payment from 1 January 1994. The income ceiling for one child will be reduced by nearly $5,000 to $60,000 a year, and the additional income allowed for each extra child will also be reduced. The assets test limit will be reduced by nearly $60,000 to $550,000.

The reduction in the income ceiling will mean that 116,000 families will be excluded from basic family payments. Another 2,000 families will be excluded as a result of the tightening of the assets test. This is another example of Labor pulling a swiftie on an unsuspecting Australian public. Absolutely no mention was made prior to the last election of tightening the eligibility for basic family payments. No mention of it was made during the election campaign. However, members of the government were very willing to criticise the coalition for advocating a tightening of family payment eligibility. The opposition was up-front with the people of Australia. The government chose to deceive them and then bring the assets test in after the election like it did with so many other things that we have seen since. The Australian public had the wool pulled over their eyes prior to the election and then had their eyes opened afterwards to what this government is really like.

This bill also seeks to apply the family payment incomes and assets test to any additional income earned by student families where one parent receives a prescribed education scheme payment, usually in the form of an Australian postgraduate research award. The coalition recognises that families in which one parent receives a prescribed education scheme payment are currently in an advantageous position compared with other families. One must question the equity of allowing such families to be totally exempt from the relevant income and assets tests, regardless of the income of the spouse of a student parent.

According to the office of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), this provision will mean that families with a parent receiving a prescribed education scheme payment will still be relatively better off than other families because the prescribed education payment itself will remain exempt from the income and assets test. Hence, the coalition will not be totally opposing this provision. However, we are very concerned about its retrospective application to current students. The shadow minister, Mr Ruddock, stated in the House of Representatives:

SPEECH.PARA: People are now being told that the family payments, which were part of their award conditions because they were not tested against this, will no longer be payable to them.

Student parents have informed me that they have made a financial commitment based on a total income package. As a former postgraduate student on a scholarship, I am very aware of how one has to budget very closely, as one's income is not very great, and plan ahead for the period of one's whole scholarship period.

PARA.TAB: The package which the student parents have talked to me about includes the exemption from the income and assets test. They are concerned that the application of this provision mid-way through their PhDs may result in them discontinuing their studies. As I said, as a former postgraduate student, I realise just how close one can get to not continuing, based on financial decisions.

As my colleague the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) pointed out in the other place, the savings from this measure are meagre—less than $1 million a year. It would take very few postgraduate students to discontinue their studies to offset totally any savings that would be derived from the retrospective application of this provision. I inform the Senate that the coalition will move during the committee stage to remove the retrospective application of this provision to students who have received prescribed education scheme payments prior to 1 January 1994.

Finally, this bill gives legislative strength to the policy to limit family payment arrears to the date that a person seeks a review. It will also make it a requirement for family payment clients to notify a change in address and allow the suspension of payment if a client does not respond to a notice because he or she has failed to notify a change in address.

The Social Security (Budget and Another Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 is the main bill before the Senate. It seeks to implement a number of election promises as well as the vast majority of the government's social security budget initiatives. During the election, Labor promised to introduce a mature age allowance. This bill facilitates its introduction from 20 March 1994. Basically, it will be available to people aged 60 and over who have not reached pension age and who have been unemployed for 12 months or longer. Recipients will not have to satisfy the normal jobsearch allowance activity test. They will also be paid at the normal pension rates and be eligible for additional assistance by way of fringe benefits, the pensioner earnings credit scheme and the pensioner rebate.

While the coalition does not oppose this measure, it must be remembered that it has evolved from the massive unemployment problem in Australia. In effect, this measure is proof that the government, to a large extent, has given up on the older unemployed. It is tragic that the skills and experience of thousands of older Australians are being wasted. Most of the 37,000 people who are to receive the mature age allowance are fit, active and willing to work. The last thing they want is to be literally pensioned off five years early.

The bill also facilitates the election promise to introduce an earnings credit of $500 per year for recipients of the maximum rate of jobsearch allowance, newstart allowance and sickness allowance. This credit is similar to the $1,000 earnings credit that applies to age pensioners. While ACOSS, the Welfare Rights Unit and the Australian Democrats have expressed concern about the adequacy of the earnings credit and the fact that it cannot be transferred between partners, the coalition will not oppose it or seek to amend its proposed form.

A number of budget measures to improve the administration of jobsearch and newstart allowances are included in this bill. Two of the more important enhancements in this bill are the discretion to require a jobsearch allowee to enter into a jobsearch activity agreement and the discretion to require a jobsearch or newstart allowee to apply for an advertised vacancy. Again, the coalition will not oppose either of these measures.

While we recognise that the vast majority of allowees are genuinely unemployed, there continues to be anecdotal evidence of a lack of interest in filling some job vacancies. Again, it must be pointed out that the tightening of activity testing compliance measures was roundly criticised by the Labor government when they were originally included in Fightback. The coalition is well within its rights to oppose all of these measures, given that Labor gave absolutely no indication during the campaign that it would, in its first budget after the election, move to tighten these criteria. This is yet another of the countless examples of this disgraceful, deceitful and underhand government deliberately misleading the electorate. It is my hope that the department will administer these compliance measures with the necessary amount of commonsense. People should not be required to apply repeatedly for the same job nor should they be required to apply for jobs for which they are obviously totally unqualified.

This bill also requires people who are entitled to welfare payments from foreign countries which have signed social security agreements with Australia to take reasonable steps to obtain these payments from these countries. This is another initiative that was kept from the Australian public before the last election. There is a significant difference between the amount Australia provides in welfare payments to people residing overseas and the amount received from other countries for people residing in Australia. In time, this initiative will make up a significant proportion of this shortfall, and it is supported by the coalition.

On 1 January 1994, an education entry payment will commence for newstart allowees and jobsearch allowees who are aged under 18 and have been unemployed for 12 months. This one-off $200 payment will benefit 6,000 clients a year. The option of full-time education is becoming increasingly more popular, particularly amongst the younger unemployed, as people come to the conclusion that it is preferable to become better educated than to waste away on the dole. The coalition supports this measure.

This bill will also remove the rent assistance waiting period for homeless people aged under 18. The coalition supports this initiative, which has been advocated by youth workers for many years. It will provide much-needed assistance to one of our society's most vulnerable groups; namely, genuinely homeless young people, some 10,000 of whom will be assisted annually.

Significant concerns have been expressed in relation to the changes to the treatment of lump sum compensation payments that are also contained in this bill. At present, one half of a lump sum payment that contains an economic loss component is deemed to be an income related payment for the calculation of a benefit preclusion period. However, no part of a lump sum payment that does not include an economic loss component can be taken into account when calculating a preclusion period. The department contends that this has resulted in circumvention of the social security preclusion provisions by minimising or exorcising economic loss components.

The changes in this bill would result in one half of all lump sum payments being deemed to be economic loss for the purpose of calculating preclusion periods, regardless of whether the lump sum payment actually contains an economic loss component. A new all persons average weekly earnings divisor, which will replace the current male average weekly earnings divisor, will have the effect of lengthening benefit preclusion periods. The requirement that reasonable steps be taken to obtain compensation will be extended to the partners of injured individuals.

Finally, the exemption from lump sum payment provisions, personal sickness and accident insurance policies will be eradicated. Again, none of these savings measures were pre-empted by the Labor government prior to the election. Concerns have been expressed by solicitors, insurers and welfare advocates. It has been argued that these changes will mean that payments for pain and suffering or medical costs will be unfairly assessed as economic loss. It has also been argued that this change will mean that lump sum compensation payments will be more harshly treated than legacies and winnings from gambling. A number of concerns have also been expressed about the possible interaction between these measures and various state government schemes, particularly in relation to the specific exclusion of economic loss from lump sum payment.

A number of possible alternatives to the 50 per cent rule were put forward during the two recent Senate inquiries. These include: exempting smaller lump payments of up to $20,000 and exempting lump sum payments in which the recipient is able to prove that no economic loss component exists—in effect, a reversal of the onus of proof. The coalition is not totally convinced by any of the alternatives that have been put forward. We consider that they may be administratively cumbersome and not necessarily any more equitable than the proposal in the bill. However, the coalition remains concerned that deeming that 50 per cent of all lump sum payments for economic loss, even if a payment does not include an economic loss component, is fundamentally unfair if a person demonstrably has not suffered any economic loss. For example, if a long-term disability support pensioner receives a lump sum compensation payment, why should he or she face an extended pension preclusion period because of the 50 per cent deemed economic loss when it is manifest that no such economic loss has occurred or could even have occurred?

The shadow minister, Mr Ruddock, has asked the minister whether it would be possible to extend special circumstance provisions to exclude cases in which it is manifest that no economic loss has or could have occurred. Unfortunately, the minister has not been able to provide any amendment to protect people in such a position. As a result, the coalition will move in the committee stage to oppose those provisions in the bill that deem 50 per cent of all lump sum components to be for economic loss.

As well as making a number of relatively minor changes to the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990, this bill seeks to remove the sunset clause in the act, the effect of which will be to permit the data-matching program to continue indefinitely beyond 22 January 1994. The coalition remains very concerned that the financial savings that have emanated from this highly intrusive method of fraud control have never even looked like approaching those estimated by the government in 1990 and used as its rationale for passing this legislation. At that time, it was contended that the data-matching program would be a central element of the department's fraud control program and would realise savings of $300 million a year. It has now been revealed that the data-matching savings have peaked at $70 million a year. Even this figure is very deceiving. Some $40 million of the $70 million is derived by simply asking for tax file numbers without having to do any actual data-matching whatsoever.

The Auditor-General's recent report on the data-matching program raises significant doubts about the cost effectiveness of this program. The program entails significant financial costs, both in the computerised infrastructure and recurrent administration. It also involves a significant extension of the use of tax file numbers—after assurances from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) when tax file numbers were introduced that no such extension would occur. However, in terms of benefit, it entails a small fraction of the total reviews conducted by the department and an equally small fraction of the number of cancellations, downward variations and overpayments.

Only about 64,000, or 2.7 per cent, of the department's 2.3 million annual reviews are undertaken under the data-matching program. Only 3.5 per cent of calculations, 3.7 per cent of downward variations and 7.8 per cent of overpayments are identified by the data-matching program. However, millions of totally innocent clients have their personal and financial information computer randomly matched on a regular basis across up to five government agencies in order to enable this program to be carried out.

The coalition is not totally convinced that the data-matching program is cost effective, particularly as the government is now indicating that savings from it will now gradually fall away. We believe that the sunset clause should continue to apply to this intrusive program and that the current annual parliamentary reporting requirement should also be maintained. We will move during the committee stage to facilitate these amendments.

Finally, the bill contains provisions which seek to transfer 16-year-old recipients of Austudy to family allowance. Again, this savings measure was not foreshadowed during the election campaign but has been foisted on an unsuspecting Australian public by this underhand government. If passed, this change would mean that some 75 per cent of affected individuals would be worse off. Thankfully, it appears that the government does not have the numbers in the Senate and this proposal will not go ahead. My colleague Senator Tierney will expand on the coalition's criticism of this part of the bill. In relation to the Social Security (Budget and other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993, I move:
At end of motion, add: ", but the Senate:
(a)is critical of the Government for its failure to take the Australian people into its confidence and inform them in advance of its proposals to reduce expenditure, involving in particular:
(i)the enhancement of compliance and review activity; and

TAB.TAB: (ii)the deeming of all lump sum compensation payments to include a 50% economic loss component; and

PARA.TAB: (iii)the implementation of a new statutory divisor which will exclude claimants from eligibility to benefits for longer periods of time; and
(iv)the disqualification of 16 year old students from AUSTUDY; and

TAB.TAB: (v)more rigorous income and assets testing of Family Payment; and

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the Government for its failure to validate statutory notices when technical deficiencies were first identified in the courts, thereby putting at possible risk the Government's entitlement to claim $250 million of accumulated social security debt and requiring retrospective legislation with effect from 1 January 1988 to protect the revenue".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to extend the remarks made by Senator Patterson, particularly with regard to the transfer of 16-year-olds to the family payments system. I believe that this particular part of the legislation impacts very severely on country families. This measure lowers the assets test radically for such families. At a time when country people are undergoing intense social and economic disruption to their lives, many families will have to face agonising choices over the level of education that their children will be able to achieve. To remove 16-year-olds from Austudy to the family payments system is neither just nor equitable.

PARA.TAB: Austudy contained a recognition of the asset rich, cash poor status of farming families in taking into account only 50 per cent of the assets of a business or farm in which the owner is substantially engaged, so doubling the standard assets test limit. This makes for a differential of $385,200. Although farmers can apply for additional family payment under the hardship provision, this is extremely onerous. Assets held can be no more than $550,000 and income must be below $13,900 and $624 per child.

The Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training have asserted that only 10 to 20 rural families would be affected by this measure. Since then, the office of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) has informed us that the figure is 26 families. This appears to be based on an estimation of those rural families which will have a 16-year-old student and whose assets will fall between the additional family payment and Austudy thresholds. Even if this were correct, it does not take into account the number of rural families which will still receive income assistance but be worse off.

The problem is to estimate the extent of disadvantage that will be suffered by the 75 per cent that the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training have estimated will be worse off as a result of this measure. It was admitted in the inquiry that this figure was unknown. The departments concerned showed a tendency to cite best case scenarios at the hearing, while being unable to produce figures as to the average effects of the change. This supports our conclusion that the government has embarked on a blind cost cutting exercise without real knowledge as to the effects of the razor.

The government has taken insufficient cognisance of the way in which this bill impacts on rural families. The argument that the Austudy living away from home rate has not changed does not answer our concerns, because the evidence is that more and more rural families are unable to send their children away to board, with the result that children are now travelling long distances daily to school. This measure may well have an adverse impact on these children with its lowering of thresholds for income and assets.

In recent years the retention rate for post-compulsory schooling has skyrocketed. The chief reason for this is the inability of young people to find employment. This is particularly so in country areas, where rates of youth unemployment are as high as 30 to 40 per cent. This legislation will then lead to the situation where parents are morally compelled to keep their children in post-compulsory education to give them some chance of employment in the future but, in doing so, they will be penalised financially.

Austudy recognises that education produces benefits for the nation as well as for the individual. It also recognises the high cost of education on top of living expenses in its significantly higher assets and incomes threshold. However, rather than Austudy being a means of ensuring the further education of many country children, it is being used as a means of scraping together savings to reduce the deficit. This legislation means that fewer and fewer low to average income earners in rural areas will be eligible to receive help with their children's education.
The National Farmers Federation, in its submission to the Senate hearing on this legislation, stated that the changes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . exacerbated the difficulties and inequities the assets test imposes on rural students trying to acquire an education.

Farm families are finding it increasingly difficult to finance the education of their children at a time when farm incomes are expected to drop 13 per cent in 1993-94 due to uncertain international markets, droughts and low wool prices. The departments concerned conceded during the course of the hearing that they did not have any data on problems in individual states and did not always appear to be clear about the impact the measure would have on families.

PARA.TAB: The government believes that it has sufficiently taken rural families into account by not changing the Austudy system for those boarding away from home. However, anecdotal evidence suggests that more and more students are living at home, as I mentioned previously, and travelling long distances daily to school because their parents cannot afford to have them board. The government has said that only 26 farming families will be adversely affected by this measure. But this is extremely deceptive and does not include those rural families which will get reduced assistance because of this measure.

At a time when Australia needs to promote the skilling of the nation, which is the prerequisite for social harmony and economic performance, this measure deserves to be opposed in the name of the families whose aim is to educate their children as highly as possible to try to ensure their place in the future economic development of our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 and the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. The first provision of the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) is to increase by $3 a week the rate of the newstart allowance paid to singles over 21 years of age. As one can imagine, the Australian Democrats welcome this increase. I am sure the nearly half a million long-term unemployed people who are recipients of the newstart allowance will also welcome it. Unfortunately, the small increase that is to be paid will be accompanied by a number of far tighter compliance measures reportedly designed to knock off about 20,000 people from the newstart allowance.

PARA.TAB: The other provision contained in this bill that I want to comment on is the reduction to be made, as of 1 January 1994, in the means test applicable to the basic family payment. Some 118,000 families are to lose their entitlement to family payments through the tighter income and assets tests that this legislation seeks to implement. The Democrats are opposed to these reductions.

As we should all be aware, the basic family payment is not intended as a welfare payment but rather is paid in recognition of the value of children to society and the costs incurred in their upbringing. Indeed, I think many senators in this place will admit, at least in terms of rhetoric anyway, that children and families are the most important and valuable resource we have. I pay tribute to the work over many years of Senator Harradine, who has pointed out to the Senate on numerous occasions that family payments can be seen as something of a tax equity measure which provides some compensation for the fact that a family raising children pays more taxes through excises, wholesale sales tax and the like. The opposition and the government should be condemned for combining to pass this reduction. For those 118,000 families to be affected, it is not much of a welcome to the International Year of the Family.

I turn now to the other bill before us, the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. I should point out that this bill is more than 160 pages in length with 55 pages of schedules and an index that runs to 10 pages. It contains several relatively complex provisions. Given the difficulty the opposition claims it was having with the size and complexity of the Native Title Bill, I can only hope that it has had adequate time to consider this legislation.

I would also be interested to know just how much consultation was undertaken with those hundreds of thousands of people whose incomes and lifestyles will be affected by this bill. I doubt if more than one per cent of these people are aware that this bill we are debating today even exists, let alone what its contents are and what its impacts will be. It seems that for some in this place only those bills which attract media interest warrant widespread public consultation.

Turning to the specific provisions of the bill, there are a number of measures which we see as being positive steps and which we support. Amongst these are the introduction of the $200 education entry payment for the long-term unemployed; the abolition of the 18-week waiting period for rent assistance imposed on our under 18s claiming jobsearch or sickness allowance; the introduction of the mature age allowance for older unemployed people; the introduction of an earnings credit scheme able to be accessed by the unemployed in order to offset income against their benefit income test; and, finally, some of the measures designed to enhance the effectiveness of the newstart allowance.

We are very much in support of these measures. However, we believe that the way in which the mature age allowance and the earnings credit schemes are being proposed is so restrictive that it may in fact defeat their intended purpose.

I look first at the mature age allowance. Under the proposed scheme, an unemployed person who is aged 60 or over but who is still below the age pension age and who has been registered with the CES for 12 months or more will qualify for a mature age allowance. The allowance will be paid at a rate equal to that of the age pension and no jobsearch effort will be required of the recipients. Under the scheme as proposed in this legislation, a mature age allowance recipient will be able to undertake work for periods of up to 13 weeks and then return automatically to the allowance.

That is all well and good. If they should work longer than the 13 weeks, however, they will be required to serve yet another 12 months on income support before requalifying for the mature age allowance. The Democrats believe that this 13-week limit is far too restrictive and may indeed have the effect of dissuading allowance recipients from taking work which may be offered to them. Surely that is not the government's intention, even if it does become the effect of this restriction. I will be moving an amendment at the committee stage to remove the restriction.

I turn now to the earnings credit scheme, which is also to be introduced in March next year. Under the scheme, jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowance recipients will be able to build up a credit of up to $500 which can be used to offset income gained from employment from their allowance income tests. I should stress, however, that the credit can only be used once a year and that it will not be able to be accessed in a fortnight when the level of a recipient's earnings would preclude that person from an income support payment. The Democrats certainly support the intention of the scheme; it is these sorts of flexible arrangements that we need to be putting in place for unemployed people.

The scheme proposed for the unemployed is modelled on that which is currently available to age pensioners, although the amount and conditions of the scheme for the unemployed as outlined in this legislation are not nearly as generous or as flexible as those applying to the pensioner scheme. In the form proposed, many people would be able to undertake only a couple of days work before the restrictive conditions proposed for the scheme would preclude them from it. To take up work opportunities and to get a foot in the door to potential full-time work, the unemployed must be able to work for at least a week. No employer is going to say, `Look, I'd like to try you out. Why don't you come in for 3 1/2 days a week?'. It is a silly proposition.

As with the mature age allowance, if we impose conditions under which people may re-enter the work force which are too restrictive, then people are simply not going to take up these opportunities. I will be moving amendments which seek to address this.

That brings me to the measures contained in this bill to which the Democrats are opposed. The first is the changes to be made to the compliance testing of newstart recipients. Apparently, there has been a suspicion within the government and the department that the Commonwealth Employment Service has not been tough enough in its screening efforts of newstart recipients to find work. The government's response as proposed in this legislation will be to allow the Department of Social Security to `work test' newstart recipients.

Further, the department will be given the power to require newstart recipients to apply for a certain number of advertised vacancies and to obtain employer contract certificates from employers verifying that they have in fact applied for the vacancy. As a result of these tougher compliance arrangements, it has been reported that the government intends to throw some 20,000 people off the newstart allowance in order to save about $10 million a year.

With the job market in its current state, the Democrats believe the tightening of work test arrangements to be incredibly unreasonable. Regrettably, the changes play on that old myth that there are jobs out there, people just need to look harder, and the government's job is to make them look harder. The Democrats are disappointed to see these changes being put up, and we will be opposing them.

The next measure contained in this bill, to which the Democrats are staunchly opposed, is the change to the way the Department of Social Security is to treat lump sum compensation payments. The situation as it stands at the moment is that the department need only be satisfied that some component of a compensation payment is an economic loss component for it to take 50 per cent of the total lump sum into account for social security income testing purposes.

It is clear from this formula—and the department acknowledges this—that the current system disadvantages some compensation recipients. No doubt the department would argue that it is only a small minority of people receiving a compensation payment who are currently disadvantaged and that the administrative benefits from the application of this rule justify this. Of course, it is of little compensation to these people to know that they are in the minority and that they are saving the Department of Social Security some paperwork.

Amendments contained in the bill before us will exacerbate this situation by removing the requirement of the department to show that there is some economic loss component within a compensation payment. The effect of the amendments will be to apply recovery and preclusion provisions to all lump sum compensation payments, regardless of whether or not there is any component for economic loss. The Democrats are opposed to this change and will be moving amendments to remove the relevant clauses from the bill.

I think it was obvious to all senators present at the hearing of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—certainly to Senator Ellison and me; and, I think, even to the government senators—that this change was inequitable. I hope those senators have conveyed that message to their party rooms and will support our amendment to delete this provision.

I now turn, finally and very briefly, to the issue of data-matching and the sunset clause which the government is seeking to have repealed in this bill. It is history that the Democrats opposed the introduction of the data-matching program. We opposed it primarily on two grounds. The first one was that the savings which it was claimed would be achieved through the program were pie in the sky figures. In fact, they were off the planet and would never have been realised.

Our second reason for opposing the program was that it presented major privacy concerns. Of course, both of these concerns have subsequently proven valid. I note that it is the opposition's intention to move an amendment to extend the sunset clause applying to the data-matching program for a further two years. The Democrats support this move. I will say more about that in the committee stage.

In conclusion, it seems to me that the very title of this bill, the `budget and other measures bill', reveals its nature: it was framed entirely within the parameter of saving money. It also seems to me that social security expenditure has been cut to the bone in terms of targeting and that the department, in order to find the required savings, has had to resort to some highly inappropriate measures. While not denying—and in fact affirming—the positive aspects of this bill, it has to be pointed out that the savings measures contained in the bill come from slugging those who have been unemployed for more than 12 months, or those who have been seriously injured at work or in a car accident. I also indicate to the Senate that I seek to amend Senator Patterson's second reading amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of amendment, add:

PARA.TAB: "; and (c)condemns the coalition for voting for the majority of these initiatives.".

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to speak at any length. The issues that speakers from both the Australian Democrats and the coalition have criticised in the second reading debate were largely dealt with in the second reading speech. We will be addressing in committee the matters that they intend to address via amendment. In view of the time constraints, I propose that we go into committee immediately.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—It appears that Senator Woodley's amendment has not been circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will oppose Senator Woodley's amendment. It would have been polite of the Democrats to have circulated this amendment in the chamber, rather than just move it at this stage.

Amendment (Senator Patterson's) negatived.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that consideration of clause 2 be postponed until after consideration of clause 12, as the Australian Democrats have some amendments to later clauses which may affect clause 2.

PARA.TAB: Consideration postponed.
Clause 3.
Amendment (by Senator Sherry) proposed:
Clause 3, page 2, proposed point 1068-B3, line 8, insert "3, 4," after "items".

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not oppose this request for an amendment, which will provide much needed financial assistance to hundreds of thousands of Australians and their families on lower incomes. However, I do not think I should at this time reiterate the circumstances which resulted in this request.

PARA.TAB: Originally, this $6 per fortnight increase was to apply only to people on the newstart allowance. The government sold its original initiative on the basis that it acknowledged that the relative position of this group—that is, people on the newstart allowance—has fallen compared with other income support recipients. In a desperate attempt to get its budget through and impose higher taxes on all Australians, which Australians were not told about before the last election, the government concocted a deal with the Greens that cost long-suffering taxpayers a further $140 million. This is part of that deal.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed.
Clauses 4 to 6—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition has an amendment after clause 6, which is the same as the amendment standing in the name of the Democrats. The coalition will withdraw its amendment and support that to be moved by the Democrats. This amendment will eliminate an unfair retrospective element from this provision. In saying that we will support the Democrats' amendment, let me put on the record that both the shadow minister for social security, Mr Ruddock, and the honourable member for Fisher, Mr Slipper, expressed their concerns about the retrospective element of this provision when the bill was being debated in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: The coalition does not oppose the provision overall. It will mean greater equity between student families that receive prescribed education scheme payments and other families. However, we recognise that student families have made financial plans taking this benefit into account and in some cases, as I said in the second reading debate, it may jeopardise their studies if this benefit were taken away from them in the middle of their courses.

The financial savings from this initiative are minuscule—some $0.4 million this financial year and $0.8 million next financial year. If some students withdrew from their courses there would be a cost involved in that anyway. Removing the retrospective element has an even smaller impact on savings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 6, page 3, insert the following clause at the end of Part 3:

SPEECH.PARA: "6A. Schedule 1A of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Transitional saving for existing student parents

SPEECH.PARA: `69. The amendments to this Act made by section 5 of the Social Security Amendment Act (No. 2) 1993, do not apply to a person who, prior to 1 January 1994, was eligible to receive payments in respect of the Post-Graduate Awards Scheme, until the person loses such eligibility by operation of this Act other than as it is amended by section 5.'.".

The amendment is self-explanatory. I acknowledge Senator Patterson's description of the effect of this amendment, which is exactly as she has described it. It is also exactly as has been described by the coalition members who showed their concern in the other place.

PARA.TAB: The retrospective effect could also be described as completely lacking in fairness. What is taking place under the government's proposal is that people who have made plans—and these are plans that affect not only individuals but their families as well—to embark upon a course of study on the basis of the rules as they existed, which is what sensible people do, now find that the government has changed the rules without warning. This has left such people with no real choice. The choice is to compromise the plans they have made in relation to the balance of income, time, expenditure and arrangements. These alterations have been brought about not by the individuals themselves but by the government. Many people cannot choose to stick in there and put up with the extra expense and inconvenience that this government decision has caused.

Those who have spoken to people affected by this change would know that usually these plans for extra study involve a great deal of negotiation within families in terms of the priorities and the sacrifices that will be made to achieve the study. This very fine balance will be disturbed by a government decision which, as Senator Patterson rightly said, will have a minuscule effect on the budget. To have one's plans disturbed by such a minuscule requirement is blatantly unfair. We roundly welcome the support and similar intent that the coalition has foreshadowed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we go any further, I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government's request and amendments to be moved to these bills. We are opposed to the amendment moved by the Democrats and supported by the opposition. We do not believe that the alleged retrospective element that has been outlined is as serious as is being made out in this debate. I will not speak further, given the likely outcome.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clauses 7 to 12—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill proposes that the means testing applicable to the basic family payment be tightened up. Very briefly, the income limit on the basic family payment for families with one child is to be reduced from $64,938 to $60,000. The additional amount of income allowed for additional children is to go from $3,249 to $3,000. Finally, the assets limit is to drop from $607,250 to $550,000.

PARA.TAB: While the reduction in the income test levels may not sound too significant, I note that the government estimates that some 116,000 families will lose their entitlement to the basic family payment, saving the government about $62.4 million this year and $124.9 million in a full year thereafter. That means that 116,000 families will lose their basic family payment from the tighter income limits alone. On top of these 116,000 families, a further 2,000 will lose their entitlement through the tighter assets limit, yielding savings of $600,000 this year and $2 million per year thereafter.

The Australian Democrats are opposed to these reductions in the income and assets testing levels on the basic family payment. As I said in the second reading debate, this payment is not intended as a welfare payment; rather it is paid in recognition of the value of children to society and the costs incurred in their upbringing. It acts as a tax equity measure, compensating for the additional taxes that a family raising children pays.

My colleague Senator Herron—and I am happy to describe him in that way—has spoken often about the plight of families, and it is a very sincere concern of his. Yet in this instance I assume he will vote with the opposition and the government to pass this measure. That is a very curious thing for me. Even at this late stage, I appeal to him, given his very fundamental commitment to families.

I believe the opposition and government should be condemned for this reduction. Time and again the opposition has tried to paint a picture of the Democrats and the government colluding to pass various pieces of legislation. Here we see the opposition coming into the International Year of the Family and voting with the government to deny a basic payment to 118,000 families. We are opposed to this tightening of the basic family payment means test and we will vote against these clauses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition advocated a reduced income threshold for eligibility for family payment prior to the election in the interest of targeting family payment to lower income earners. However, we advocated a 100 per cent increase in family payment for low income families and a 50 per cent increase for middle income families.

PARA.TAB: The coalition would have every right to support these amendments of the Australian Democrats because the government again gave absolutely no indication prior to the election that it would introduce more rigorous income and asset testing for family payment. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, the government criticised us because we actually told the Australian public the truth before the election. On the contrary, Labor members and candidates went around the countryside campaigning and saying that the coalition was reducing the upper income threshold for family payment. While the government is condemned for not being truthful to the Australian community, the coalition recognises the need to target finite financial resources to those in greatest need. We will therefore not be supporting the Democrats' amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the stance taken by Senator Woodley. Anybody who has heard me speak on this matter surely would not be surprised at my saying this. Anybody who has seen over the years what has happened to the family allowances would not be surprised by the consistent attitude that I have taken about this matter. We must think about what family allowances are. If we think back to 1976, we will see what family allowances really are. In 1976, the then government abolished—
—Child endowment.

—No, it abolished tax rebates for children and child endowment—it abolished both. It abolished the tax rebate for children and cashed it up into a family allowance to be paid to the carer. I agreed with that. In fact, some six years before that, when I was on the ACTU executive, the then President of the ACTU, Albert Monk, made a recommendation that the money should go into the hands of the principal carer instead of being spent in a hotel or something like that because, ultimately, it was the taxpayer who was getting the benefit and not necessarily the carer. That was the situation.

PARA.TAB: So what really happened was that it was out of the hip pocket into the purse. I remember it well—it was out of my hip pocket into the purse. It cost the government absolutely nothing. On that occasion, I well recall saying to the then government, `Well, I hope you are not going to make this sum dwindle away'. I remember Senator Grimes standing up in this chamber in the old Parliament House and saying exactly the same thing: that family allowances are not welfare payments; they are part of the tax transfer system. That is what he said; that was Labor Party policy.

What has happened since then? Remember, it was out of the taxpayers' pocket into the purse. Since then, successive governments have had their hands into that purse, pilfering the money from the purse of the carer who, generally speaking, was the mother, and the government is going to pilfer again now. I have worked out that over $8 billion was pilfered from the purses of mothers. This was done by two means: firstly, when the family allowances were not indexed—as indeed were the tax rebates—and, secondly, as a result of means testing, thresholds and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!
—Yes, it is a shame. Here we have another attempt to exacerbate this situation, to pinch a few more bucks from the purses of the mothers of this country. That is what this government is doing.
—At Christmas.

—As Senator Herron said, at Christmas time. That is what the government is doing. It did not say that it would do it before the election, but it is doing it now. It should contrast what it is doing on this particular measure with what it did yesterday with the child-care rebate. There is no means test on that. There is no means test on dual income families, many of whom live in this capital city. They can put their children into care and there is no means test on their rebate. I will give the committee an example. I cannot remember the amount that is suggested; it might be $55,000 or something like that.
—That is the asset limit.

—It is $60,000. I give the example of a two-income family in Canberra, two well-paid senior public servants on, say, $50,000 a year each—$100,000. They put their kids into child care. They are not subject to means testing at all. On the other hand, a one income family on $60,000 with children is means tested.

PARA.TAB: It was not the government's money in the first place. It was the taxpayers' money in the first place. The government is pinching it out of the family purse. It is going right against every single principle upon which this particular payment was based. If it is talking about targeting, then it should target properly. But that is a welfare measure. We have to have a really good look at this at some stage. I congratulate Senator Woodley on taking this stand at this time. I hope his amendment will be carried.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the opposition and the government on this occasion are supporting the government's measure. To reiterate, this will change the ceiling from $64,938 to $60,000 a year. The existing assets value limit for basic family payments will be reduced from $607,000 to $550,000.

PARA.TAB: I was not surprised at Senator Harradine's contribution, nor at Senator Woodley's contribution. I appreciate their views and the philosophical position they have. But this government does not agree with them on this particular issue. We have taken a view that these sorts of payments should be targeted much more directly to those families most in need. For those reasons, I have to reject the comments made by Senator Woodley and Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just give a personal example. The government could not care less as to how many dependants there are on a particular income. I will give the committee an example just off the top of my head of a widow with six children marrying a widower with seven children. I will ask you, Mr Chairman, and the committee to consider what this intact family saves the Commonwealth government per annum. I will tell you one day, but I would suggest that the government have a look at what this family saves the Commonwealth in respect of family allowances, in respect of Austudy forgone and in respect of widow's pension forgone. In the light of those figures, the government might have a think about what it is doing to other families. What the government is doing to families is simply a horrible injustice.

PARA.TAB: The government is overturning the principle upon which family allowances were based. At the time, former Senator Grimes, the Labor party's shadow minister, assured the parliament—and when he became minister he continued to assure the parliament—that, so far as his party was concerned, this was a tax transfer measure; it was not a welfare measure. If the government is targeting, it should do so in the welfare net area, not in the tax transfer area. I will not say anything more, but I do appeal to the coalition to think about this in terms of the principles. I will support Senator Woodley and his colleagues in voting against these clauses.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 13 to 15—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)After clause 15 insert the following new clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mandatory suspension of family payment in certain cases

SPEECH.PARA: "15A. Section 881 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting `the Secretary may determine that the family payment is to be cancelled or suspended' and substituting `the Secretary must determine that the family payment is to be suspended'."
(4)Clause 16, page 6, proposed section 881A, line 10, omit "the Secretary may", substitute "the Secretary must".
(5)Clause 16, page 6, proposed subsection 881A(2), line 11, omit "The Secretary may", substitute "The Secretary must".
(6)Clause 16, page 6, after proposed section 881A, add the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Effect of decision to suspend family payment

SPEECH.PARA: "881B. A determination by the Secretary to suspend family payment under section 881 or 881A remains in force until whichever of the following first occurs:
(a)a determination is made by the Secretary following provision of the information the non-provision of which resulted in the determination to suspend the family payment;
(b)a determination is made by the Secretary cancelling the family payment, being a determination which the Secretary must make 12 months after the determination to suspend the payment.".

These are minor amendments designed to simplify the legislation as it relates to the suspension and cancellation of family payments. Proposed section 873A contained in this bill allows the secretary to issue a notice asking whether the family payment recipient has changed addresses. If the recipient fails to respond to that notice—which is highly likely if the person has moved because the notice will go to the old address—then the secretary may suspend that payment.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, where a person fails to respond to a notice sent from the Department of Social Security, the department is able to suspend or cancel the person's benefit. I understand that it is current departmental policy to suspend the payment for a period of 12 months and if the department does not hear further from the person in that 12-month period it then cancels the payment. The person then has 13 weeks to appeal that decision to be eligible to be paid arrears.

This seems to me to be an eminently reasonable procedure. The amendment that I am proposing simply seeks to ensure that the legislation accurately reflects what is current departmental policy. These amendments seek only to establish a mandatory suspension of family payment in order to ensure that people have that full 12 months to realise their payment has been suspended and to contact the department to provide the necessary information. I reiterate that this is current departmental policy. It in no way infringes on the department's right to suspend a payment for a 12-month period, nor does it prevent it in any way from cancelling that payment after—and I emphasise `after'—the 12 months.

I highlight that the type of situation we are talking about here is simply where the department has sent out a notice requesting certain information and a person who has changed address has not received the notice and, therefore, not provided the information. Cases involving any serious wrongdoing on a recipient's part are dealt with under a different section of the act. We do not seek to amend the department's power in any of those situations.

These amendments simply apply in a situation where a person who may have changed addresses has not received a notice requesting a particular piece of information. The amendments seek only to provide a 12-month suspension period in which to provide that information and, as such, they simply back up the current policy. They allow the department to suspend a payment for 12 months and still allows it to cancel the payment if the required information has not been provided in that time, but not before. I urge the Senate to support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition questions the need for these amendments because we have been informed by the department that this is how the secretary normally administers this discretion anyhow. These amendments, we believe, will make this discretion a Clayton's discretion—the sort of discretion you have when you do not have a discretion. One of the other things that is of concern to us is that these amendments were brought to our attention by the Australian Democrats on Wednesday. We have not had adequate time to undertake the necessary consultation. We are prepared to look at the merits of these amendments if the Democrats are prepared to bring them back at some other stage, but, at this point, we are not in a position to support these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We also oppose the amendments. As has been mentioned, the fact remains that the government had a policy in operation for many years, until the O'Connell and Sevel cases. That policy did recognise the onerous needs of the Social Security administration system in which it is essential that clients keep in touch with the department about their qualifying circumstances and challenge quickly—and by quickly I mean at least within 15 months for family payment—any cessation of payment. The department might be liable for unpredictably large amounts of money if and when clients pursued unlimited rights of arrears. That would be a severe disruption to public administration and expenditure. For those reasons, we do not agree to the Australian Democrats' amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what the opposition is saying. If its members do not support us today, I trust that they will take into account a debate that was held earlier today. When opposition senators moved amendments which we did not support, they argued that, even though there were written agreements in that case which had been signed, they still were not prepared to trust the government but wanted their amendments to strengthen those agreements. So I hope that they will read that debate and note the way they argued on that occasion, and that when they reconsider this issue, they will not simply accept the assurances they have been given but will make sure, by the kinds of amendments we are moving, that what the department says it is doing currently is, in fact, the way the department will continue to act in the future.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

These amendments seek to enhance the operation of the mature age allowance. We welcome the introduction of this allowance in recognition of the disadvantaged position of older unemployed people, but we believe these amendments are necessary to maximise its usefulness.

PARA.TAB: The government estimates that when the allowance is introduced in March next year, around 26,000 newstart recipients will become eligible for the new payment. Importantly, recipients of the allowance will also qualify for the fringe benefits—the earnings credit scheme and the taxation rebate—which are currently available to age pensioners.

The position of older unemployed people is of great concern to the Australian Democrats and I note that the green paper, released yesterday, provides some concrete options for these people. As I said in my speech on the second reading, under the proposed scheme a mature age allowance recipient will be able to undertake work for periods of up to 13 weeks and then return automatically to the allowance. That is all well and good. If, however, they should work for longer than 13 weeks, they will be required to serve yet another 12 months on income support before requalifying for the mature age allowance. We believe the 13-week limit is too restrictive and may have the effect of dissuading allowance recipients from taking work offered to them.

Clearly, people will be reluctant to undertake a few months work if it then means they will have to go back to the jobsearch allowance and fulfil the activity test which that allowance requires for a further 12 months. We feel it is essential to allow mature age allowance recipients to undertake longer periods of work and requalify for the allowance automatically if their work should conclude before they reach the age pension age.

Having already spent 12 months on income support, it is simply unfair to expect these older people to have to do so again. As such, the amendments will provide that where people have previously qualified for the mature age allowance, they may undertake work for any period and then return immediately to the allowance on the completion of that work. I understand the opposition intends to support these amendments and I welcome its support.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be supporting these amendments. As my honourable colleague has said, this will overcome a disincentive for older people taking up work opportunities of longer than 13 weeks of duration. While a mature age allowance should be a recognition of the employment difficulties of middle-aged Australians, the government must realise that it is not a de facto age pension.

PARA.TAB: Older people on mature age allowance will still look for work. As I said in my speech at the second reading stage, many of them have not voluntarily given up work; they have been put on to the scrap heap because of this government's inadequate and inept policies, and its approach to the Australian economy. They still have every right to look for work and most of them are qualified for a wide range of jobs and have enormous skills that are a great loss to this community. Recognition of specific employment difficulties of older Australians does not mean that the incentives to obtain employment should be removed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated, the Democrats and the opposition support these amendments, so, clearly, the government will not be in a majority on this matter. I would just like to point out that the proposed new subsection would mean that if at any time in the past, instead of within the previous three months, a person had received a mature age allowance or a mature age partner allowance, that person would not have to satisfy the requirements of 12 months continuous registration with the CES and 12 months receipt of income support in the period immediately before again claiming mature age allowance. This would be an extremely generous provision.

PARA.TAB: In effect, a person who had received a mature age allowance from March 1994 for only two weeks before obtaining a job, who then worked for two years before again becoming unemployed, would be able to qualify for mature age allowance. This goes beyond the intent of the allowance. The legislation as already proposed in the bill provides that a person receiving a mature age allowance who transfers to newstart allowance does not have to satisfy the newstart qualification requirement of having been registered with the CES for the previous 12 months. Similarly, if that person subsequently decides to transfer back from newstart allowance, the 12-month registration requirement for mature age allowance does not apply.

The earnings credit scheme introduced by this legislation will allow jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowance recipients to accrue a credit of up to $500, which can be offset against income gained from employment. In other words, a single person can accrue credit at a rate of $90 a fortnight and each member of a couple can accrue at a rate of $80 a fortnight. For example, a person earning $400 for a fortnight's work can use the earnings credit to discount this amount from the allowance income test. This will allow the unemployed to earn very limited casual or part-time income without automatically affecting their income support payments. We believe that for the new scheme to be of at least some benefit to recipients, the conditions governing it should be comparable to those applying to the pensioners earnings credit scheme.

PARA.TAB: In line with this, the Democrats are opposed to the provision in this bill that the earnings credit cannot be assessed in a fortnight in which the ordinary income test would reduce the person's unemployment allowance to nil. No such restriction applies to the pensioners scheme and to leave this restriction in would discourage many unemployed people from taking more than a few days full-time work.

Of course, employers simply do not offer anything less than a week. So without these amendments, the scheme may be virtually useless to many of our unemployed people. We should remember that the credit can be assessed only once a year, so that is just a few days work in a full year. This is particularly the case for our young unemployed as they are subject to much tighter income tests on their allowances and will, therefore, find this condition on the earnings credit the most highly restrictive.

With youth unemployment running at a rate of around 30 per cent, it seems ludicrous to introduce such a potentially valuable scheme and then stifle it with these restrictive conditions. For 18- to 20-year-olds, jobsearch cuts out when income reaches about $250 per fortnight. If this provision remains in the legislation, the earnings credit scheme will be useless to these people if they take a job that pays more than about $125 a week. This of course means that these young people may just simply not take the job. For the under 18s, the income cut-out point is even lower still.

In the current labour market, people have to be able to take up whatever work opportunities are available to them. These days, those opportunities may be only a week or so around busy periods such as Christmas or school holidays. As such, these amendments will delete the provision that the earnings credit cannot be assessed in a fortnight in which the ordinary income test would reduce the person's unemployment allowance to nil.

With our job market in its current state, people have to be able to take up whatever work opportunities are available to them and our income support system needs to be flexible enough in order to allow this. To get a foot in the door for potential full-time work, the unemployed must be able to work for at least a week, and the Democrats' amendments will provide for this. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We cannot support these Democrat amendments, which address the issue of joint accounts, the issue of a $1,000 rather than a $500 maximum, and the issue of whether allowees can access existing earning credit if their income exceeds the allowance cut-off point.

PARA.TAB: I turn firstly to the joint accounts issue. One of the primary aims of this initiative is to encourage participation in the work force by both members of a couple. The introduction of joint accounts could serve as an incentive for one member of a couple to withdraw from the work force. It is recognised that both members of a couple have a contribution to make to the labour force. This initiative encourages both parties to take up short-term employment, thereby increasing their overall income. By both persons maintaining links with the labour market, they are maximising their opportunities of returning to full-time employment.

I now turn to the issue of the $1,000 versus the $500 credit limit. The $500 earning credit for the unemployed was an election commitment announced in the election in Investing in the nation. It has subsequently been endorsed by cabinet. For that reason, we cannot agree to that change.

Finally, I turn to the third matter. An upper limit on earnings will target the credit to low to medium income earners. The absence of an upper limit on earnings for accessing any accumulated earnings credit would be excessively generous and involve paying allowances to high as well as low income earners. Having an upper limit still represents a quite generous treatment compared with the standard income test arrangements. A married couple, for example, could have earnings of up to $677 a fortnight—and a single adult up to $416 a fortnight—and still have access to their earning credit. Credits accrued will be preserved for up to 13 weeks for those whose allowances are cancelled because their earnings exceed the upper limit.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be supporting the Democrat amendments. It ought to be remembered that the $500 earning credit for allowance recipients was an election promise in Investing in the nation. It also ought to be noted that the difference between the $500 earnings credit limit for allowees and the $1,000 earnings credit limit for pensioners reflects the difference in the income tests and the income-free areas for allowees and pensioners. The difference between the limits also reflects the difference in the circumstances of allowees and pensioners. As we all know, the pension is a form of long-term income support, while the allowance provides interim support when a person's independent earning capacity is temporarily reduced.

As I mentioned earlier, assets testing for farm families is something that I have been pursuing for some three years. Today I will again pursue this issue. While I am sure that by now most senators understand the problems that those who live on farms, particularly family farms, are facing, I believe that very few of us have had any first-hand experience and have any real understanding of how difficult it is for those farm families. A variety of factors is involved: historic debt, low commodity prices and, in my home state, a whole range of seasonal factors, including mice, frosts and just about every other known disaster.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to see that the government is at last beginning to recognise that we have a problem. That is what we have been negotiating with the government about right through until just a few moments before coming into this chamber to deal with this legislation. While it is not moving as far as we would like and taking out of the assets test the family farm and what a farm family needs to actually run the business, it is at least acknowledging that the piece of paper a farmer has that says that the farm is worth $300,000, $500,000 or $800,000 really means nothing and that what is relevant is what can be earned on that farm, how big the debts are, and the fact that this year many farmers are going to get very little, even for good barley crops, and not make sufficient to pay the bills and meet the overheads.
I will continue to pursue this issue. I will be moving this amendment again next year. Hopefully we will begin to understand the difficulties that our farm families face.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be supporting this amendment. The Democrats have put forward this amendment on a number of previous occasions, without success. We recognise that many farmers and their families are struggling because of a number of factors, not least the economic mismanagement of this Labor government. It should never be forgotten that this Labor government introduced the assets test for the family allowance and has progressively tightened that assets test.

PARA.TAB: The coalition recognises the importance of maintaining equity between families as well as targeting assistance to those in greatest need. If we provide an across-the-board exemption in the family payment assets test for the family farm and related plant and articles, should we then, on the grounds of equity, exempt all business premises, plant and equipment? There are huge ramifications. It is not an easy issue. We have outlined our concerns on previous occasions.

Of course, I do not agree that the very difficult circumstances that farming communities are facing today are due to policy of this government. It is quite a complex issue. They are primarily due to corrupt world markets and low world prices. That is a debate for another time.
