The Democrats recognise some of the positive moves the government has announced in the budget to be made in relation to the management of our long-term unemployed and welcome the small increase to be paid to single newstart allowees over 21. It has been a policy of the Democrats for some time now to align the benefits paid to the unemployed with those currently paid to pensioners. We see the $3 a week increase as a small step toward that goal. Of course, there is to be no increase for those on jobsearch or sickness allowances or for those under 21.

PARA.TAB: As I foreshadowed in my speech in the second reading debate, however, we are opposed to some of the changes being proposed to the compliance testing of the newstart allowance; in particular, the clauses in this legislation which allow the Department of Social Security to activity test newstart clients and to require those people to approach a certain number of employers to obtain employer contact certificates. Unfortunately, this rate of increase and these positive changes are to be accompanied by compliance measures designed to remove 20,000 people from the ranks of the long-term unemployed—not by finding them jobs, of course, but by raising the compliance hurdles and adding some more hoops for these people to jump through.

The Democrats are opposed to these changes, and it is not difficult to understand why. The whole idea behind the newstart agreements was that the long-term unemployed required more individual and flexible arrangements in their jobsearch efforts than those applying to the newly unemployed. The CES was seen as the most appropriate body to provide that case management service, given its ability to take into account an individual's particular circumstances and factors such as local labour market knowledge.

The changes proposed in this bill represent a step back to the old checking mentality and mean a greater standardisation of agreements, with little or no allowance for individual circumstances and with little or no allowance for the expertise of staff involved with the case management of clients. The other aspect of these changes is the responsibility and burden that will be placed on employers.

Over the last couple of weeks, the opposition has constantly reminded the Democrats about the burdens that employers face, particularly those employers who are involved in the running of small businesses. To begin with, employers will be contacted by the unemployed person about the job; they will then need to see that person; they will then have to fill out the employer contact certificate; and they will then have to respond to inquiries from the DSS if a review of someone's jobsearch efforts is undertaken. Let us not forget that employers will be required to complete hundreds of thousands of these certificates each year. It is simply a nightmare, as I am sure Senator Panizza would agree.

The coalition should seriously consider the effect that this could have on those involved in the running of small businesses. The situation will be exacerbated in the many areas where there are few advertised positions suitable for unskilled workers, yet there is a great number of unskilled, unemployed people. This will be particularly true in some rural areas. This proposal is simply a nightmare. Many unskilled jobs are filled without any advertising, which further narrows the number of available positions the unskilled can apply for to satisfy the new requirements.

This could mean that the only small business in town with a job on offer would not only be inundated with people applying for the job but the business owner would also be required to complete social security forms for them. Many employers simply want someone to fill a position and have little time to fill out forms or to talk to the Department of Social Security. It is highly likely that, on top of the problems already associated with the constant job rejection, many unemployed people will have difficulty getting employers to take time to complete these certificates.

The other aspect is the enormous influence an individual employer may have over the income support that an individual unemployed person receives. I remind the Senate that hundreds of thousands of these certificates will require completion by employers each year. If employers refuse to cooperate, the person may risk losing his or her allowance.

We agree with the evidence which was given at the committee inquiry by the welfare rights representative that we are contemplating imposing these much harsher restrictions on our long-term unemployed when there has been no increase whatsoever in the availability of employment opportunities. It is surely beyond contention that very few people are voluntarily unemployed. To impose these harsh conditions at a time of such high unemployment is surely indefensible. Perhaps when the labour market does start to pick up, these sorts of measures may warrant consideration, but they do not at present. The effect of the amendments that I have moved will be to oppose the introduction of employer contract certificates.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some ways the coalition would have every right to support the Democrats' amendments. When we went into the election saying that we would introduce safeguards into the activity test, this hypocritical government said that that was harsh, draconian, uncaring and any other word that it could dream up to make us appear to be the baddies. What did the government do after the election? It did what we suggested. It is yet another example of this hypocritical, underhand government. It is a case of, `Tell them the nice things before the election and pull on the tough things afterwards.'

PARA.TAB: I hope that the Australian public does not have too short a memory and that it will remember these matters before the next election. During the election we will remind the Australian public every day of all of the government's broken promises—one broken promise after another—and of all of the promises that the government did not make. We will remind the government day in and day out, night in and night out, about all the nasties and about the ways in which it deceived the Australian public.

In my speech at the second reading stage, I pointed out that we argued that there ought to be a drawing up of guidelines to ensure that local and individual circumstances are taken into account and that that should negate some of the argument that the Democrats are putting. As someone who has an interest in these matters and as a member of the relevant estimates committee, I put the minister on notice that I will be following up questions in estimates hearings to ensure the provisions are being applied.

Of course, the Democrats never go to the estimates hearings, so it will be up to the opposition to follow this matter through and make sure that it is checked out. They never appear at the estimates hearings. When the department and the government are being put under the spotlight about the way they are using taxpayers' money, where are the Democrats? They have gone away. They are having a day off. I do not know what they are doing, but they are not at the estimates hearings challenging the bureaucrats, like Senator Bishop, about what is happening in the area of taxation; or like me, finding out what is happening to $4.9 million of taxpayers' money on selling the disability reform package. They are not there, they are at the bottom of the garden or somewhere. But I will be there. I will be asking the department whether the concerns that the Democrats have expressed are actually being addressed.

The Democrats stand up here and grandstand but they never follow through. They never deliver in the end. That is the message from this. They stand here and grandstand about what they are going to do about all these people going off to meet the activity test, but they will never check up with the department what is actually happening; they never seek to find out how many people are finding it difficult and what research the department has done. They will not be at the estimates hearings, but I put them on notice that I will be.

As I said before, it is important that we strike an appropriate balance between ensuring that those on the allowances are meeting their obligation of actively seeking work and providing them with assistance in a sympathetic way. We will be following that matter through very carefully.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what happened before these amendments were put. We have just had a flurry of verbal abuse from Senator Patterson—
—The facts.

—We will gets to the facts in a moment. I will pass Senator Patterson's compliments on to Senator Richardson, the minister responsible in this area. Senator Patterson accused us of hiding these initiatives before the election and playing up the changes the opposition was going to make in this area. She said that we alleged—I think quite fairly—that the coalition's changes were draconian and unnecessarily harsh on the unemployed. They were. We are not implementing the opposition's policy. There are clear policy differences.

PARA.TAB: Senator Woodley made quite a contribution about how onerous these provisions would be for small business. I have heard a lot of complaints from small business about a lot of matters in the three and a half years since I have been a senator, and about other matters prior to becoming a senator. I have never heard a complaint from an employer in small business about these matters in terms of placing some onus on unemployed people when they apply for a position. I have never heard a complaint from a small business about this type of form filling. When I have got a comment, it has generally been one of praise that we have these sorts of initiatives to ensure that the unemployed people who are looking for work are carrying it out in a satisfactory way.

In relation to the general philosophical background to this change, I refer to the recent findings of the report on the post-implementation review of newstart which considered the administrative arrangements. That interim report indicated a need for better early identification of unemployed clients at risk of becoming long-term unemployed and a need to provide more intensive assistance to prevent such clients from becoming long-term unemployed. An interim evaluation of the findings demonstrated the advantages of providing assistance to those clients with barriers to regaining employment at the point at which those barriers are detected, rather than waiting until a particular duration gate has been reached. Currently intensive CES assistance is primarily targeted towards NSA recipients, those unemployed clients registered by the CES as having been unemployed for more than 12 months. The measures comprise a number of administrative arrangements aimed at clients at greatest risk of becoming long-term unemployed, and supporting legislative arrangements that allow the secretary to require clients detected as being at risk of becoming long-term unemployed to enter into case managed jobsearch activity agreements with a view to arresting long-term dependency on income support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume from Senator Patterson's speech that she is supporting our amendments.

—I said at the beginning I was opposing them. In my second reading speech, I indicated that we would not be supporting them. The answer is that we will not be supporting them. While I am on my feet, and in order to save time, I indicate that we will not be supporting amendment Nos 13, 14 and 15 either.

—I assumed that that was what Senator Patterson was about to do, although from her rhetoric it was hard to determine which way she was going to vote. In a preaching class once, I discovered some notes from a preacher. In the margin of these notes to the sermon was written the words, `Argument weak—shout'. I presume that is what Senator Patterson was doing because her argument really was, `We should support the Democrat amendments, but we are not going to, so let's bash the Democrats and shout about it while we are doing it, because that is the only way we can cover up our real intention'.

Clause 22.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats oppose this clause because we are opposed to allowing the Department of Social Security to work test newstart recipients. As I said in my comments to the previous amendment, the Commonwealth Employment Service is a far more appropriate body to supervise allowees' jobsearch activities as it has the capacity to take into account individual factors. The work testing conducted by the Department of Social Security is mechanical in nature and will do nothing to place long-term unemployed people into jobs. This whole exercise needs to be seen for what it is—a process of knocking off people's allowance.

PARA.TAB: Clause agreed to.

Clause 69.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 69, page 90, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

"69. Section 17 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting `male employees' from paragraph (a) of the definition of `average weekly earnings' in subsection (1) and substituting `employees (all persons)'; ".

I express the coalition's concern that this provision will discriminate against people where it is manifest they have not suffered an economic loss as a result of a compensable incident. I outlined our concerns in detail in the second reading debate.

PARA.TAB: The government's provision seeks to deem that 50 per cent of all lump sum compensation payments are for economic loss, regardless of the circumstances, incident or person involved. The coalition recognises that there is a need to prevent cost shifting to the social security system. We understand that there are cases where the economic loss component is minimised to reduce the social security preclusion period. While we do not condone such action, it is imperative that the government comes up with a system that does not at the same time inadvertently penalise people where it is manifest that no economic loss has occurred.

An example would be a long-term disability support pensioner who receives a lump sum payment as a result of a compensable incident. He or she has not suffered an economic loss, yet the government's provisions deem that 50 per cent of the lump sum payment is for economic loss.

The coalition asked the government to come up with amendments to overcome this problem, but it has failed to do so. The only amendment that it has come up with is an exemption for lump sum payments under $10,000. Not only is this an arbitrary cut-off point; it also does not specifically overcome the problems that we have highlighted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the comments of Senator Patterson. I say at the outset in relation to these provisions that I sat on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Concern was expressed there by not only the union movement but also welfare groups and solicitors representing claimants for personal injuries.

PARA.TAB: Since then, I have been contacted by the Law Society of Western Australia. I have seen a letter from the Law Society of New South Wales and the Wollongong and District Law Society. They all condemn these proposals, which would take into account such things as medical bills, legal fees, payment for pain and suffering and the calculation of a non-entitlement to social security.

At the outset, it would be reasonable to take into account an award of damages where there was an economic loss component, because that is payment in lieu of wages. It operates in the same way as wages. People getting an income would be subject to testing for social security. So I have no qualm about that.

As Senator Patterson mentioned, these proposals contemplate bringing in the pensioner who might have no economic loss component. A pensioner is not one who would suffer any loss of income. Similarly, a single parent who might suffer an accident of some sort would have very little or no economic loss component. Therefore, these proposals disadvantage those who can least afford it, especially at a time when they have suffered some disability.

I urge the government to reconsider this proposition, which really attacks the average Australian whom this legislation is designed to support in cases of need. I reiterate the overwhelming opposition to this clause from legal firms in Western Australia and the support for the stance that I am taking.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I pay tribute to the work that I know Senator Ellison has done in informing his party and making sure that either the amendment that we would have moved or the amendment that Senator Patterson has moved is carried. I agree with the remarks of Senator Patterson and Senator Ellison in this case. Of all the measures contained in this bill to which the Democrats are opposed, the provisions relating to the treatment of compensation lump sum payments are perhaps the most objectionable.

PARA.TAB: I need to also state that, in addition to this amendment, the Democrats will be opposing clauses 70, 71, 72, 73 and 74. I also point out to the Senate that this amendment leaves intact the change in the divisor to be used in calculating preclusion periods.

I remind the Senate that the people affected by this legislation are people who have been victims of some form of industrial accident or, perhaps, a car accident. The money to be countered by these proposals may have been awarded by a court to cover past and/or future medical expenses or as compensation for pain and suffering incurred as a result of that accident. While the current situation, using the so-called 50 per cent rule, is a broad brush approach, which already disadvantages some in order to yield some administrative simplification, the proposed system will go even further.

The government argues that there is significant rorting of the system through the construction of compensation payments which split the settlement into two payments—one typically large, maybe for pain and suffering, and another typically much smaller for economic loss. From the outset the Democrats have acknowledged this problem and most, if not all, of the witnesses that appeared before the standing committee inquiry into this issue also acknowledged it. I concede that it is the case that such construction occurs. The amendment being proposed will take the assumed guilty approach for all compensation recipients, thereby disadvantaging those who receive a compensation payment which contains no economic loss component.

A clear demonstration of the inequity of this proposal is the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act which specifically preclude claiming for economic loss. This is also the case under section 98 of the Victorian system. There have been some murmurs of acknowledgment from the government that the proposed change will be a problem in Victoria. We need to remember however that it appears highly likely that the Victorian system will be adopted by other states, notably South Australia and Western Australia, meaning that what was once a small problem in Victoria will then spread to nearly half of the country.

A further aspect in the government's thinking on this move, and I think this was admitted by departmental officers at the Senate committee inquiry, is the argument the government ran during the pensioner shares debate. The government said that people should be exhausting all other funds available to them before calling on the social security system. In some cases, I am sure that is justified. In this case, however, a person may have received those funds as a result of an industrial accident or a car accident and they may have been awarded by a court to cover past and/or future medical expenses or as compensation for pain or suffering. To expect people to use this money to pay their rent and buy their groceries is heartless.

The government's proposal does nothing to address this problem at its roots but rather impacts on the final recipient, the injured person. We will be opposing this change and we know that the opposition will join us. I feel confident that if the cost shifting is as large a problem as the minister would have us believe—and I have no reason to doubt that it is—then the resources and expertise available both within the department and in some of those outside bodies who gave such convincing evidence to the inquiry will be able to develop a situation which goes to the heart of the problem and does so in an equitable and fair way. We support such a solution. But we are unable to support the proposal before us today. I therefore commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had some previous experience with workers compensation before I came into the Senate. I think there is a very deep philosophical issue we have to tackle with regard to lump sum payments. We have to determine whether it is a correct approach to encourage lump sum payments at all. It is a debate that we are also having at present in the retirement incomes area. I think the inevitable shift away from lump sum payments to annuities or pensions, whatever term we may use, is a necessary one.

PARA.TAB: Likewise in the pensions area, I notice that there has been a trend in recent years for state governments and some private corporations to encourage lump sum payments or a mix of lump sum payment and pension. This is particularly so in the government sector. Whilst it might be a saving for those state governments, it is an increase in the costs that the federal government has to meet. Whether it is being done deliberately or not, people do tend to spend a part or all of their lump sum payment in the case of retirement income and then go on to the age pension. That is shifting these payments effectively from state governments to the federal government. That is a similar issue but one which we should not debate today.

The provisions for dealing with the treatment of compensation payments for social security purposes are intended to address double dipping by individuals and prevent compensation authorities from shifting their costs to the Commonwealth. The measures announced in the budget sought to close off a number of identified avenues for minimising the impact of current provisions. The main point of contention about these measures has been the proposal that 50 per cent of any compensation lump sum payment, regardless of whether it includes an economic loss component, be included in the formula used to calculate periods during which most social security payments are not payable. The age pension is the main exception.

My understanding is that all parties appreciated the need to prevent double dipping and cost shifting by state compensation systems. They also agreed that the government was trying to fix a problem which needed attention. None of the compensation measures were adopted as an exercise in heartless penny pinching. I make it clear that the concerns of unions and the welfare sector have been treated seriously.

Considerable efforts were made to find options which would ensure that the arrangements were fair and reasonable. The minister specifically wrote to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs to discuss these matters. In the end these options simply could not be structured to cope with all the possible cases. This simply reflects the complexity of this area of policy. Consequently, the government will not be opposing the amendments to delete this provision, but it intends to revisit the matter and seek alternative solutions to the identified problem.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 70 to 74—by leave—taken together, and negatived.
Clauses 75 to 77—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 78.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Democrats are opposed to this clause as it inserts a provision which would require a person's partner to take action to obtain a compensation payment for that person where that person may be eligible for such a payment. To allow this change to go through would surely rely on far too rosy a view of the relationships of couples. The Democrats seek to delete this clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the government will not be supporting the Democrats' approach.
—I indicate that the opposition will not be supporting the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8)Page 106, after clause 100, insert the following new clause:

"100A. Subsection 12(2A) of the Principal Act is amended by omitting all the words after `each House of the Parliament' and substituting `further comprehensive reports including references to all the matters identified in Guideline 12 of the Privacy Commissioner's Guidelines:
(a)by the end of October 1994; and

TAB.TAB: (b)by the end of October 1995'.".

SPEECH.PARA: (9)Clause 102, page 106, omit the clause, substitute the following Division heading and clause—
"102. Section 21 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting `22 January 1994' and substituting `22 January 1996'.".

These amendments seek to extend the sunset provisions of the data-matching program until January 1996 and maintain the current annual reporting arrangements. I have taken a particular interest in privacy since I have been in this chamber and I was delighted that it was recognised the other day. I received a Christmas card from someone who recognises that I have taken a long interest in the matter. On the front of the card, Santa is up against some computer equipment and it reads, `He knows when you've been sleeping; he knows when you're awake; he knows when you've been bad or good', and inside the card reads, `You probably can sue him for invasion of privacy'. I thought that was quite appropriate when we are discussing the Privacy Bill. I have taken a long interest in it and I was delighted to see that we can have a sense of humour, despite the fact that it is a very serious issue.

PARA.TAB: The sunset clause and the reporting arrangements were included in the data-matching act as a safeguard due to the significant privacy ramifications of the program and the doubts over its financial benefits. As I said in my second reading speech, the Australian National Audit Office report that was tabled in October demonstrates that these concerns, which were expressed by both the coalition and the Australian Democrats in late 1990, were totally valid.

From reading the Hansard of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs one would think we looked into a crystal ball and said, `What if? Can you do this? How did you estimate that?'. We were nearly 100 per cent right and the government was nearly 100 per cent wrong. That is how bad it was. We were told that we would be jeopardising all these savings. I think I have mentioned before that we were going to change one word in the bill and Mr Hawke wrote to Dr Hewson making some extravagant claim that we were going to affect the savings. That has not been the case.

I outlined in detail in the second reading speech and when the report came down that the government did not make the savings that it said it was going to make. We believe that the sunset clause should remain so that the parliament can observe what is happening and decide whether this very intrusive measure is warranted. It is also important that the department reports to the parliament on the basis which was required in the original bill and now in the act. That enables us, as representatives of the people, to look very closely at what is happening and how the guidelines are being met. From my discussions with the Democrats, I believe that they will be supporting the amendments and the extension of this sunset clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government would prefer not to have a sunset clause. We recognise from the comments of Senator Woodley and Senator Patterson that, on this occasion, our proposals will not receive the necessary support. I should try to liven up proceedings, as Senator Patterson was doing earlier, by pointing out to the chamber just how much money this data-matching has saved the Australian taxpayer. The figure was $70,360,000 for the last financial year.-
—It is not $300 million like you said.

—That is a directly measurable figure, Senator Patterson. That does not include perhaps another $40 million to $50 million because of the deterrence effect in the measure of data-matching. I think it has been a very significant saving and it ensures that the sort of waste that has been occurring is minimised.

PARA.TAB: In his special report, the Privacy Commissioner makes the point that the safeguards put in place have been substantially complied with. This is demonstrated by the fact, which was his other key point, that the very large number of the matches have proven, following further internal investigation by the department, to not be of value, which emphasises the fairness of the safeguards. In addition to the success of the safeguards we still have, no matter how one looks at the matter, substantial savings from the scheme. The Australian Democrats have decided to support the opposition on these amendments. So once again, in two years time, we will have this debate about whether a program is quite obviously succeeding. What is wrong with those opposite deciding now?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you told big fibbers; that is why: $300 million, what nonsense!

—I did not say $300 million, Senator Patterson. I said $70 million, and that is a very substantial figure for the taxpayers of this country. The Privacy Commissioner is fairly convinced that monitoring of the scheme is operating well, so much so that in a letter to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) he said that he expects that when we do have this debate again in two years time it should be the last time, as a final decision about its permanence would be made at that time. So even the Privacy Commissioner anticipates the continuing success of the program. I realise that we will lose and, as we have to get home for Christmas, I will say no more.
—The Australian Democrats support the amendments for the reasons given in my second reading speech.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Clauses 101 and 102, as amended, agreed to.
Progress reported.
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a rather long delayed start to the committee stage of consideration of the Native Title Bill but I think, on balance, the delay may expedite our consideration of this matter. The reason why there has been some delay is not only the pressure of other business, but the need to try and put a mass of complex material into a format that would expedite our discussion. I think every minute of the delay so far has probably saved us two or three minutes of possible confusion in the chamber. I hope that confusion will now be able to be avoided as a result of the material before honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: Party leaders and those leading the debate should have in front of them a committee stage running sheet of some 13 pages which goes basically clause by clause. If they have not, may I offer them one. Do the Democrats and Senator Chamarette have a copy of that running sheet?

I will explain the nature of the running sheet and how the material is organised. Basically, the bill is addressed down the left hand column from the preamble through to clause 238 in order. The right hand columns indicate where amendments are to be moved. Those amendments are grouped, so far as possible, by subject matter in order that, so far as is possible and reasonable, the debate can coalesce around particular subject areas in sequence taking place at the time the subject matter in question first arises, thus avoiding, hopefully, repetition as one works one's way through the bill and encounters the same subject matter on a number of future occasions. That is the basic concept.

The material honourable senators have before them consists in the first instance, apart from the bill itself, of course, of three bundles of amendments that were circulated yesterday by the government, the Democrats and the Greens, respectively. The government's list of amendments runs from 1 to 74; the Democrats' amendments from 1 to 52; and the Greens' amendments from 1 to 65. There are in addition some further amendments representing redrafting of some of those already circulated amendments. I am not sure that it is complete, as circulated so far, or that everybody has them so far. But there are some government amendments in that category; there are some Green amendments in that category; there are some Democrat amendments in that category.

For example, there are a couple of pages of supplementary Democrat amendments labelled 2A and 28A, respectively. What they represent is a redrafting of Democrat amendment No. 2, as circulated previously in the consolidated list, and a redrafting of Democrat amendment No. 28, as previously circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are we supposed to deal with it if we don't have things before we start?

—Be reasonable. There is only a handful of additional amendments in this particular category. The major amendments, some 200 of them coming from three parties, have been circulated with 24 hours notice. If we had delayed the start-up of the debate by another half hour, we could have had all material in front of us, but it has not been possible to do that. There is ample material before us on which we can now start.

PARA.TAB: If I might, I will mention further that it ought to be possible, in my judgment, provided a reasonable approach is adopted to the conduct of this debate, to work through the groups of amendments as they now stand in a reasonable time. What that reasonable time will be, I do not know, but I would hope that if we broke only for an hour over dinner and that if we worked our way systematically through this and there was not too much unnecessary repetition, it might well be possible to conclude this whole committee stage debate some time late tonight. I think it is obviously in everybody's interests to do that, given the difficulties about transport and so on. If it is not possible to do that, well, so be it. We will just have to make other arrangements—I am not quite sure what they are going to be—tomorrow afternoon or indeed Sunday. But the hope and the intention have been that now that the material is organised in the way that I have described—and those supplementary amendments are being duplicated in the office as I speak and will be distributed around the chamber; that is, the small group of amendments, some seven or eight in total, I think, to add to the three bundles honourable senators have already—they will be in the chamber certainly before we get to them.

Under those circumstances, I think if it is understood the way it is proposed to proceed through the running sheet in this way and if we are prepared to accept the principle of amendments being put together and debated in subject groupings, it may well be possible to conclude this debate at a reasonable hour. I hope so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, do I now have all the amendments on my running sheet?

—The running sheet before you should contain a reference to every single amendment that I am aware of. It is not to be assumed that every one of those amendments will in fact be moved. It is quite possible that quite a significant number of them will not. For example, under clause 4 you will see a reference to `C. Parliamentary Joint Committee'—government amendments 3 and 44A. Government amendment 3 is on the list of government amendments that were previously circulated. Amendment 44A is in the supplementary group that is being duplicated at the moment and will be available in just a very short space of time.

—I want to put on the record in the strongest possible terms our protest at the way in which this matter is being handled. We are dealing with one of the most complex and socially difficult pieces of legislation that has been put before this parliament for decades. What are we being asked to do? On the last day of the parliament at a quarter past four in the afternoon, the government is asking us to debate what seems to me to amount to something like 250 amendments. The government said, `But you got 200 of those amendments 24 hours ago and you therefore ought to be happy'.

PARA.TAB: What a way to run a legislative program! Could one envisage a more incompetent handling of the management of government affairs than the way in which this process has been dealt with. I cannot. We received 200 amendments 24 hours ago but, when we came into the chamber for the debate this afternoon, there was another swag of amendments—a swag of amendments from the Greens, from the Australian Democrats and from the government. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) says, `Some of these amendments amend the amendments we gave you yesterday, but we're not quite sure which ones yet and there may still be more to come'. What a legislative shambles!

The way in which this matter is being handled is a national disgrace. There is no way, through this process, that this parliament can pass sound legislation. We have seen this government try to short cut before. What has happened on every occasion is that within a couple of months it has been back apologising with major amendments to bills. That will happen most certainly after this process, if this bill is carried in this form.

All senators in this place are equal and have an equal right to have before them all of these amendments, adequate time to understand the amendments and a running sheet that will make the process workable. But they have not been given the courtesy or the opportunity of that very basic requirement. This is a totally unsatisfactory situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few pages of scribble!

—As my colleague says, the running sheet is in handwritten scribble. We have to try to work out what on earth it is all about and only one copy was given to each party leader as we walked into the chamber for this debate today.

PARA.TAB: How the government runs its legislative program is up to it, but we also have responsibilities as the house of review to do our job as well as we are able to. The government is not allowing us to do that when it administers the program in the way that it has done today. It is a disgrace. This government should bow its head in shame. This is not the way in which to debate legislation.

I put that protest on the record. I do not know what is going to happen later tonight. The minister said, `We'll break sometime for an hour for dinner'. What sort of management is that? Most senators, of course, have tickets for planes. What are we doing with the airlines? I am told that after tomorrow morning, no more plane tickets are available until next week and possibly not then. What a shambles! What is happening to the staff of this place? Are they going to work all night tonight? What about all the additional costs? What a mess—what an absolute mess.

All of those opposite—not just the minister—ought to be embarrassed. This is a shambles and they should not be a party to it. They ought to bow their heads in shame because this is not a sensible way to enact legislation. Anyway, the government has made this choice. It wants to do it this way. We will, of course, meet our requirement and sit as long as the government requires us to sit to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to put a couple of comments on the record with reference to Senator Hill's very unfair remarks. The fact of the matter is that the opposition announced earlier this week that it was going to vote against all amendments and against the bill. One might wonder what members of the opposition wanted to consider about the amendments which have been circulated, when they have already said, `We're not interested'. Mr Peter Reith has said on the public record, `This bill is rotten to the core and we will vote against every amendment'.

PARA.TAB: The second point I want to make is that the opposition finds it very difficult to understand a consensual process. What, in fact, has been happening behind the scenes is that Democrats, Greens, Aboriginal groups, lawyers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Some Aboriginal groups; not all of them.

—Actually, a great many Aboriginal people. Democrats, Greens, Aboriginal groups, lawyers, draftsmen, QCs and many others with an interest in this issue have been debating, discussing and negotiating for more than 24 hours.

PARA.TAB: The opposition's problem with the amendments is its problem. We know that we have spent a great deal of time going into the detail. We know that we have put our amendments to Senator Alston, who is the opposition's spokesperson. Senator Alston received our amendments last night. The principles of those amendments are well known. There is no problem in moving forward from here, because those of us who care about this bill and these amendments have had time to look at the detail.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have sat here since 9 o'clock this morning in expectation of the Mabo legislation coming forward. Meanwhile, there has been a troop of QCs, Democrats and Greens traipsing into Senator Gareth Evans's office trying to negotiate a deal.
—We want to get the detail of it right.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand the feelings of honourable senators but we have a long way to go and I think it would help us all if we start off in an orderly fashion.
—We are handed a running sheet in someone's writing.
—You can't read it.

—Senator Tambling is right; I cannot read it. Then, half an hour ago we were given three or four pages of amendments which have massive implications for every farmer, every grazier and every miner in Australia.
—And lots of Aboriginals.

—And a lot of Aboriginal people in Australia. These amendments will have to be given to QCs and lawyers for their interpretation if we are to get any sense out of them. We were thrown six or seven pages of new government amendments. While the government has lawyers and so forth at its disposal, we have to consider these amendments on the run. How can Senator Gareth Evans reasonably expect that we can go into the detail of those amendments in half an hour?

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans is being quite unreasonable. He is not being unreasonable to people in here; he is being unreasonable to every farmer out there—and there are 145,000 of them—and all the miners and all the Aboriginal people who want to know what, in the name of goodness, is happening and who have not got a clue. Senator Evans, in bringing in new amendments, did not even have the decency to give the farmers, the miners or the Aboriginal people a chance to see them. It was just, `Here, cop this; this is the deal that we have done'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true.
—It is true.

—Yes, it is true. Senator Kernot should not say that. The mining industry has not seen the new amendments, neither have the Aboriginals or the farmers; their representatives have not seen these amendments. These amendments have come straight off the press with no time even to get a typist to type them up—just straight in here, and away they go.

PARA.TAB: This is an obscenity. This is the most important legislation that has ever come before the Australian parliament, and Senator Evans is treating this parliament with contempt; he is treating the farmers with contempt; he is treating the Aboriginals with contempt; and he is treating the wealth producers of this nation with contempt. He is sitting over there smugly, trying to cut a deal. He wants to get the bill through before Christmas; he knows the thing is collapsing around him and he cannot hold his caucus together—get it through, and do not worry about the rest of Australia!

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is crossing the floor from your team, Ronnie?

—That is another matter. Senator Evans ought to be ashamed of himself for coming in here and talking to us about human rights; he would not even know the meaning of the words `human rights'. He has treated this place abominably. All I can say is that those opposite are just a disgusting group of people.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Can this galah over here, who is the Manager of Government Business, sit on an armrest in this place and cackle and interject?
—Order! On the point of order, all honourable senators are required to speak from their chairs.

—It is very important that we examine the process by which what is, supposedly, one of the most significant pieces of legislation to have been introduced into this parliament, has been handled over the last few days.

PARA.TAB: I am appalled at the cavalier manner in which Senator Gareth Evans has essentially just distributed pieces of paper at the last minute. For example, I note that yesterday we were given a one-page document of government amendments grouped by subject matter. It lists various blocks with clauses alongside them. When we look at the running sheet, which was delivered within the last hour, we find that it does not quite accord with that sheet. There has been virtually no opportunity for any sensible digestion.

What appals me above all is the way in which Senator Kernot seems to approach this whole matter. She ought to be captain and coach of the industrial relations club. She talks about a consensual process; what I take her to mean by that is that essentially the democratic process is not good enough for her. What she wants is deals behind closed doors. In her extremely sanctimonious way, she criticises anyone who dares to say that we ought to be allowed to understand amendments so that we can contribute to the debate. Whether or not she has taken a position of opposition, I would have thought that she would at least tolerate, if not welcome, the opportunity for others to comment on the significance of amendments. But no. All we have from Senator Kernot is the statement that we were given the principles of Democrat amendments.

When I walked into this place today, I was handed by Senator Gareth Evans a couple of Democrat amendments, 2A and 28A, to go with the amendments circulated yesterday by Senator Kernot and, again, I suppose, further amendments headed `Replacement and new amendments' in the name of the Democrats. So what we end up with is Senator Kernot with an intention, obviously, to have as little discussion as possible, to leave the chamber whenever she is confronted with the reality of her own hypocrisy, and to not be prepared to practise what we all profess to preach in this place—in other words, the Democrats are into the politics of exclusion. They do not want a sensible parliamentary debate; that would be far too democratic. What they want is to do deals outside the chamber. We have had people coming to us during the course of this morning saying, `What's going on?'. We have said that what we understand is going on is that the Democrats and the Greens and the government all have their heads together and are trying to put together some amendments that will suit everyone, and then they can come in here, put the package on the table and say, `There you are, done'. From what we can understand, at the last minute, that process has not quite worked—but not for want of support on the part of the Democrats. The Democrats clearly think that that is the way we do parliamentary business—that we do not expose issues to debate, that we do not try to explain what amendments are all about; we simply rush things through because they have been agreed beforehand.

If ever there was a classic demonstration proving the need for a special examination by a select committee—for which we have long argued—it is before us today in that we have been given in the order of 200 amendments, which we have had no opportunity to comprehend and no opportunity to make comments on. The best one could possibly do is start from a position of principle and say, `Well, in general terms, this is our impression'. We take legal advice on the run. Everyone knows that not all lawyers agree—and why should they, any more than all senators do? How can anyone possibly do as we did—sit down with hand delivered amendments three-quarters of an hour or an hour ago, try to understand what those amendments mean and then come in here and make an intelligent contribution?

Yet we have Senator Kernot carrying on as though somehow it is hypocrisy on our part to want to understand these things. In other words, if she is serious about the parliamentary process, which clearly she is not, she would have acknowledged long ago the overwhelming need for a select committee process. Yet, from the very outset, that is the last thing the Democrats would countenance. What they had in mind was deals, deals, deals, and that is what they have done.

I simply want to put on the record that the Democrats' approach to this whole debate is even more scandalous than the government's in many respects. It simply destroys any claim they might have had to keeping anyone honest, because they just do not know the difference between honesty and dishonesty. As Senator Hill rightly says, part of the family, part of the group, part of the IR club approach—consensual politics has replaced democratic politics and now we have to pay the penalty. No doubt we will do the best we can. But if people ever doubted this was a model of how not to go about things, they ought to go back and study what has happened over the last 24 hours and they will see that this is the worst possible way to debate probably the most significant piece of legislation that has come before the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my first remarks to Senator Gareth Evans with respect to some of his remarks which he has never substantiated and which ought to be substantiated if we are to proceed with this debate and deal with this bill before Christmas. I refer to Senator Evans saying, `Look, there's a fragile consensus on this bill, this being the appropriate response to Mabo No. 2, and if we let it fall out past Christmas, well, the consensus will be gone'. That, I understand, is his reasoning. I have heard all variations of that, but that is basically what has been said.

PARA.TAB: There is a fundamental flaw in that reasoning. What Senator Evans wants to say to us in this chamber is that, if they, the Labor Party and the Democrats, and I do not know whether we know what the Greens or Senator Harradine are doing yet, find that what they are going to do now is very unpopular—if over January they find out it is acutely unpopular—they might not have the guts to go ahead. That is what those opposite basically are saying; they are such a weak and gutless bunch of people that they would not proceed with this, which I understand very many of them genuinely believe is the appropriate response to Mabo No. 2.

We understand that. I think some people do not perhaps extend the same courtesy to what we think is the appropriate response to Mabo No. 2. Nonetheless, some people think this is the genuine and better response. If those opposite really think that, and if they are not part of a pack of gutless wonders, why would they not want to have their legislation, their response, properly dealt with? Why would they not want to have every nook and cranny of the legislation right? Why would they not want to have all of the amendments properly considered? The only reason they can offer for proceeding with this legislation is that they are too chicken to face the public response that they may well get if they go into January.

It seems to me that is a fundamentally unacceptable way to proceed to make legislation because Labor and the Democrats are saying, `We're the parliament in here and we want to do this. But, heavens above, if people find out what we are doing, they might not like it and then we'd go another way. We would not have the guts to proceed if more people decided that they didn't like this'.

That is not a problem for me because I do not have that view. But I think it is a problem for everyone who wants this bill dealt with before Christmas, who wants the amendments not considered properly, who wants this rushed through. The only reason for rushing it through is that they are such a pack of gutless wonders with no stomach at all to face any debate that may or may not arise in January. They are such a pack of gutless weaklings that they had better rush it through now, otherwise it would be a bit awkward.

I can see one senator over there smiling at me and I suspect it is because the mirror has been put up in front of him and he recognises something. That is what I suspect. He recognises that his party is asking him to join in with the Democrats and some others and pass some legislation irrespective of whether the detail of it is right or wrong. The reason his party is asking him to do that is that it knows that if it is electorally unpopular, the government will not have the guts to do it when we come back. It is fundamentally unacceptable to say, `We must rush legislation through here, otherwise the public will find out about it, and if they are all unhappy about it, heavens, we might not have the guts to go ahead'. That is a fundamentally unacceptable way to proceed.

But in any event, I think there are some other points that need to be made with respect to some remarks made by Senator Kernot. I will not repeat at length Senator Alston's remarks, but what he says is right; Senator Kernot says, `Look, you do not understand. There has been a consensual process about this'. Why do all these taxpayers here fund this building, fund the staff, fund the parliamentary library and all the research facilities that we have? Why do we bother with all of this? Why do we not just vote from our electoral offices because then the convenient deals could be done in back rooms?

The natural consequence of what Senator Kernot says is: unless we are prepared to deal on this particular issue this particular way, unless, for example, in this case we think this is the appropriate response to Mabo No. 2 and unless we come to the table with that view, then the doors shut in our face, and if the poor suckers think that when it gets to parliament we will be able to debate it, think again, because the executive with power of numbers and a deal being done in the back room is going to make parliament irrelevant. I do not think any of those opposite should be proud of that.

I look forward, not to this legislation being passed but if it is passed, to it coming back to be amended and reminding all the gutless wonders in this place that they took part and encouraged the bill to be passed without proper consideration. It will remind them of the expenses incurred by private citizens—the government does not have to worry about it; it will not cost anyone in here anything if it is all wrong. The government does not have to worry; someone else can foot the bill. Those opposite can come back and have their salaries and they will be okay. They can say, `Oh, well, Christmas was a bit busy'. If we had former Senator Powell here, she would say, `I want to go home'. That was the excuse for rushing things through last time.

TALK.START.PARA: —She's home all right!
—The electorate told her what they thought of that attitude of let us rush things through because we want to go home; that is just simply inadequate.

PARA.TAB: The first point I want to make with respect to Senator Kernot is that consensual politics is, I think, a substitute for the better democratic process. It says, `Unless you'll come and do a deal at our table on the meal of our choice, you'll be locked out, and if you poor suckers think parliament is going to have influence on the deal that we come to, think again, because by force of numbers we'll shove through whatever we like'. That is what all those opposite are going along with today—inadequate consideration. Senator Kernot says the principles of her amendments have been understood for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —She hasn't got any principles.

—I actually do not necessarily agree with that. But the point I am making is that if Senator Kernot says the principles of her amendments have been understood for some time, then why do we bother with this legislation? Why do we not chuck it out, come in here, agree on some principles and then we will let someone else work out the detail? Why do we not let everybody else work out the detail and not us?

PARA.TAB: What Senator Kernot does not understand is that the responsibility of every person in this place is to get the detail right. The principles are the easy part. We are paid to do a job. Sure, we can come to some agreement about what principles ought to be implemented but then we should get the detail right. So when Senator Kernot says, `The principles of our amendments have all been agreed to', I say, `So what?'. We want to have time to consider the full detail of all of these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot has had her go, she has had her say, and now I am having mine.
—Tell the truth.

—I am telling the truth. I want to acknowledge that interjection from Senator Kernot. She is instructing me to tell the truth and, by doing so, implying that I am not. The Hansard record will show that I am and she will live to regret the day that she made that accusation to me. Sister Sanctimony does not like criticism being levelled at her. She comes in here and says, `Tell the truth'. I am putting my view and she can just button up until I have finished. The record will show that Senator Kernot did say, `The principles of our amendments have been understood'. All I say is, `Big deal!'. Our job is to get the detail right.

PARA.TAB: The third point I want to make with respect to Senator Kernot explains why I call her Sister Sanctimony. She says, `We are the people who care. We know about these details. We have been caring about this for so long'. What she is trying to do—I am surprised that this is not a broadcast day because that is the sort of day that this sort of mishmash goes on—is say that the people who care know about this. There is a clear implication that anyone who does not agree with Senator Kernot does not care about it; anyone who does not think this is the appropriate response to Mabo No. 2 does not care about it. What she is trying to say is that all us heartless people over here do not care about it. I just want to inform Senator Kernot that I happen to be of the view—I certainly know it is true for me and I believe it to be true in the case of my colleagues—that we simply have a different view as to how Mabo No. 2 should be responded to.

We are all going to have our differences in this respect; we have a different view about how it ought to go. We are entitled to come in here and debate the proposals put forward by this back room sort of consensual deal—I would like to say by the executive, but it is not.

Senator Tambling is right; just because the principles have been sorted out and deals have been done does not mean that we should be deprived of the right to debate the detail. It is irrelevant to the existence of that right and the maintenance of it, which we are going to exercise, that we are going to vote against all the amendments. We want the record to show that the problems with this bill were pointed out in the parliament and we want to show that, despite the fact they were pointed out in the parliament, this bunch of people took no notice whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —And still voted for it.
—And still voted for it. Senator Hill referred to a running sheet. I think he now understands that there are in fact two running sheets.
—Pages 1 to 10 and pages 11 to 13.

—Yes, exactly; there are additions. I acknowledge Senator Evans's interjection. He has acknowledged that a bit more has now come in. That is the only point I am making. We have this hand-written, tacky bit of paper. Millions of dollars of salaries are being paid in this place and we are legislating from a handwritten schedule that half the people cannot read and the government acknowledges that a few more pages have come in—fine. Has the government got any more out there? Why don't you wheel a truck in with the whole lot!

PARA.TAB: The simple point is: this bill deserves proper consideration. Mabo No. 2 should be dealt with thoroughly and properly by this parliament. We know from the beginning of the debate that this side—that is, the coalition—has a different view as to how Mabo No. 2 should be responded to, but we are entitled and obligated, as senators over there ought to be if the government's response is to be passed into legislation, to get it right the first time. The only reason we are not doing that is that there is self-acknowledgment around here that the gutless pack of wonders on the other side who get paid a salary to be parliamentarians would chicken out if anybody had any more time to consider this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no secret that the Greens wanted more consultation, time and community scrutiny before this legislation was dealt with. The opposition has to share some of the responsibility for the fact that there was a concern in the community, a concern that the government capitalised on, about the failure to deal with this legislation quickly, about a delay and about the effects of that debate.

PARA.TAB: I think the opposition must accept responsibility for the fact that it declared early on that it was not prepared to support a bill that would be the first in our history that actually attempted to give justice to Aboriginal people. The obstructionism and attitude of the opposition have generated concern within the broader community that this one opportunity to deal with this matter would pass by and that Aboriginal people again would be disappointed.

I received many requests from people within the Aboriginal community who would love to have been consulted, who would love to have had the opportunity to speak for their land. They had no confidence—I share their lack of confidence—in the parliamentary process and the community process to offer that to them. The committee offered that opportunity and the committee had the opportunity of looking in a more fair way at the legislation. I believe that it failed to do that and there is no evidence that this legislation's being referred to a committee for a longer time would actually improve the chances for justice that Aboriginal people have been hoping for.

I might add that many of the Aboriginal people who have contacted me are hoping that this legislation will not be passed because they are not confident that it, in itself, will offer any protection or justice for them.

The Greens want to make very clear what we think about this bill. We believe that this bill is not about justice for Aboriginal people. It is about resource security for the mining and pastoral industries and very little else. Pat O'Shane said to me just today that this is not about Aboriginals' rights but about other people's rights, and nothing else.

I believe that the opposition is posturing when it opposes this bill because, in fact, there is much in this bill that it has nothing to worry about. However, it may not gain votes from that. I believe that we have to step away from a party political view of what we are discussing today. I believe there are flaws here. I believe there is a need for all parties within this chamber to share their different perspectives but to do it with a respect for what we are actually discussing.

It concerns me that there are three very different views reflected here. The first is the opposition position. I believe the opposition, in its requests for delay and for more consultation, needs to look at its own record because it is not admitting the need to redress the injustices of 200 years. It is actually presenting the view that it is unjust to positively discriminate in favour of Aboriginal people at this point in history.

The second position is the Labor Party position. I do not agree with that position either. It is a fear of fully dealing with the historical injustice that Aboriginal people have suffered because of the anxiety, the consequences on the country and a desire to placate everyone, including some Aboriginal interests, but with far too much emphasis on economic certainty, on mining and pastoral concerns and state involvement.

While the Democrats and the Greens share a common concern that something be brought out of this legislation that will be for the benefit of Aboriginal people, certainly the Greens' concern is that it will be held back from being simply a composite meld of the various competing interests being satisfied. The Greens' position is that we have to acknowledge the truth of the historical injustice. Until we acknowledge it, then no healing or reconciliation is possible. If this legislation fails to at least protect existing native title rights, based on the High Court's decision, it is unacceptable to the Greens.

The committee stage of the Native Title Bill, as we perceive it, is the chance the Greens have of trying to extract some justice for Aboriginal people from a bill that gives less than the Mabo High Court decision. If we cannot, the legislation will not gain our support.

I remind the Senate that the people who will suffer if this bill does not go through are those, some of whom are in the gallery, who are waiting on the response of this parliament to the injustice of 200 years. They are the ones who will suffer if they do not get this legislation. If this bill does go through, there are other people in the Aboriginal community in Western Australia who will also suffer because this bill is not meeting the needs of those who are totally dispossessed, who do not gain from the High Court's decision.

I believe it is this parliament's responsibility to try to address this debate in the most respectful and dignified way possible so that the best legislation possible can be achieved, despite the fact that we have been rushed and despite the fact that it should have been done in a far different way with a better process of consultation and community scrutiny. But we all have to take responsibility for the part we take in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to draw Senator Vanstone's attention to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of 9 December in which 35 Democrat amendments were published. If that does not show the thrust of our amendments, I do not know what does.

PARA.TAB: I am not aware that Senator Vanstone, Senator Alston or anybody else has approached us to consult on those amendments. No-one has asked any questions about whether any of these amendments fall in line with what the opposition wants or not, but they have been on the table. Senator Vanstone could have read them if she had wished, if she had taken an interest.

The only answer we got is that the opposition is going to vote against everything. So where is the opposition's consultation? Where is its attempt to approach this in a constructive way? I do not believe those in the opposition really have an answer to that because they have positively ignored it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is it?

—The report is published. The report is available to everyone. It was available to Senator Vanstone; she was a member of the committee so she has seen it. In that committee report the Democrats were not able to say to the government, `We will accede to your wish that the bill should be passed as it stands'. We believe that there need to be amendments to make certain that this bill becomes the basis of a just relationship between Aboriginal people and the rest of the community. We will pursue that end even if the opposition chooses to ignore it.

PARA.TAB: I believe that we need to make sure that this is done speedily and that we do not wait a little bit longer, as a member of the coalition said under his breath just a few minutes ago. I think Aboriginal people have waited long enough for justice. We should get on with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The hypocrisy of the way in which the government is dealing with the Native Title Bill is probably the most important issue that we should be addressing here. This is a bill that has 238 clauses. As at my count last night, we were being asked to consider 196 amendments by the government, the Greens and the Democrats—196 amendments to 238 clauses. Something should be telling us, statistically, that the proponents of the legislation have got it dreadfully wrong.

PARA.TAB: We have seen another raft of amendments hit the deck today. In fact, I just got two more that Senator Gareth Evans did not even refer to in his opening or earlier comments. We have to have the time to have them properly canvassed and properly considered.

Senator Chamarette referred to the fact that a number of Aboriginal people have been around Parliament House this week making representations. I would ask her to explain how many came to her with differing viewpoints and considerations. Of course, there were many of them. I acknowledge that 50 or 100 of them have been in the House just about every day this week, talking to people all around the building. But what about the other 260,000 Aboriginal people in the community for whom we have a responsibility to get this legislation right?

This legislation is terribly important. This afternoon—or this evening, or tomorrow, or the next day—I specifically want to speak to 14 issues that I have identified as having a very major impact on the Aboriginal constituents of the Northern Territory, whom I represent, as well as, of course, the Northern Territory government's interests on behalf of the entire Northern Territory community and on behalf of all of the industry that makes the economy of the Northern Territory work.

The purpose of the legislation should be to treat all Australians, including Aboriginal Australians, under a just and fair land administration system. Yes, there is a serious debate of philosophy in this legislation. There is nothing wrong with that. I want that debate to happen in here, on the Hansard record, not—in Senator Kernot's words—out the back of the dunny somewhere, where a deal in that area has been done. We do not do deals in that way. We want the constitutional debate. I want to test a number of the Green amendments. There is a Green amendment proposed that will destroy the national park system of the Northern Territory. I want to test the Greens on that, fundamentally because of their Green credentials. I appreciate that they are representing an Aboriginal constituency viewpoint, but on the other side they are completely changing and altering the national park system.

There is a tribunal process proposed in this legislation which makes a complete mockery of the normal legal processes of Australia. What is going to happen in a year's time or five years time when I have to front Aboriginal people throughout Australia and say, `The reason you're not getting a decent system of native title in Australia is that it's caught up in the High Court in appeal after appeal after appeal', because of the way in which the legislation will get caught up in those legal areas?

There are enormous economic implications for the country in this legislation. They need to be tested and teased out and put on the table and properly acquitted by this government on behalf of the Aboriginal people. I want to know that there is certainty to back up the commitment to Aboriginal Australians. In dealing with these 238 clauses and, now, about 258 amendments, I want to know that those economic issues have been addressed. What about the creation of the new land acquisition fund, which is going to have phenomenal consequences for Aboriginal people and other Australians all around the country? The implications of purchase in this area are important.

Similarly, I am sure all honourable senators know the importance in the Northern Territory of the role of native title and its consistency with the Aboriginal Land Rights Act that is already in the place of legislation of this parliament. This particular legislation highlights and creates dramatic inconsistencies that will tear that system apart. The bill will bring in changes that do not make it equal for all people in the community, and they certainly do not make it equal for all Aboriginal Australians in that particular area.

I do not feel that I will have adequate time in this debate to specifically address the 14 areas that I want to, given the constitutional issues of Senator Vanstone, or the financial interests of Senator Short, or the social issues of some of the others; or the Western Australian issues that have to be tested by the Western Australian senators, or, for that matter, the issues that should and properly ought to be addressed by Senator Reynolds and Senator Chris Evans, who have taken very strong and fundamental viewpoints that are totally opposed to mine. Those contributions must be on the record of legislation as important as this. In order to look in detail at those issues, we cannot give this legislation a flippant 24-hour debate. That is an insult to this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —A disgrace!

—It is an absolute disgrace, as Senator Vanstone properly points out. There are investment interests in one particular clause that affect the McArthur River mine in the Northern Territory. There are provisions in this legislation that could affect the viability of the jobs and the benefits that will flow to Aboriginal territorians, and that could end up causing major problems in all of those areas.

PARA.TAB: The capacity of the states and the territories to confirm their ownership and control of resources is a fundamental issue that recurs time and time again in many of the clauses of the legislation and in many of the amendments. If we get them wrong, we are damning Aboriginal people to subservience and dependence far greater than any crime of past governments in Australia.

I do not want to get it wrong. I do not want to just force this through here and have Aboriginal people being mendicants at the High Court for the next five or 10 years. What do the Greens and the Democrats really think they are going to achieve by cuddling up to the government for 12 or 24 hours and then going off and enjoying Christmas? They will be damned forever by many Aboriginal Australians. That will be one of the serious consequences.

This legislation is vitally important for all Australians. What is wrong with a good controversial debate on it? Nothing. Because some people think that there is a little fragile consensus here that is going to go missing, they are just doing nothing. As I said before—and I heard Senator Kernot take offence, but tough luck—they are prostituting their principles completely. They are completely putting at risk the issues that I feel very passionately about for Aboriginal people. I notice that Senator Spindler is on his feet; he obviously has a problem with my language.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I believe the expression that was used by Senator Tambling has been ruled unparliamentary in the past. I ask you to ask him to withdraw it.
—Order! I heard what Senator Tambling said. I must say that it did jar. Senator Tambling, it might be appropriate if you would consider withdrawing it.

—I withdraw that remark, but it does not make me resile one bit from my criticism of the people who today attempt to stick this thing like a concertinaed piano accordion into a bit of cobbled-up legislation. It goes against all of the issues of human rights of all Australians. It completely mucks up the Australian economy. It will have so many effects on all of the very important fundamental issues. It is as important as a constitutional debate. We should be treating it that way, not walking around in here in a 24-hour, all night sitting, when we have to get down to each of these clauses.

PARA.TAB: I put Senator Gareth Evans on notice: the 14 clauses that I specifically want to address will not be addressed in under a quarter of an hour. They demand and need that sort of attention. On this side of the chamber there are 36 senators who have an equal share in the issues, and they want as much time on behalf of their constituencies as I do on behalf of mine. I am appalled that the Democrats and the Greens would appear at this stage to be wanting to just roll over and perhaps do deals and cobble up these agenda sheets, which we did not see until we got in here—as we had not seen the additional amendments, which demand extra and special attention.

If we do not get this legislation right, it will be an absolute travesty of justice that will impact on Aboriginal people. I do not care what the vote is at the end of the 24 hours, or the two weeks, or the two days, or the two months. It seems that Senator Kernot and Senator Chamarette are pre-occupied with what the outcome of the vote might be at the end of the night. It is not the outcome of that vote that is the most important one; it is the outcome of this legislation when it has been properly considered. If any senators take it upon themselves to prejudge by guillotining, or cutting short, or in any way thwarting and frustrating the good and proper debate on each and every issue in this legislation, they are walking away from every constituent that they seek to, or should ever, represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the comments of my colleagues. I wonder what we are so scared of. Why are we scared of giving the people a chance to have their say on this bill? I listened to Senator Chamarette, and I listened to Senator Kernot and Senator Spindler. The impression I got was that somehow it is something to be feared to consult with the Australian people more widely to get their views and to get their thoughts. Senator Chamarette said that the Australian people were concerned about the approach of the Liberal and National parties on this issue. That is not what I have heard. I think she is totally wrong, but she may be right. That is an issue which I believe should be tested.

PARA.TAB: It is a great pity that Senator Kernot dropped that great slogan of Don Chipp's to `keep the bastards honest', because this is a classic occasion when the parliament should operate. This is an immensely complex bill which has huge consequences for the future of this nation. This is the occasion to consult widely with the people—not just a group of people who may be Senator Kernot's supporters or Senator Chamarette's supporters—to get their views and to try to bring the community with us.

I would like Senator Kernot or Senator Spindler to stand up and say whether they have agreed with the government to guillotine this bill through the parliament.
