It would be very handy to find out what is the full nature of the deal that has been struck. Senator Kernot has the chance to get up and make a comment on that. The founders of the Australian Democrats felt that they could trust the people; they were here to operate on behalf of the people to keep this parliament honest. The Democrats have now joined forces with the power blocks in this country in order to ram this particular bill through the parliament.

There is a final great irony in this matter. Senator Evans, who has been so keen to open up the scrutiny of the Australian legal system to UN committees, who has fought hard to do that, and who has overturned the philosophy of the Australia Act, does not want those very laws to be properly scrutinised and debated in this parliament. It is a great pity that the smaller parties are taking this approach to this particular issue. I am not afraid of what our people think. I am not afraid to get out and consult widely with them—with all people. Maybe at the end of a proper process of consultation we can reach agreement on a bill that has some chance of standing up and some chance of bringing our people with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak now, but I have been provoked. I was provoked by what I consider to be gross hypocrisy by a number of honourable senators. On 28 September, Senator Chamarette gave notice of her intention to move a motion. I thought that it was a genuine indication of what Senator Chamarette wanted to do in relation to this legislation. I do not know Senator Chamarette as well as I perhaps should but, having got to know her over a few years, I am sure that she is very genuine on these issues. On 28 September, Senator Chamarette said:

SPEECH.PARA: I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (contingent on the Senate, on any day, agreeing to the first reading of any bill whose purpose is to implement the principles of the decision of the High Court decision on the Mabo case)—That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion that the Senate invite a delegation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander representatives from around Australia to be the first people to appear before the Bar of the Senate in this Parliament House, to address the Senate in relation to the implications of that bill for the indigenous people of Australia, at a time and day, before the bill is read a second time, to be arranged by the President, and in accordance with procedures to assist the delegation, to be provided in the resolution of invitation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am quite sure that Senator Chamarette's intention was to have a very serious consultation and to include the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—all of them, not just the ones who head these organisations and who are part of the negotiating committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —All of them?
—Yes, all of them.
—There are about 200,000 of them.

—There are actually 260,000. Senator Collins is so bright on these issues. He knows everything, does he not? The saddest thing about what has occurred, particularly in Senator Chamarette's and Senator Margett's decision not to allow the democratic processes of Australia to take place by having a detailed committee hearing into this most complicated and crucial legislation for Australia, is that there are thousands upon thousands of Aboriginal Australians whose views will not be heard. We know that when Senator Kernot goes and does her deals late at night with the Labor Party on this bill, negotiating her amendments—government amendments which were sent around hour by hour today—
—Another one just arrived.

—There is another one. When Senator Kernot does those deals, those people get excluded from the democratic process. There are thousands upon thousands of Aboriginal people who feel very strongly about this issue. Senator Chamarette knows it, Senator Kernot knows it, we all know it. There are thousands upon thousands of other Australians with all sorts of interests, as well as normal other Australians who have a quarter acre block in the back blocks of capital cities who worry about it as well. We know better, do we not, Senator Kernot? We know that we can go around to a minister's office and negotiate a deal, cut a deal. You are meant to be the politician who does not like all these nasty—
—Senator Campbell, would you direct your remarks through the chair.

—I was looking at Senator Kernot, but I was thinking of you. Senator Kernot goes on television; she is the Noelene Donaher of the Senate, looking like the lady next door—the family woman on the verandah of her house in Queensland. She is the lovable Noelene Donaher of the Senate who does not like the nasty politicians, the nasty males—Paul Keating and Dr John Hewson—who yell at each other all the time. It is a sort of reverse sexism that offends me. Senator Kernot is the one who wants to make politics all nice. She makes it nice by going around and doing little deals, and excluding people from the democratic process. The Australian Democrats were founded on the principle of including people in the political process.
—And you were part of that, weren't you?

—That is right. I was a great supporter of the Democrats when Senator Chipp first founded them, because it appealed to my sentiments that we could include Australians in the democratic process by having ballots and ensuring that we consulted them. Here we have a crucial piece of legislation. The Democrats and the Greens are ensuring that Australians citizens are excluded. The reason they put forward is to ensure that this legislation gets put through quickly before Christmas.
—Rubbish! I will stay here as long as you like to debate this.

—Senator Kernot says she does not want to get it through before Christmas. The opposition wants wide consultation on this matter. The Democrats and the Greens have said that the coalition wants to delay this bill so we can have this racist campaign and build up racial hatred in Australia and see the legislation fall over. That is offensive.
—Five seconds ago you said that people's backyards were at risk. You are one of the people putting people at risk.
—I did not say anything of the kind.
—You said people's backyards were at risk.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. That is a direct reflection on something that Senator Campbell did not say and I request that it be withdrawn.

—It is not a point of order. It might be a debating point. I have allowed a sense of emotion to emerge in this debate thus far, but it would be helpful if we allowed the speakers to be heard in relative silence.

—I am quite happy to debate it. It is an emotional issue and I know that Senator Margetts feels very strongly about it. I ask her to check the Hansard. As soon as I get the pink I will deliver it to her office and I will show it to her. I never said that backyards are as risk. I referred to thousands of Aboriginals who would like to be included in the democratic process of creating a piece of legislation to deal with Mabo. I said that there are thousands of people involved, such as people in the mining industry and the farming industry, and I also made a reference to typical, average Australians living on a quarter acre block. I referred to the typical, average Australian—if there is any such thing any more. There are not any quarter acre blocks any more; they are usually 600 square metres. I did not say those backyards were at risk. If I sought to imply it, I am very sorry. That is not my implication.

PARA.TAB: The nub of what we are talking about here is how Senator Margetts, her party colleague, Senator Chamarette, and the Australian Democrats have excluded the Australian citizens from a crucial involvement in the democratic process to create this piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you say that?
—Senator Kernot has done it with the help of Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts by ensuring that this bill has to be put through before Christmas.

PARA.TAB: We know that this bill is an absolute mess. Senator Gareth Evans came in here with this scribble pad of a running sheet. He was not even sure whether all the amendments were on it. He could not assure you, Mr Chairman, that all the amendments were on it. We now know that they are not, because more are coming in. We basically have to make up this legislation on the run.

The people of Australia have not been consulted about each of the amendments. I am sure that the minister, the Democrats and the Greens have consulted with people from the mining industry, the NFF and the Aboriginal community, but that excludes thousands upon thousands of people who should have a say in this.

By excluding those people, Senator Kernot has absolutely left behind her any claim to being an Australian Democrat in the original sense of the name `Democrat', which was the intention of former senator Don Chipp and the founding fathers of the Australian Democrats. The Democrats cannot go on television saying that they want to include people in the democratic process and consult people when all they have done by their votes in this chamber—Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts have also done this—is exclude people from being consulted.

Senator Chamarette was unable to tell us how she will vote on this bill. I am sure that she will take an active interest in the debate during the committee stage. She has not been able to tell us what she will do with the bill. She has said that if the bill goes through, it will hurt Aboriginal people and that if it does not, it will hurt Aboriginal people. She has also said that she will be looking at the amendments. She gave us no clue as to what she will do. It would be good if Senator Chamarette were able to tell the Senate that, if certain amendments are not put into place or are not agreed to, she will vote against the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would have done a deal if we said that.

—No. They would not be doing a deal; they would be giving the Senate an indication of where they stand. But it does not matter. We will find out where the Greens stand at the end of the two or three days we spend debating this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I predict that the Greens will vote for this legislation. They will do what they did with the wine tax legislation. They will run around all over the country saying, `We will make up our minds. We will look at the amendments and the legislation'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four days of publicity and then cave in.

—And get four days of publicity or a week's publicity. They will become the centre of attraction. All of a sudden, they will call a press conference and say, `These are all the reasons we were going to vote against the legislation, but, in the end, it was better to let it through'. That is what they did on the wine tax and the Senate select committee and we all know that that is what they will do on this bill.

PARA.TAB: One can only cry wolf so many times. In the end, the media people will ignore the Greens. They will not even ask them what they will do on this. The Premier of Western Australia has called the Greens slow socialists. They are socialist. They always vote with the Labor Party when it counts, although it takes a few days for them to make a decision.

I guess that there is an incentive to do that because the media people—our friends in the gallery on the second floor—will shine the spotlights on them and make them the centre of political attention for a few days while they make up their minds. But the media will lose interest because, in the end, the Greens always vote with the Labor Party when it counts. They did it on the wine tax and the select committee, and they will do it on this bill.

It will be a very sad day when a piece of legislation that fundamentally alters the human rights of so many Australians is passed. The saddest thing about this legislation is that it will be very bad for Aboriginal people. It will create unprecedented racial division right throughout this nation. It will not help the welfare, opportunities or prospects of Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Point to the clause that will do that.
—We will go through this clause by clause and point these things out all the way through. You have reminded me of one thing you said which provoked me to speak and which I thought was most unfair.
—Senator Campbell, address your remarks through the chair.
—I am sorry, Mr Chairman; I will.
—Why don't we start talking about it clause by clause?

—We will. One of Senator Kernot's comments in her contribution was that the opposition has made a commitment to oppose all these amendments and clauses; that is dead right. She then said that, because we are opposing it, we are not interested in it. That is the most illogical and stupid thing that I have heard her say all day—and that is not really saying very much.

PARA.TAB: Mr Chairman, you know that the coalition is deeply interested in this legislation. Western Australians are deeply interested in it because of what it will do to our state. We are very concerned about what it will do to Aboriginal Western Australians. We are very concerned, as Senator Chamarette said she was concerned, that Aboriginal Western Australians have not had proper consultation on this. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs went around the country. It popped into Perth for about 10 hours of hearings and really had to rush everyone through.

This legislation requires the most thorough consultation of any piece of legislation in this place. It fundamentally affects so many areas of Australia. It fundamentally affects the welfare of Aboriginal people, their prospects and the whole way that they will be a part of Australia for generations and generations to come.

As Senator Vanstone said quite properly, if this legislation is so good, it will stand up to scrutiny. We have 250 amendments before the chamber. If we waited another month, one wonders whether we would have another 250 amendments. Why do we not do it properly? Why do we not use a sensible process to deal with this legislation? We should deal with it through a proper select committee where amendments can be dealt with sensibly and practically and in an ordered way.

But we do not want to do that. We want to rush it through this chamber. We want to come back with Native Title Amendment Bill (No. 1) on 2 February 1994, Native Title Amendment Bill (No. 2) in March 1994, Native Title Amendment Bill (No. 3) in April 1994 and then go to the High Court and pay the lawyers hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars to fight over the constitutionality of this all because the Democrats, the Greens and the Labor Party want to rush this legislation through before Christmas and exclude Australians from having their say. Basically, they will make a farce of the democratic system.

The Australian Democrats should no longer call themselves Democrats. They are totally undemocratic. They are an affront to the democracy in this nation. On any occasion they have a chance to consult people, they stop those people from being consulted. I look forward to taking part in the debate in this committee stage and pointing out to the Australian people how this unworkable legislation will destroy the hopes and aspirations of so many black and white Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself in a situation that is probably different from the situation of anybody else in this chamber or any of their expressions of opinion in this first commentary on clause 1 of the Native Title Bill in the committee stage. We are all at one in one aspect: we all acknowledge that this legislation involves deep questions of social justice, equity and certainty before the law. It is the parliament's duty to address these questions against the need, in my view, for reconciliation and healing amongst all peoples of this country. It is also the parliament's duty to do so in the best interests of all Australians in a manner which does not do irreparable harm to the federal compact upon which the constitution is based.

PARA.TAB: As we all know, there are a number of possible responses to Mabo No. 2. There is the response that we in this federal parliament do nothing. For example, each claim would go to the courts. Surely that response would fail against some of the principles that I have mentioned, not the least of which is certainty before the law. It should be remembered that Mabo No. 2 was not a unanimous decision.

The other response is that the matter should be left to the state parliaments. That, too, would fail on equity grounds and probably on certainty before the law grounds because we could well end up with six different statutes dealing with the questions in six different ways. I have always been of the view that land management issues are essentially state issues. I acknowledge that. But we have to look at the other principles and when we consider the other principles we must remember the 1967 amendments to the constitution which were deliberately made to enable the federal parliament to deal with these questions in special circumstances. I believe this is a special circumstance.

In my view, federal legislation which satisfies the requirements of justice, equity and certainty before the law is necessary. As I indicated before, this needs to be done in the spirit of unity which does not appear to be evident at the moment. I wanted to see this resolved before Christmas and that is one of the reasons I took the action I did three weeks ago. I believed that no good purpose would be served by the matter going to a Senate select committee. As we all know, the legislation did go to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That committee reported to the Senate on 9 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —It went to the committee for only one week, for a limited consideration.

—I understand that. The opposition must acknowledge that there should not be one senator in this place who does not understand the issues involved in Mabo No. 2. Not one of us should stand up and say that he or she does not fully understand the issues involved.
—We don't understand the amendments.
—That is one of the issues that I wanted to address. I have not been involved in any of the toing and froing in relation to this legislation.
—They reckon they didn't need you, Brian.
—That may be so. I would like to politely challenge what Senator Kernot said about the opposition. She said, `You have decided to vote against it.'
—They have decided not to be part of the process.
—She said, `Why do you need to be involved in the Committee of the Whole?'
—No.

—That is how it came across to me. I voted for the second reading of the bill so that the legislation could go into the committee of the whole for the very purpose of examining it. It is fair to say that even though the opposition voted against the second reading of the bill, every member of the opposition has the responsibility to ensure that the legislation is properly explained to the chamber. Each and every one of the amendments should be properly explained to chamber—especially if the legislation is likely to end up in the High Court. I assume Their Honours might like to read the debate that took place in the committee of the whole.
—Probably not.
—They may do. They could well use this debate as an aid to the interpretation of the law which will be passed by this chamber. We have processes to ensure that that occurs.
—And that takes time.

—That does take time. One of those processes is the Committee of the Whole. I have noted what the Australian Democrats have said about their amendments. Some of the Democrats' amendments were contained in a statement by Senator Spindler in the report. I have received the Greens amendments. They need to be considered.
—Two weeks ago.

—That is what I said. I think this report came down on 9 December. I received the Greens' amendments yesterday and I have received the government's amendments. I am not going to be in the position of truncating the debate in the committee stage. If it is necessary to sit tomorrow, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday then we ought to sit on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. I am not saying that this is the most important bill to come before this chamber, but it is a very important bill. To truncate the Committee of the Whole debate on this important bill would mean that the Senate is not discharging its obligation to review the legislation.

PARA.TAB: We can ask questions of the minister because we are in the committee of the whole. I want to ask the minister about the government's proposed amendments. I have a number of proposed government amendments and one of them is headed `government 14A'. Is that still a proposed government amendment? I want to be very clear about this. I am told that it is out. When was it taken out? That proposed amendment was in as far as I understood.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed amendment 14A has not been circulated in this chamber. It was circulated to party leaders inadvertently earlier today. It was in a form that needed some more attention. A large number of amendments have been the subject of attention. At one stage it was thought that we might pursue a modification. All that involves is the addition of one subclause to amendment 14 in the main set of amendments. The drafting difficulties that are associated with that subclause are such, in our judgment, that it is not able to be sensibly pursued. I have not circulated it in the chamber. Proposed amendment 14A has no status. There is a reference to it on the running sheet but it will not be pursued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that we did not start the committee stage debate this evening on a better note. Senator Gareth Evans came in the other day and inflamed the situation by using the jackboot approach. He did it again today.
—Oh.

—You did! As Senator Gareth Evans struts the world stage, I hope he conducts himself in a better manner than he does in this chamber. He has inflamed the situation and got everyone going. We could have been through six or seven clauses by now.
—How did I inflame it?
—The minister inflamed the situation. The minister knows he did. It is the minister's fault. Then he went on to say that we have to finish this by midnight simply because of transport requirements.
—I said if we approached it in a dignified and sensible fashion we would do it by midnight. If that is going to be impossible, so be it.
—The minister used the same tone of voice that he is now using.
—So be it.

—Yes, so be it. No minister has ever been around the world as much as this minister has. Yet he uses transport as an excuse for our not getting out of here on time. At the beginning of the week, I booked myself on a plane on Sunday because I could see that we would still be here on Sunday. Anyone else could have done the same. The minister's excuse of transport is a weak one. I will not delay the chamber for very long because we have a long night ahead of us.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats said, `Opposition members have decided to vote against it, so why should we listen to them?'. We will explain why we decided to vote against it. What Senator Kernot says is irrelevant because we know where she gets her riding instructions from—she gets them every time from ATSIC and from Lois O'Donoghue, and also from the government. If Senator Kernot wants to challenge me on that, she can get up and do so and I will explain why I made such a statement. We know where Senator Kernot's instructions come from.

People around here are wringing their hands, displaying public guilt and getting infuriated in the build-up to a crescendo in this debate. I would like to know how much those people have done for Aborigines. How many of them have an Aboriginal on their staff? How many have employed one in the past? How many have had one sitting at their dinner table? How many employed Aboriginals as long as 30 years ago when it was not quite the politically correct thing to do? Those opposite are very silent.

I turn to the Greens. The Greens gave us the reasons why we should have a Senate select committee, but then they did not want one. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs gave some of the reasons for not having a select committee. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee rejects the suggestion that the reference of the Bill to a Senate Select Committee will better settle the competing claims for title or in any way improve the effect of the Bill.

The committee rejects that suggestion. What is it frightened of finding out? Why does the committee say that this would not improve the bill? A Senate select committee would find out all sides of the story—not just one side, as was the case with the inquiry of the standing committee which lasted for three days. The standing committee used a lot of the evidence that was given by former senator Fred Chaney. I remind those opposite that when former senator Fred Chaney was here, no-one on that side ever took notice of what he said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Senator Collins can say `Rubbish'. But now, all of a sudden, he is being used as an authority. In evidence, Fred Chaney said:

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose my chief concern as an ex-member of the Senate is that I do not want the Senate Committee system used as a Trojan Horse for prejudice . . .
The government, the Democrats and the Greens really picked that one up. The report states:
A Senate Select Committee if formed prior to Christmas would not, in reality, begin its inquiry prior to the second half of January.

Senator Gareth Evans's argument the other day was that no-one works in January. They were his words—not mine. But, as I told him, a lot of people work in January—for instance, the people who keep this country going by producing to earn export income. So what if we could not do it by the end of January. We have all the time on earth.

PARA.TAB: This is the most important legislation that has come before this parliament in a mighty long time. One of the reasons it is the most important legislation is its financial impact. As far as I can see, the minimal amount is about $6 million. It is the most open cheque legislation I have seen in this place. Yet we want to rush it through by midnight. We do not have time to refer the legislation to a Senate select committee or anything like that. The Greens and the Democrats are supporting this open-ended chequebook situation.
Let us look at the next reason for our not having a Senate select committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not listening to Senator Kernot. She should go up to ATSIC and get her next instructions, as she usually does. If she wants me to put my evidence on the table, she should just say so. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Travel to outlying communities would be enormously difficult and extremely time consuming. The Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australia would be particularly difficult.
Western Australia supplies 25 per cent of Australia's export income, yet no-one wants to go into those areas where this wealth of Australia comes from. The report goes on to state:
A referral to the Senate Select Committee would result in a minimum delay of five or more months.

But we want to give someone a cheque that will be open, as far as I am concerned, for the next 100 years. Senator Collins is sitting there huffing and puffing, but these are the stupid reasons that have been given for not having a Senate select committee. The report states:
Mr Riley said that children were now being subjected to negative criticism and derisive comment and that his organisation had knowledge of instances of physical violence occurring.

In other words, we are getting on to the racist bit. I can tell honourable senators that I went down that path long ago. My children are still getting it. So the racist bit for an extra three months would make no difference whatsoever. For all of these reasons, the standing committee decided not to have a select committee. The report states:
The Committee was not persuaded that delay in the passage of the Bill would ultimately assist any group affected by the Mabo decision.

That is completely wrong. Miners, pastoralists and farmers are affected. I found out today, to my dismay, that fishermen are affected too. No-one wants to listen to them. So it is a lie for this report to say that a delay in the passage of the bill would not assist any group that is affected by Mabo. Are not fishermen, farmers, miners and pastoralists affected by Mabo? This report does not think so.

PARA.TAB: Having all of those reasons in front of them—and Senator Chamarette has spelt them out—the Greens decided not to support the establishment of a select committee. I suppose they could rethink their situation; it is not too late. We will live to rue the day if we rush this open cheque legislation through, as the minister wants us to because he is worried about transport—he is probably going overseas tomorrow or something like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be brief; nonetheless, I believe they should be placed on the record. Firstly, I direct my criticism to the government and the responsible minister, Senator Gareth Evans. I see that on the running sheet there is a new clause 6A. I have yet to see a copy of that. An announcement was made nearly two hours ago that we would see a copy of it, but we have yet to see it. Senator Gareth Evans might tell us how long we will have to wait before we see that.
—About five minutes, I believe.

—That is an entirely unsatisfactory situation. I remind the chamber that in any civil court this sort of behaviour would not be tolerated. If a person amended his pleadings or changed his case at the door of the court, he would get a tongue-lashing from the judge and there would be grounds for adjournment by the other side. I realise that Senator Gareth Evans has not practised law for some time, but I wish to place on record that it is entirely inappropriate for the government, with a bill as important as this, to be dropping amendments on the opposition at this late stage. We still do not have one of them.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Harradine correctly pointed out, the committee stage of this debate is very important. It is one which the High Court could well have regard to in any subsequent action. It is not a game; it is not a joke. It is very serious. We are here at great expense to the taxpayer. We are here to do a job, and that job is to make sure that the legislation is debated properly and that all aspects of it are aired adequately.

I am only new here and some of the old hands might think this is a good trick. It might be established practice, but I am telling those senators that it is not on. It is not good practice and it is something which the people of Australia should not accept. I want to place on record my disgust at the way the government has handled that aspect of it.

I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I was in a privileged position to travel across this country and hear the very many views that were put forward. I can say to the chamber that, as I previously stated, I believe it was done in a thoroughly civilised fashion. I do not in any way believe that a deferral of this matter to a select committee would engender any further division in the community. I reject that view and I wish to place that comment on record as well.

I believe that this bill has many flaws. I believe that it has not been given adequate time to be drafted properly. In no way do I criticise the draftsmen because I believe that their instructions were vague and deficient. I also believe that they did not have sufficient time to put it together. So, to that extent, I say that in the time allotted they could not come up with a piece of workable legislation. Some time ago the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was reported in the Australian as saying that the legislation had `long, clean lines of logic'. I fail to see where these long clean lines of logic are.

If this matter had not been referred to a Senate standing committee—and I concur with Senator Spindler, because I believe he was party to that as well—we would not have these 74 government amendments. Do honourable senators know why? When the government read the report of the committee it realised the problems with the bill. Until then it thought it was hunky dory; it thought it was fine. After due inquiry, it saw its flaws. I say to Senator Evans that, if people had been properly consulted and due consideration had been given to this legislation, the government would find a good many more flaws.

I believe that the government has a responsibility to the Australian people to draft efficient and competent legislation. I see that Senator Evans is leaving the chamber. Perhaps he does not like what I am saying. Nonetheless, it is true and I wish to place those comments on record. I think this whole process on the part of the government has been shabby.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a few comments at this stage of the debate. I do so as a Western Australian senator with a lot of concern about the final outcome of this legislation for Western Australia. I am particularly concerned to see that, at the end of the day, we end up with a system in Western Australia that gives justice and fairness to all. I do not believe this legislation will do that. More than that, I believe it will lead to long, drawn-out constitutional challenges to its validity.

PARA.TAB: Once again, as I have done on a number of other occasions and as I did in the debate on the industrial relations legislation the other night, I want to say that I think there has been a dangerous consistency of events. More and more legislation is being put through this parliament that we all know when we vote on it will end up in the High Court. I think that is a reflection on the parliamentary process. It is a reflection on the integrity of the people who operate here. I want to put that on the public record and I want to put it to the government, the Green senators and the Democrats that they need to look very, very carefully to make sure that, as these processes go through, we do not consistently pass key legislation that ends up in the High Court.

I want to voice my concern about the butchery of the democratic process which is occurring here. I think it is quite tragic. Of course, the victims of this process are justice, equity and fairness. When we finish this debate, whether it is at midnight or whether it is Saturday or Sunday or Monday or whenever it might be, I believe that we will end up with legislation—because I think at the end of the day the Greens will fall over and vote with the government—which does not meet those objectives. I also want to put that on the public record. I do not think it is in the best interests of this chamber to pass legislation in that manner.

I found it regrettable that Senator Kernot should insinuate in her comments that, because we said we were going to oppose all the amendments to this legislation, in some funny way we have given away our rights to actually debate it. I believe that was the core of what she was saying. I cannot believe that any senator could actually say that. There are many pieces of legislation that come into this place which we do not seek to amend. But that in no way takes away any of the rights of individual senators to question any clause in any bill, particularly a bill of this nature. I think that we have the right—and we should use it—to go through each bill clause by clause and get from the government on the table what its intentions are and what the actual clauses mean in plain, explained English, and I want to emphasise that—plain, explained English.

Senator Harradine said that we should all be across all the issues. I doubt whether there is anybody in this place who is across all the issues of the Mabo decision. Let us look at the judges' decision. Three of the judges, Justices Mason, Brennan and McHugh had one view; Justices Deane and Gaudron had a variation on that view; Mr Justice Toohey had another variation on the view; and Mr Justice Dawson had a significantly different view. I do not know how Senator Harradine could make that statement in respect of an issue like this one. What we have to do is respond as best we can.

We will be debating the bill clause by clause because we do not believe that it will serve the interests of Australia; we do not believe that it will serve the interests of all Aboriginals. That is a very, very difficult thing to do. It is not a simple thing to do. I have been trying to come to grips with the amendments that have been put before us at this late hour. It is not dissimilar to what happened with the industrial relations legislation. We suddenly had a huge number of amendments thrown at us and we had people running in circles trying to come to grips with those amendments. The same thing is going on here now. I think it is something like 200-odd amendments that we have before us. I think that is quite tragic for the democratic process of dealing with the amendments in a meaningful manner and getting down to the nitty gritty of them.

Once again I wish to raise the issue of fairness to the people who work in this place, who serve us. I want to relate that back to the industrial relations legislation that we dealt with the other night. People from that end of the chamber, from over where the Greens are and from that side of the chamber from time to time were yelling at us, `What about the worker; what about the employee?' It is now 6 o'clock. We have only recently received the amendments and we have the prospect of working all through tonight and all day tomorrow; we do not know. What about some fairness to the attendants who work in this place? What about some fairness to the staff who work in this place? What about some fairness to the dining room staff? I could list all the staff who work in this place.

I find it absolutely objectionable that we are here now dealing with this legislation. The staff have no idea when we will be adjourning. It is quite hypocritical for us, in dealing with one piece of legislation, to be talking about fairness and equity and how things ought to be handled in the workplace, yet virtually a couple of days later all that is thrown out the door because it happens to be convenient for some people to adopt a totally different position and a totally different strategy.

The final comment I want to make relates once again to Senator Kernot's comments when she referred to being out in the garden shed trying to stitch up a deal. We should not have something that is put together with superglue, a few bandaids, a bit of chewing gum—

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit of tie wire.

—A bit of tie wire, as Senator Panizza says—trying to facilitate a process because the government cannot come to an agreement and cannot get proper legislation. What we are going to end up with, as other speakers have said, is a hotchpotch of various things that, in fact, have been concessions. I want to know what other deals have been done in reaching that consensus—not with this legislation, but with some other legislation—and how they will affect our export industries. I will bet London to a brick that a few deals have been done around the place. I would like to know how they will affect our forest management and, in particular, the AHC-CALM agreement in Western Australia. I bet there has been a bit of a trade-off down the line somewhere on that.

PARA.TAB: This process goes on. It is not a proper process where we get good legislation in the end; it is a process where we have compromises down the track in various areas. At some stage during this debate I would like the government, the Democrats or the Greens to tell us what the trade-offs have been because I believe they will be detrimental to the long-term interests of Australia. In conclusion, I repeat what I said at the start: we are seeing the worst of the worst regarding the butchery of the democratic process and I totally reject the approach that has been taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I despair about the sheer pointlessness of it all. We are going to sit here for the next three days late at night going through this legislation, and all to no avail, I say to Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts, because the word is out that the government is already redrafting the Native Title Bill. Not even Senator Gareth Evans is that silly—he is a better lawyer than to think that this bill will ever get anywhere. He knows, as well as his advisers, that this bill is ruined. It is finished; it is gone; it is never going to work.

PARA.TAB: As we go through the next three days of agony late at night trying to stitch it up, Senator Gareth Evans knows as a lawyer that we cannot do these things on the run, make them fit in together, and have any semblance of sense when they come to be interpreted. One cannot do this sort of complicated drafting on the run. Senator Evans knows that. The whole exercise will be absolutely pointless. We will be back here in February or March doing it again. The word is out that people have already started to rewrite proper legislation that takes everything into account, so we are going to go through all of this for absolutely nothing. I think Senator Ellison was lucky enough to get the last amendments; I suspect that other people in the chamber have not seen them. That is the way this government is running the chamber, and it is all for nothing.

I ask Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette to mark my words. They and the group down in the corner will not be consulted next time because the government will do it in its own way and ignore them, and deal with other groups.

In conclusion, I want to take issue with my friend and colleague Senator Panizza. He was inviting people to argue with him that the Democrats get their running orders from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I disagree with Senator Panizza. It is fairly clear to me that the Democrats always get their running instructions from caucus. They are a part of the caucus. Why they do not just save their shoe leather and sit in there with caucus and vote on the decisions, I do not know. I am sure we could start the new ultra left faction for the Labor Party so that they can be in the caucus together. It would save a hell of a lot of time.

I do not accuse the Greens of the same. I suspect that, however misguided they are, they are genuine in their attempts to do something correct. But the Democrats have simply just turned into a faction of the Labor Party. They do whatever they are told to by Senator Gareth Evans and all the other people who gather around them every time a division is called to make sure that they remain on side. In that regard, I disagree with Senator Panizza.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a small contribution to the preamble to this committee stage. Before the dinner break I wondered why Senator Gareth Evans was looking so washed out by all this and so preoccupied with other things, perhaps we now know the reason why.

PARA.TAB: I ask Senator Evans to put himself in our position, and I am sure that he would be outraged. I know that in his heart of hearts he is very embarrassed because he knows that to start the committee stage of what is probably the most important legislation to come before this Senate in a decade at 4.30 p.m. on a non-sitting Friday is really outrageous. There are over 200 amendments, some of which—as he said, amendment 14(A)—were delivered to the leadership group about 15 minutes before the committee stage was about to begin. That is totally unacceptable.

Considering that we have had over 205 years without this Mabo legislation, the argument that it has to be passed in haste before Christmas is just not on. I really cannot see that, in the interests of good administration, another two or three months will make very much difference to the perception of whether or not the obligations of the government have been properly carried out. This legislation must be right and, as has been pointed out, there is a very fair chance that it will come back again and again. The people who have been looking at it are looking at it again right now.

We have heard a lot about consensus from this Labor government over the last 10 years. I think Senator Evans himself, or perhaps it was Mr Keating, said that this Mabo legislation was built upon a very fragile consensus. I was reminded the other day that somebody said, `You point out to me a politician who talks about consensus and I'll point out to you a fraud'. Government is not about consensus; it is about doing the right thing; it is about, taking a stand, having a vision and going for it, and doing the best you can. We are elected to this place to improve the prospects of our electorate, our state, and everybody in this country. We are not about enacting legislation that puts one group of Australians in front of, or in a different place to, another group of Australians. Unfortunately, this legislation does just that.

I have mentioned amendment 14(A) which, as Senator Evans said, was circulated to party leadership. A request was made of his office, and he very kindly said he would send somebody down to give us a briefing. The public servant from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet said that the legislation had been withdrawn. I guess this whole exercise is just not the way in which a sophisticated Western democracy should operate. I believe that all of us in this chamber should be condemned by the performance of the government. This legislation will not serve the interests of all Aboriginal Australians, and it will certainly not serve the interests of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some speakers have ascribed motives to the decision of the Democrats, Greens, government and Aboriginal groups to meet together. I want to put on the record that the point of our meetings was to assist the process—to sort out the areas of common concern; to remove the duplication; to sort out and discuss the sticking points; and to understand the differences that we had. There is nothing wrong or dishonest in making the choice to do that. In fact, I believe it was sensible and probably helpful because we have had the opportunity to improve wording, to tidy up loose ends, to understand the fine points of difference in the positions we hold; and we have had the opportunity to understand the substantive matters so that we can group the amendments in a logical and reasonable way. We will not need to debate 250 amendments, nor will we need to have 250 divisions. We are trying to find a cooperative way forward. I think the running sheet and the way we have chosen to do it is sensible and logical.

PARA.TAB: Much has been said about anticipated guillotines and all the usual threats that are made at this time of the year. The fact of the matter is that I will sit here for as long as it takes to get this legislation debated, for as long as we as a parliament choose to debate it. I am not seeking to obstruct the debate but, in order to deal with obstruction and the fear of giving indigenous Australians just a modicum of improvement in their basic rights, I do not mind whether I sit here right until Christmas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, I know that you want to explain the layout, but, in the light of the construction of the running sheet, you might seek leave to have the bill dealt with in the manner in which it is set out in the running sheet.

—Mr Chairman, I appreciate your assistance. I do seek leave for that course to be followed. I hope that, by now, people have had sufficient opportunity to understand the layout of the running sheet. I apologise for the possible illegibility of some of my handwriting—that is one of the more strenuous criticisms that have been advanced in the last two hours of debate.

PARA.TAB: The basic concept is to take the bill almost clause by clause on the way through, but there are a large number of clauses that do not attract amendments and hopefully we can jump over those pretty quickly. When we get to a particular subject matter for the first time in that sequential approach, it is then proposed that at the same time there be debated other clauses and amendments bearing upon that same subject matter. Thus, for example, when we get down to clause 4, that clause simply is a kind of index provision to the rest of the bill, but that is a useful first opportunity to address the question of financial assistance to states and to deal with the actual incorporation of the proposed new part 8A as a result. Another part of clause 4 is a trigger for consideration under this principle of the parliamentary joint committee.

Might I suggest that the debate for each one of these subject matters thus identified be a cognate one with all the relevant clauses and amendments grouped in this way being debated together. Equally, it will usually be possible, I suggest, for the amendments in question to be put together rather than individually. But, of course, if any senator seeks a particular amendment to be put separately or the issue to be broken up in some way, there is no difficulty at all about accommodating that, and that will occasionally be helpful. I hope that with that explanation we can proceed to consider it.

I quickly repeat for the benefit of those honourable senators I have not had a chance to talk to personally that, although quite a litter of paper has been distributed around the chamber, really only six or seven documents are relevant to the debate as it now stands. They are the three master sheets of amendments for the government, Democrats and Greens, respectively. Then there are just three supplementary government amendments, and that is the sheet that has in the top right-hand corner `Government 44A'.

So far as the Democrats are concerned, senators should find a couple of sheets of paper stapled together with `DEM 2A' written in the top right-hand corner with the Democrats' amendment No. 9A behind it. Then there is a separate sheet of paper also circulated with the Democrats' amendment No. 28A. So that, together with the Democrats' master sheet, constitutes the Democrat amendments.

So far as the Greens are concerned, in addition to the master sheet of amendments, there is just one stapled document labelled—again, in handwriting in the top right-hand corner—`GREEN 1A'. That represents the Greens' redrafted supplementary amendments as they stand at the moment. There will be just a handful of additional amendments about which discussion on drafting is still proceeding that may be circulated at a later stage, but we certainly have ample material before us to get a very long way into the bill.

If, at any stage, people want to defer consideration of a particular clause, perhaps to enable some further discussion of it or for whatever reason, I see no particular difficulty in accommodating that, although I think it ought to be possible on the way through to follow the sequence that is set out in the master sheet.

I formally table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments, at least those that are in the government master sheet of amendments. This document was circulated a couple of days ago, but I formally table it in accordance with process. Perhaps we can then move on to consideration of the preamble and government amendment No. 1.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Does the procedure set out in the running sheets attract the approval of the chamber?

—We are certainly willing to cooperate in expediting the process as much as is reasonably possible, given that there are a large number of clauses that individual senators will have particular interest in. We have tried to concentrate our focus by ensuring that there are people who have particularly addressed certain clauses. We think the running sheet is a very useful approach. We understand the minister's willingness to ensure that each and every clause is taken separately, if that is necessary, but the groupings that are set out in that running sheet do strike us as reasonable at this stage and we would be happy to work to them.
—There being no objection, that course will be followed.

PARA.TAB: Preamble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Preamble, page 3, after line 18, insert the following:

PARA.TAB: "Governments should, where appropriate, facilitate negotiation on a regional basis between the parties concerned in relation to:

TAB.TAB: (a)claims to land, or aspirations in relation to land, by Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders; and
(b)proposals for the use of such land for economic purposes.".

SPEECH.PARA: I will not speak to the language of the preamble generally; I think it speaks for itself. We all understand these days the role that preambles have in legislation as an interpretive tool for the courts and as a useful way of expressing the intended scope of legislation.

PARA.TAB: I have moved just one amendment to the preamble—government amendment No. 1—and it relates to the question of the desirability of there being regional agreements. The government has received a number of representations about this. Most have suggested that there be greater detail about such agreements set out in the bill itself. We have taken the view that the concept of such agreements is relatively unexplored in Australia and we are prepared to encourage them where appropriate. But, at the same time, we want to allow the maximum flexibility for their future development.

We see no necessity for more detailed provisions in the bill because governments can clearly enter into such negotiations without there being a specific formal legislative framework. Nonetheless, the notion of the government facilitating negotiation on a regional basis in relation to, as the amendment says, claims to land, aspirations in relation to land or proposals for the use of land for economic purposes seems to us a worthwhile thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to both the preamble and the amendment. The preamble, I think, is intended to set out the government's general philosophical direction. It undoubtedly does that from its perspective, but I think it certainly overstates the case when it purports to express views on behalf of the entirety of the people of Australia. In that sense, it is, I think, a little more than a political statement.

PARA.TAB: The words `The Parliament of Australia therefore enacts' is of course the usual introductory clause, and we find that at the end of this preamble. But before we get there, we have statements like, `The people of Australia intend to rectify the consequences of past injustices'. It is one thing to say that as a result of the High Court decision there is now a very different approach taken not just to native title but also to the rights of the Aboriginal community as they currently are, but one cannot of course right any wrongs that might have occurred many years ago.

Certainly, if one adopts the normal approach of looking at who might be responsible for an injustice, it is completely unfair, I would have thought, to suggest that those who did not believe that they were committing any injustices should therefore be condemned with the vision of 20-20 hindsight. Therefore, I think that is just another example of an overstatement of the position.

The preamble talks in terms of the needs of the broader Australian community requiring certainty and the enforceability of acts potentially made invalid. I think all one can say is that the whole of the rest of the bill gives the lie to that noble aspiration. Certainly no-one would deny the need for certainty and enforceability, but to suggest that in any shape or form this bill does much in that regard is, again, a gross overstatement of the position and simply makes it a very tendentious political document.
It makes clear, for example, that what was spelt out by the High Court is to be significantly varied. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where appropriate, the native title should not be extinguished but revive after a validated act ceases to have effect.

This is a deliberate variation from what the High Court has said. It says also that native titleholders' rights and interests `under the common law of Australia need to be significantly supplemented'. Again, that is certainly not anything that flows from the High Court decision. It is simply a conscious decision on the part of the government as part of a social justice package and one that will need to be followed up in subsequent legislation.

PARA.TAB: But it is quite incorrect to put this document forward as though it is simply the unanimous will of the people that the Mabo decision be reflected in this legislation because there is, I think undoubtedly, a very high degree of controversy about the implications and the extent of that decision. It has been described, for example, as the greatest obiter dicta in history, and anyone who understands the law has to recognise that this decision was only confined to one group of offshore islands so that ultimately any decision about the rest will have to be reconsidered by the High Court. Undoubtedly, it will do so in the context of this legislation. But to make sweeping statements about what the High Court has done and what the people of Australia intend, I think, goes well beyond what one would normally expect to find in a preamble.

I say briefly in relation to the amendment that we find it objectionable for two reasons: it says, `Governments should, where appropriate, facilitate negotiation on a regional basis'. It clearly purports to tell state governments how to organise their affairs. It certainly says that this should take place in relation to land and proposals for the use of land for economic purposes. Again, the constitution makes it plain that land management decisions are the responsibility of the states, yet this preamble baldly asserts that there is a bounden duty and obligation on all governments, state and federal, to negotiate on a regional basis.

If we take that at face value, at which I suppose it is intended to be taken, then this is effectively telling the states to ignore their own boundaries, to adopt an entirely non-federal approach to what is essentially a state issue. Therefore, if the constitution is to have any meaning—and we certainly believe its meaning is clear—then this preamble would simply negate it for other political reasons. It is certainly not acceptable for that reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the issues of the preamble, there are some very important points to consider. I note in particular the amendment that the minister has put forward to facilitate regional agreements.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that in addressing this the government would also have turned its attention to the necessity of satisfactory agreements or consultations with states and territories in addition to proposing regional agreements. Whilst the purposes as stated in the preamble are very obviously to treat all landowners fairly and to create a just and fair land administration system, the Native Title Bill provides in the Northern Territory, which I represent, a system of land administration which has been nationally rejected and it is entrenched. That is particularly in respect to Northern Territory land rights.

There are provisions in the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory that relate to veto on mining, to doubt over the application of Northern Territory law, to the fact that there is no ability to compulsorily acquire land and for government assets to be not subject to claim. This bill changes all of these problems for a national application and, in doing so, highlights the inconsistency of the existing legislation of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act. If the tenets of this particular preamble are to apply and there is to be an equality, then very obviously the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory must be amended. Therefore, in putting forward amendments that relate to a regional basis, that provides an application.

I also note that the Democrats have an amendment subsequent to this in clause 41 of the legislation to which I think it is important to allude. That amendment changes words in that clause, which relates to subdivision where satisfactory alternative state or territory provisions exist. The Democrats propose to take out of clause 41 `are overruled on the grounds of State or Territory interest or of national interest' and insert `are overruled in a state or territory interest or in the national interest on grounds that are consistent with the preamble'.

I appreciate that amendment will probably have to be argued again when we reach clause 41, but if that Democrat amendment were subsequently adopted and considered in the context of this preamble, there would very obviously be a limitation imposed on the states and territories. In fact, that would be unprecedented with regard to legislation. So I would certainly ask Senator Kernot to keep that point in mind with regard to the application of her amendment when we get to clause 41 because it certainly has application to the intent of the preamble, which is then going to be totally enforced by its application in this particular area.

There are a number of other tenets outlined right through this comprehensive and detailed preamble that do have further impact and I give the minister notice that as we proceed through the bill a number of issues that will arise are, I think, related. For example, in the area that relates to onshore waters, the land between high and low water is to be subject to claim and, consequently, any activity in these zones, such as pipelines or pearling, could well be thwarted. That similarly, as I said, affects clause 16 and also a Greens amendment to clause 238.

In relation to the issue of renewals, which will arise in clause 24, for example when a mining lease is in existence for, say, 50 years and it comes up for renewal, governments will have to pay compensation to ensure that that activity proceeds. Again, we are not alerted at any stage here to the enormous economic implications that will have for the country.

Similarly, in clauses 34, 36 and 37, where there are issues to be considered, the bill potentially allows for endless negotiation. Certainly the Northern Territory experience under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act has been that we ought not have an open-ended loop in the process of negotiation that constantly goes on.

There is also a need to address the issue of the replacement of state environmental assessment processes that will arise and how those processes are affected. I note that the Greens are proposing an amendment in that area which will in effect amount to private royalties—again, impacts that come back to the preamble.

With regard to clause 44, which specifically relates to the Northern Territory and the McArthur River project, the Northern Territory is again singled out for special treatment. This has already been covered by other areas of the bill. Why, therefore, does that particular section have to be highlighted?

Pastoral leases that are purchased under the new land acquisitions fund, which is alluded to—a number of people have spoken to the proposals that will subsequently arise—will never be converted to native title in the Northern Territory because of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act and its draconian provisions. Again, that will need to be addressed.

Native title land can never be subject to a debt recovery process. As a consequence, many of the laws of the land will be unenforceable on native title land. Again, these highlight financial implications that are quite major.

The tribunal process that is proposed in clause 64 is a mockery of normal, legal processes and again needs to be addressed. If we look at the area of fishing, which is caught up in clause 197, we see that the capacity of the states and territories to confirm ownership and control certain of its resources is said to be subject to provisions of this bill; for example; the control of waters. Compensation and negotiation may be required. I therefore see in that a number of unintended consequences.

The Greens also have an amendment to clause 213. I am concerned that it has the potential, as I mentioned earlier today, to destroy the national parks system of the Northern Territory. It seems to be targeted and very specific and therefore does not meet the criteria that is established in the preamble of this bill of its equality of application. The Greens' amendment will attempt to make all titles of the Conservation Land Corporation unable to be validated. That has very serious implications and I would hope that the Greens will address that issue and perhaps consider backing off on that particular amendment.

I see a number of issues that arise because the preamble, by its nature, sets the tone. The issues I identify have a very significant impact on the Northern Territory. I hope I will be joined here in the debate by my Northern Territory colleague, Senator Collins, and that he will come in and argue strongly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Spare us.

—Maybe Senator Campbell wants to be spared from Senator Collins, but these 14 specific issues that I alluded to earlier this evening and have now reinforced all arise and have consequences in this preamble. There is no way in which I see that the Northern Territory should be maintained and kept as a social experiment at the expense of the rest of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I would hope that the private commitments given by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory will be reinforced and set out by the minister here and that those commitments will be publicly put on the record, that we will see in the future amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory to make it consistent with these principles.

For the last four or five years, there have been a number of reports and a number of acceptances by government of the need to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory and they have never surfaced, even though that legislation would be easy and simple for the government to accommodate. Yet we get such complex and difficult legislation as this pushed down the throats of people under the process we are now adopting. At the same time, what have been accepted as previously good areas for amendment, the government has walked away from. Therefore, I am very suspicious of many of the issues that arise out of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling was right when he said that the preamble sets the tone. It is quite a splendid preamble because, for the first time, along with the recent ATSIC bill, it tells the truth about the history of this nation—the history that we ought to own. It says:

PARA.TAB: The people whose descendants are now known as Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders were the inhabitants of Australia before European settlement.

SPEECH.PARA: Fact. It goes on:

PARA.TAB: They have been progressively dispossessed of their lands.

SPEECH.PARA: Fact. It continues:

This dispossession occurred largely without compensation, and successive governments have failed to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders concerning the use of their lands.
Fact. It further states:

PARA.TAB: As a consequence, Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders have become, as a group, the most disadvantaged in Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: That is another fact that we read about almost every day. The preamble goes on to talk about the referendum and the High Court judgment. It states:
The High Court has rejected the doctrine that Australia was terra nullius . . . at the time of European settlement.
Fact. That is why we are where we are now, debating this most important bill. I do not find this preamble one bit odious. In fact, I wish what it said had been enshrined in our constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address some remarks to the preamble as well. I do not share Senator Kernot's description of the preamble as splendid. It has a number of elements to it which I would not wish to have incorporated in legislation.

PARA.TAB: One matter which I do not think adds anything to the legislation is in the third paragraph of the preamble. In the setting down of the history of dispossession, as it describes it, it basically blames successive governments for having failed to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders concerning the use of their lands. This takes us back to the makarrata-type promises that were made to the Aboriginal people by the former Prime Minister. It implies that the Australian government needs to make some sort of lasting, more equitable agreement. I guess it implies the wishes of many people in the Aboriginal debate to have a makarrata or a treaty with the Aboriginal people. This is something that has been anathema to me personally.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a long bow you are drawing.

—It is fantastic to come in here and have a continuing stream of verbal diarrhoea coming across the crossbenches from Senator Kernot. I guess she just cannot help it. Maybe she should take something. She wears her heart on her sleeve. Senator Kernot cares so much about all of these things that no-one else can have a view that is validly held. If I want to read a preamble and interpret it in the way that I want to interpret it, I will. I do not really care what she thinks about how I interpret it. I am entitled to put my views here. I listened to her in absolute silence. I do not always listen to her in silence, but I did this time. I will put my views down. If she wants to keep going with her verbal diarrhoea, I invite her to please do so.

PARA.TAB: The concept of a lasting and equitable agreement with the Aboriginal peoples, which to me only implies some sort of reference to a treaty or makarrata, is anathema. I think the best solution for Australia and the best way for Australia to go forward is to ensure that we treat all Australian citizens, regardless of their race and regardless of the colour of their skin, as Australian citizens. We do need to recognise that many Australian citizens do suffer disadvantage and that many Aboriginals do suffer disadvantage. But if we want to overcome that disadvantage, we do not go about creating laws that are based on race. This legislation is one of the worst examples of that sort of law that has come before this parliament.

The preamble goes on to talk about the decision that the Australian people made back in 1967 to amend the constitution. It says that the Australian people agreed that the parliament would be able to make special laws for the peoples of the Aboriginal race. Of course, that referendum had nothing to do with making special laws for Aboriginals, but it did confer upon the parliament of Australia the power to make laws for Aboriginal people. The preamble goes on to say that the High Court rejected the doctrine of terra nullius for Australia. It is fair to say that that is one interpretation of the High Court's decision, but it is an interpretation that is hotly contested by many more eminent lawyers and thinkers on this subject than me.

There is no doubt that, if one is to look at the strict narrow interpretation of the doctrine of terra nullius as saying that Australia was a land belonging to no-one, as Senator Kernot said, the fact that Aboriginals occupied Australia prior to European settlement is absolutely indisputable. Of course, that is not what the doctrine of terra nullius incorporates. To that extent, the preamble again does not have my agreement. I guess it is only a grammatical point, but I note that the preamble goes on to say that the people of Australia intend to rectify the consequences of past injustices. The people of Australia have not had an opportunity to pass judgment on these matters and, at least in the next few years, there will not be a referendum on it.

As Senator Bishop said during the second reading stage, if the debate over the consequences of Mabo No. 2 and the consequences of this legislation and the various pieces of states legislation goes the way we predict—being tied up in constitutional fights in the High Court for years to come—perhaps it may be a good thing that the people of Australia do have the opportunity to vote on these issues at a referendum at some stage in the future.

It is wrong to say that the people of Australia intend any of these things because just about every published opinion poll of the Australian citizens shows that they are strongly opposed to the federal government intervening in these matters of land administration which are properly the responsibility of state governments. They certainly do not intend for the parliament and for the government to take these actions, so it is a stupid thing to say in a preamble that the people of Australia intend these things. If the people of Australia were asked whether they intended these things, they would tell the government `no'.

The other matter that I will raise in this discussion of the preamble is the special fund to be established to assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who `have been dispossessed of their traditional lands' and where native title has been extinguished due to valid acts. We have asked Treasury, we have asked Finance and we have asked ministers in this chamber how much money would be going to this special fund and how this will be paid for. It is a very valid question.

I know my colleague Senator Short has asked these questions at estimates committees as well. Australian citizens do have a right to know how the money will be raised, what sort of Mabo levy will be applied to the Australian people, and whether the money that will pay for this lands acquisition fund—or the `special fund', as it is called in the bill—will be raised by way of a new levy, or a tax surcharge, or an increase in taxation, or a broadening of the sales tax base, or an increase in borrowings. The Australian people have a right to know that.

To date the government has been extremely silent not only on how it is going to pay for the potentially enormous sums involved in compensation, which we know have to be paid, but also on the funds that will go into the special fund. It would be helpful to the Senate and to the people of Australia if the government were able to advise us on the way it is going to raise these funds, the amount we are looking at, and what the Australian people should be expecting to pay in terms of taxation, levies or surcharges to fund this additional expenditure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to make a couple of points on the preamble. The first page of the preamble which Senator Kernot read out states:

PARA.TAB: They have been progressively dispossessed of their lands.

SPEECH.PARA: While it is a known fact that the Aborigines were dispossessed of some of their lands, they also voluntarily left a lot of their land. If honourable senators do not believe what I tell them, I will once again quote from an article written by former Senator Peter Walsh who was in this place for a long time; he had a balanced view of these matters. In his article, he reminded us of a very worthy long-time member of the Western Australian parliament, Bill Grayden, who probably did more for Aborigines than any other parliamentarian in Australia, including our good friend Ernie Bridge.

PARA.TAB: According to the article, in the 1950s Bill Grayden and his brother, who was also a member of parliament at the time, ventured into the area around Warburton in the western desert in four-wheel drives and discovered the Pintubi people who were supposed to have belonged to the area. In time, most of those people moved out and into a better situation. Senator McKiernan can smile as much as he likes, but it is history that the Aborigines left the western desert because they found it much easier to live in a similar situation to white people around Warburton. The population increased in the area around Warburton, because the Aborigines had a stable source of food and were able to multiply more. The young ones lived with the others in the western desert. Peter Walsh states in his article:

The 1991 census data shows that Aborigines in Victoria and Tasmania, the most thoroughly "dispossessed", have much higher incomes, significantly longer life expectancy and a better education than Northern Territory Aborigines—the least "dispossessed". . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is his finding, not mine. I believe that he is correct. Peter Walsh further states:
In Western Australia, an analysis of an ABS census data showed a very strong inverse correlation between income and the propensity to speak an Aboriginal language at home. (Brunton, October `93.)

PARA.TAB: None of this is terribly surprising. The relatively affluent and healthy Aborigines are those with the highest level of socio-economic "assimilation". It is politically incorrect to say that, but what are our objectives: the material wellbeing of Aborigines—or feeling good about ourselves?

SPEECH.PARA: Those are very true words. He continues:

PARA.TAB: Almost certainly there is a higher proportion of part-Aborigines in the more affluent groups—a function of the duration of the association with white Australia, not biological inheritance.

SPEECH.PARA: Apparently, those statements are not politically correct these days. I use those points to disagree with the part of the preamble which states that all Aborigines were dispossessed of their lands, because it is simply not true.
Page 2 of the preamble, which Senator Kernot also read out, states:

PARA.TAB: As a consequence, Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders have become, as a group, the most disadvantaged in Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: I totally agree that they are amongst the most disadvantaged. But Senator Kernot never cared to mention the amount of money that has been spent in the last few years—almost $1 1/2 billion a year. Unfortunately, that money is not getting to the areas where it will do the most good—health, housing and education. Senator Kernot had a chance to support an inquiry into where that money was going.

PARA.TAB: I disagree with the bulk of the preamble. It could have been much better written, reflecting the points that I made and the points that former Senator Peter Walsh made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the preamble an admirable introduction to this long overdue measure. It does confirm the High Court's decision. The High Court has rejected the doctrine that Australia was terra nullius, but it also found that the common law of Australia recognises a form of native title that reflects the entitlement of indigenous inhabitants. It is those two legs on which this legislation is founded. I believe that it does provide a magnificent opportunity for the people of Australia to rectify the consequences of past injustices, as the preamble says.

PARA.TAB: Much has been made in recent contributions of the large amounts of money that reputedly have been spent on Aboriginal people. It is time that we recognise that money alone is not enough.
