We must recognise the cultural importance of the relationship that Aboriginal people have with their land. Some years ago I was privileged to do some work on Aboriginal communities in Australia's centre. I have learned to appreciate their values and their culture. I wish that, in many ways, our own culture felt free to emulate their values.
I turn to some of the comments in the preamble that are a little more specific. Page 3 of the preamble states:

Justice requires that, if acts that extinguish native title are to be validated or to be allowed, compensation on just terms, and with a special right to negotiate its form, must be provided to the holders of the native title.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also worthwhile to draw attention to the sentence in the preamble which says:
. . . where appropriate, the native title should not be extinguished but revived after a validated act ceases to have effect.

The preamble draws attention to the Racial Discrimination Act and the intention of the government and, I believe, the intention of this parliament that this legislation should not contravene, in any way, the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act. It seeks to characterise the act as a whole as a special measure. To ensure that this view is taken of the provisions of this act, the Australian Democrats have placed an amendment to the preamble before the Senate which states that it is the intention of the parliament that the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 shall prevail over the provision of this act.

PARA.TAB: I foreshadow that we are prepared to withdraw that amendment because, on reflection, we prefer the amendment with a similar intent circulated in the Senate by the Greens (WA). Their amendment 1A seems to us to achieve the purpose more specifically. I foreshadow our intention to withdraw our amendment if the minister will confirm that the government will support the Greens's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked by Senator Spindler to give that confirmation, and I do so. We will support the new clause 6A that is proposed by the Greens' amendment 1A as circulated in the supplementary amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would appreciate it if the minister would address one other matter which has concerned me for quite a while now. This act is generally referred to as a special measure under the terms of the Racial Discrimination Act. I noted, when I read it a few months ago, that the Racial Discrimination Act incorporates as a schedule the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, which is referred to in the preamble.

PARA.TAB: Section 4 of that convention, which describes the matter of special measures, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Special measures taken for the sole purpose of securing adequate advancement of certain racial or ethnic groups or individuals requiring such protection as may be necessary in order to ensure such groups or individuals equal enjoyment or exercise of human rights and fundamental freedoms shall not be deemed racial discrimination, provided, however, that such measures do not, as a consequence, lead to the maintenance of separate rights for different racial groups and that they shall not be continued after the objectives for which they were taken have been achieved.

I would appreciate the minister informing the Senate how this bill, which creates special rights for a racial group—certainly on my understanding of how the legislation will be implemented—maintains those special rights in perpetuity.

PARA.TAB: I have raised this matter in a number of forums. I am yet to receive a satisfactory answer to this question of the maintenance of separate rights continuing after the objectives for which they have been taken have been achieved. I ask the minister to address himself to that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not wish it to be thought that the existence and recognition of native title is itself a special measure, because that native title is part of the common law of the land. It is no different in its essential character from other kinds of proprietary right recognised as a matter of common law.

PARA.TAB: The special measures come in with a number of the procedural and institutional provisions of this legislation that are designed to give effect—hopefully, speedy effect—to the enjoyment of that newly recognised common law native title right. Things like the just terms compensation provision, the tribunal process and the land fund, together with provisions like the conversion of Aboriginal pastoral leases and setting constraints on extinguishment that might otherwise conceivably be applicable as a matter of common law so far as future mining leases are concerned, are all examples of particular measures that obviously confer particular advantages, and unashamedly so, given the history of disadvantage of Aboriginal people in this country.

It is true that the international convention and the Australian Racial Discrimination Act, which is based upon it, set a notional time limit in the sense of the enjoyment of special measures and benefits. That is in order, not over time, to create a group of people who so benefit from those special measures that they start enjoying some special differential privilege over and above the ordinary members of the community. I do not think anyone would suggest there is any chance of Aboriginal people assuming that exalted status in the foreseeable future.

But I guess that there would clearly be an argument in a few years about the operation of some of these provisions when the native title process has worked its way through for all those people who will need to employ those procedural mechanisms. Notionally, there is to be regarded as built into this some constraint of that kind. But I do not think anyone would want to try to begin to set a time limit on the operation of this legislation, given the nature and extent of the wrongs that have to be righted and the process that is necessary to produce that result.

I note for the record that, in the case of Gerhardy v. Brown, the High Court held that the Pitjantjatjara Land Rights Act was itself a special measure, even though it had no specific time limit on its operation in the way of a sunset clause or anything else. That is not to say that some argument might not conceivably be able to be mounted in some years that this kind of provision has run its course. I would not wish to set any such time limit on it for the reasons I have already explained.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether I understood correctly what the minister was saying. Perhaps he can see whether I did or did not on the basis of this question. Is it his view that a law which vests native title in a body corporate without its consent can be a special measure when the view can be run by some that it is expressly excluded from being a special measure by virtue of section 10(3) of the Racial Discrimination Act?

—Apparently, section 10(3) of the Racial Discrimination Act deals with land managed by people other than Aboriginal persons. This leads to a question about body corporates, which is perhaps better dealt with when we get to the clauses that deal with body corporates. It is not the intention that the creation of a body corporate as an interest holding device should in any way operate to anybody's disadvantage. Certainly, it is not intended that there be any discriminatory impact and any consequences as far as the Racial Discrimination Act is concerned in this respect. Perhaps this issue is better raised when we get to the provisions dealing with body corporates.

—I understand that the minister has acknowledged that he will be acceding to the Greens amendment No. 1A. This amendment, which is part of a series, has the potential to render an already complex bill even more uncertain and some of its provisions ineffective. There are provisions of the bill which might offend the RDA.
—Order! Senator Tambling, we have not got to that amendment, which inserts new clause 6A. We are still dealing with the preamble. It is probably more appropriate to deal with it later.
—The price of a withdrawal of a Democrat amendment that addressed the racial discrimination issue was to indicate our intentions later in the bill. We will get to it later.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Preamble, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 4, page 6, table containing outline of Act, after the entry relating to Part 8, insert the following entry:
8A Financial Assistance to States and Territories: This Part
provides for the Commonwealth to enter into agreements for
the provision of financial assistance to States and Territories
that have validated past acts.
(40)After Part 8, page 82, insert the following new Part:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Financial assistance to States or Territories

TAB.EMPHASIS: Financial assistance that may be given

PARA.TAB: "191A.(1) If a State or Territory has validated past acts as mentioned in section 18, the Commonwealth may enter into a written agreement with the State or Territory for the provision of financial assistance to that State or Territory in relation to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the satisfaction of any liability to pay compensation arising under Part 2; or
(b)the satisfaction of any liability to pay any costs incidental to any claim for such compensation or determination of liability for such compensation; or
(c)costs and expenses of establishing and administering any recognised State/Territory body of that State or Territory; or
(d)costs and expenses of administering any provisions having effect under subsection 41(1).

PARA.TAB: "(2) The financial assistance is to be provided on such conditions as are determined by the Commonwealth Minister and set out in the agreement.".

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of these amendments will be to introduce a new part into the proposed act—part 8A, which deals with financial assistance to the states and territories. The amendment to clause 4 is a very simple one; it is the outline of the proposed act that is in the nature of an index and a table of contents for the act as a whole. The amendment consists simply of introducing the reference to the new part.

PARA.TAB: The substantive part of the government's amendment is amendment No. 40 which seeks to introduce a new part 8A on financial assistance, making it clear that the Commonwealth may enter into a written agreement with a state or territory for the provision of financial assistance relating to satisfaction of liability to pay compensation. This addition to the bill was sought by the state of Victoria which wrote to the Commonwealth saying it thought it was appropriate that the Commonwealth's intention, so far as financial compensation is concerned, be made explicit in the terms of the legislation. This is the sort of thing that could have been done by executive agreement but the legislative provision sets out the framework for determining that assistance on a jurisdiction by jurisdiction basis as the implementation of the bill takes place, and the Commonwealth was perfectly happy to accede to that request from the states.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Gareth Evans has said, amendment No. 40 is the more important of the two amendments. Amendment No. 40 seeks to introduce a completely new part 8A into the Native Title Bill. Part 8A is headed `Financial Assistance to States and Territories'. As the minister explained, amendment No. 2 amends clause 4 of the bill which attempts in a tabular form to broadly summarise the content of the whole bill. Amendment No. 2 amends clause 4 to insert a summary description of the new part 8A into the tabular format outline. The amendment to clause 4 says that the proposed new part 8A:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . provides for the Commonwealth to enter into agreements for the provision of financial assistance to States and Territories that have validated past acts.

In essence, this new part 8A seeks to insert into the bill for the first time a provision whereby the states and territories can look to the Commonwealth for financial assistance to meet the compensation costs arising from the validation by a state or territory of past acts.

PARA.TAB: These are only two of 74 amendments that the government has circulated in the last 24 hours and there have been additional amendments since. These are amendments to the government's own bill. This is a classic example of the government's absolute incompetence in handling this matter.The supplementary explanatory memorandum specifically says that none of the 74 amendments, not even the new part 8A, contains any financial impact. I must say that I find that quite extraordinary. I hope that the minister will be able to enlighten us on that in due course.

There are at least two extraordinary aspects to amendment No. 40. I understand the reason for it being introduced. Nevertheless, one has to look at the wording of it to make a clear judgment on it. The first point is that this proposed new part was not included in the bill in the first place. I do not really understand how that could be. In his second reading speech, in relation to compensation, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where compensation is owed to native titleholders for validation of past grants, it will be government, not the grant holder, who pays. We recognise that the Commonwealth should make a proper contribution towards compensation costs. We will have further discussions with the states and territories willing to join with us in this national approach, as well as on cost sharing for the legal and administrative regime.

He talked about compensation at the time of the council of Australian governments meeting earlier in the year when he was trying to negotiate a deal with the states and territories on Mabo No. 2. It was there all the time, and I find it extraordinary that part 8A—more accurately and appropriately drafted than the part 8A now being introduced—was not included at all. That is the first aspect of this amendment that I find quite extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I find it quite extraordinary that the government claims that it will have no financial impact. Since when does a new provision for financial assistance have no financial impact? The logic of that is that the Commonwealth must envisage making no contribution at all to the compensation payments made by states and territories. Clause 19(3) of the bill says quite clearly that so far as past acts validated by a state or territory are concerned, the compensation will be wholly met by the state or territory itself.

It is extraordinarily confusing. Obviously, the Commonwealth is not envisaging paying no compensation to states or territories for past acts validated by them. One of the great criticisms and concerns that the coalition has about this whole bill is that, looked at in total, it really just provides a blank cheque to the government with no indication at all of what the costs are going to be to the taxpayer or anyone else for that matter—the states or territories, the Commonwealth and taxpayers generally.

As my colleague Senator Campbell commented earlier, there is no idea of the cost of compensation and there is no idea how it is going to be funded. Perhaps one of the reasons for the resignation of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) during dinner time tonight is that he has suddenly realised what he has on his hands, potentially, with this legislation—it appears to be a totally open-ended cheque. I hope that the government in the course of the committee debate will try to give the Senate some indication of what the costs will be. Part 8A is only one small part of the compensation cost. It is quite inconsistent to have part 8A included in the way that it is and, at the same time, to say in the supplementary explanatory memorandum that these amendments will have no financial impact.

The inclusion of part 8A presumably stems from the remarks and statements made by the government, particularly the Prime Minister, over many months. They have changed their minds from one day to the next. I accept the minister's statement at face value that the idea is included at the behest of the Victorian government, but I would be very surprised if the Victoria government had a hand in the drafting, because it is very sloppy.

What does the amendment actually mean? What are its implications? I have mentioned the cost element. I am reinforced in the remarks I made about the open-endedness and the vagueness of it all by the fact that, at the first COAG meeting, when the Commonwealth tried to talk the states and territories into a deal, my recollection quite clearly is that the Commonwealth was offering 100 per cent compensation to states and territories if they signed up on the dotted line there and then. But when the states did not turn over and say, `Tickle my tummy', the 100 per cent compensation reimbursement offer was jettisoned and replaced with a 75 per cent offer.

The bill itself made no provision whatsoever for Commonwealth reimbursement. On the contrary, clause 19(3) specifically says that the compensation is payable by the state or territory. This amendment is presumably designed to correct that, but what will it do? It does contain very vague and equivocal wording indeed. First of all, it gives no guarantee whatsoever that the Commonwealth will compensate a state or territory. The new clause 191A(1), which is the essence of part 8A, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth may enter into a written agreement with the State or Territory for the provision of financial assistance to that State or Territory —

in relation to the compensation cost. I note the word `may'. It does not say that it will; it simply says that the Commonwealth may. It gives the Commonwealth the power to do so, but it does not give a requirement that it do so. So there is no guarantee of anything at all there.

PARA.TAB: Even if the Commonwealth does agree to provide financial assistance, there are no limits at all in any direction as to the amount. There are no percentage limits. It could be five per cent; it could be nought per cent; it could be 100 per cent. There are no dollar limits either. In other words, there is total uncertainty about the real meaning of the provision when one looks at the hard print.

How will the amount be determined? These are some questions that I hope Senator Gareth Evans will respond to. How will the amount be determined from one case to another? Will there be any limits? Will there be any regulations that will give us more specific guidance on that? They are all very legitimate and important questions that I hope the government has some answers to.

As well as those points of detail, there is equally a problem of very considerable magnitude with respect to the wording of part 8A. I refer in particular to clause 191A(2), which says that the financial assistance will be subject to conditions. The clause states:

SPEECH.PARA: The financial assistance is to be provided on such conditions as are determined by the Commonwealth Minister and set out in the agreement.

So there are two points: the first is that the assistance will be conditional. One gets no prizes for guessing the answer to the second point. Who is going to be the sole determiner of the conditions? The answer is that obviously, given what happens under this government, it is the Commonwealth minister. The Commonwealth minister alone has the sole power of determining the conditions. Not only can and will the minister impose conditions, but also the conditions themselves are not required to have anything at all to do with the native title itself. They could relate to the state's or territory's education system, health system, transports system or anything else.

PARA.TAB: There is nothing at all in the bill or in the wording of this amendment to tie it down to the situation related to the bill itself. In essence, that means that this clause is potentially a Trojan Horse to a major increase in the Commonwealth's power over financial assistance arrangements with the states in that it would both directly, but more particularly indirectly, enable an enormous increase in the tied grants power of the Commonwealth in respect of the states. The most centralist power that any federal government could have over the states is the ability to tie its financial payments to the states to particular conditions.

I want to come back to that a little later on, if I may. But I will cease there. I ask the minister to respond to the following questions that I posed: how will the compensation payments be determined; will there be any conditions; are there any upper or lower limits—in other words, how will we get some certainty into this?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short ought to be familiar enough from his previous experience in financial administration to know that payments to the states for special purposes are always subject to appropriate conditions. What those conditions will need to be will depend entirely on the terms of the federal-state financial agreements as their substance evolves.

PARA.TAB: This is very much a broad outline framework provision. It does not purport in any way to get into the detail of how those financial agreements will work. They are intended to be agreements, after all, properly negotiated between the Commonwealth and the states and one would expect the normal sorts of considerations that apply to Commonwealth funding in the context of such agreements to apply. I cannot be more specific than that.

As to the absence of a financial impact statement and the absence of reference to negative or any financial impact for this, the point is that these provisions are not self-executing. There is no automatic financial obligation associated with the mere existence of this particular statutory provision. It does depend upon agreements being entered into with the states. Those agreements, in turn, are expressly conditional, as the clause makes clear, on the state or territory in question validating past acts. It is clearly only in an environment of cooperatively moving the game forward that it is anticipated that agreements of this kind will be able to be reached. Agreement implies agreement on both sides and that implies some common approach and some willingness to approach the issues in a complementary and cooperative way.

Because there is that uncertainty of just what sorts of agreements will be implemented, and with whom over what time period, because that will depend on the capacity of the two sides to reach amicable agreement, the clause has no direct or immediate financial impact, although obviously there will be a significant financial impact in due course flowing from those agreements when they are reached and implemented.

As to the quantum of that financial impact in due course, it is simply not possible to do more than offer very broad brush guesstimates. We had exchanges about this during a series of question times in past weeks and I am afraid that I cannot add anything more to those exchanges at this stage. The quantum of the degree of the Commonwealth contributions, compared with any possible state contribution, in percentage terms is not something I can comment usefully about at this stage. That is a matter for ongoing discussion and negotiations between the Commonwealth and the states, between the Prime Minister and the Premiers, and there is nothing much more as a result that I can usefully add to the information base before the chamber at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested in what the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) had to say about the financial impact statement. After all, only $6 million has been set aside at this stage for the implementation. But I find it very peculiar that the minister cannot give a better estimate. I thought, considering the importance of this legislation, the government might have done some sort of feasibility study to determine how it could be financed. We should also bear in mind the expectations of ATSIC, which were outlined in a big announcement by Lois O'Donoghue on 18 October 1993. I will not read out all of the statement, but part 7 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Compensation will be payable for past extinguishments of native title. Compensation will be on just terms and there will be no "cap" on the compensation payable.
Bearing that in mind, I would still like the minister to give us some idea, because $6 million in this case is a very small amount.

PARA.TAB: If I understood the minister correctly earlier in answer to Senator Short, he said that these agreements between governments, federal and state, are subject to certain conditions. Do I take it that agreement is reached if it is financially possible? Just looking at this and knowing how much of Western Australia can be claimed and what industries this can tie up, to me it is out of this world what sort of figure we can come up with. I believe the minister should be able to give us a better explanation, or are agreements reached only as the government can afford it over the years? That is bearing in mind Lois O'Donoghue's statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I cannot add anything useful to what I have said in that respect. I would like to be able to, but the conditions that are associated with the financial agreement are a matter for negotiation in the ordinary way, as between the Commonwealth and the state.

—They are subject to it in an ordinary way—but subject to what? The Australian budget is about $110 billion. The parties could come up with one deal worth $1 billion. As I understand this legislation, that could be a figure attained in one deal.

—Senator Panizza has heard what I have said about orders of magnitude of these things in earlier debates and question time. It is obviously going to take place over a period of years and obviously we do not anticipate orders of that magnitude for single deals. If we did, we would not have used the sort of figures we variously did in those earlier contributions. We have to work out, and the courts and tribunals have to work out, what appropriate compensation levels are and we will fall into line with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to say to the minister that, in the light of his explanation, which I find much less than satisfactory, it seems to me that the supplementary explanatory memorandum which says that there will be no financial impact is absolutely and totally misleading unless we make the assumption that never ever will the Commonwealth provide any contribution towards compensation paid by a state or territory which has validated a past act. That, quite patently, is nonsense and I put it to the minister that it is an absolutely misleading statement of financial impact to have in that supplementary explanatory memorandum.

PARA.TAB: May I seek clarification of two other matters, one of which I raised as a question? It does not seem to me that the minister really answered it. Is it envisaged that there will be any guidelines or other documentation that will accompany the act in respect of terms and conditions that might apply as to upper or lower limits, or anything else, to financial agreements that might be entered into by the Commonwealth in these areas? Is anything envisaged that will come before this parliament again?
My second question relates to proposed subsection 191A(2), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The financial assistance is to be provided on such conditions as are determined by the Commonwealth Minister and set out in the agreement.

Does the minister agree that a correct reading of that proposed subsection is such that the conditions that are talked about there need have no relationship at all to native title, to the act or to anything even vaguely resembling it and that it could, in fact, relate to conditions that might be imposed on a state or territory's health system or education system or transport system or any other form of state activity? If he does agree with that, then I presume he would also agree that that is an extraordinarily wide provision to have in a bill of this nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —Frankly, Senator Short is stretching an exceedingly long bow. He will be familiar with the standard expression in the constitution itself under section 96 so far as financial grants to the states are concerned. They have to be under such terms and conditions as the parliament thinks appropriate. He will equally be familiar, from his previous experience in financial administration, that when grants are made in the context of particular agreements for particular purposes, the conditions may well include provision that the money be spent for that particular purpose, just as a normal method of ensuring appropriate financial accountability and conformity to the rules that govern these things.

PARA.TAB: There is no intention on the part of the Commonwealth to invent conditions here which have nothing to do with the administration of native title legislation and the implications of that for the states. It would be an absurd thing for the Commonwealth to contemplate exercising clauses like this in that way. I am sure that there is not even the beginnings of any intention to think in those terms.

I emphasise the fact that we are talking here basically not about unilateral grants by the Commonwealth, but payment pursuant to agreements—agreements properly negotiated and entered into. There cannot be agreement without agreement on the part of both sides. That is the expectation that will occur. This is purely a very sketchy framework provision just to indicate the Commonwealth's good faith that we do anticipate financial liability being incurred; we do anticipate willingness to enter into agreement.

We are under no legal liability to pay for the consequences of validation, notwithstanding what Professor Howard, my old law school colleague, may have said in opinions and things of that kind. That is certainly not the judgment that I or the law officers of the Crown have about the actual liability. So it is a matter of the Commonwealth expressing a bit of goodwill here in response to a request from the states to do so in outline terms.

Really, those opposite cannot take yes for an answer sometimes. We are really trying to be nice, to demonstrate a willingness to be helpful, to assist, and they are so redolent with suspicion about our lousy, rotten motives that it sometimes makes me wonder whether it is worth while responding in an affirmative way to some of these requests that we get from the states from time to time.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say in response to that, having seen this government act for the last 10 years in the way that it has, is that any state premier who thinks that the government will act with good faith and goodwill really needs—
—Jealousy is a curse.

—You started it; you can take a little bit back in response. This is an area where the states have been absolutely screwed financially by this government over the last 10 years with the enormous growth in the proportion of payments going to the states in the form of tied grants. The thing that concerns me about this amendment, good faith or no good faith, is that, as worded, it does constitute potentially a real Trojan horse for a Commonwealth government that might wish to use it. It could have a very significant impact of an upward nature in further tying grants or payments to the states.

PARA.TAB: There can be no greater form of centralised power by a central government than making its payments to the states highly conditional, as Senator Evans's government has done relentlessly over the past 10 years. If we were to take his assertions on his good faith—and I put this to Senator Gareth Evans as a question—why does he not look at rewording clause 191A(2) to ensure that it is not possible for that clause to be used under my interpretation of it, which even he has not denied?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been accused of littering the landscape with excessive amounts of amendment paper but I think that is one amendment which, to be perfectly frank and fair to Senator Short, is quite unnecessary. We are talking here about agreements that will be entered into between the Commonwealth and the states. They will be entered into and administered in good faith. We see no need for such an amendment.

—I just wanted to put on the record—because Senator Gareth Evans has gone to some length to say that the government will act in good faith in these matters—that this government, in relation to its negotiations with the Western Australian government, has shown no good faith whatsoever since June last year. Senator Short has raised an important issue of the Commonwealth intervening in state affairs using tied grants.

PARA.TAB: Only in October of this year, there was an example where the Commonwealth included for the first time in a draft for the renewal of a landcare Commonwealth-state agreement, I think it was, which it put to the Western Australian government—I do not have it in the chamber with me; it is back in my rather extensive Mabo files in the office—a clause which one could consider to be a condition of the Commonwealth funding the landcare project that was under consideration. The condition was that, in the Commonwealth's words, the agreement would be subject to the state government recognising either the Mabo decision or the existence of native title.

That is one example of the very concern that Senator Short has raised where the Mabo issue is intervening in a range of Commonwealth-state affairs. It actually contradicts exactly what Senator Gareth Evans told us; there is no good faith there. The federal government will not only use its financial power in respect of this legislation but also in just about any area into which it can intervene.

This government has had a total lack of faith in the state premiers. It is fair to say that the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, made a genuine attempt—even after his famous Boyer lectures where he suggested that the states should be abolished and that we should set up regions—when, after many years in office, he saw the wisdom of a strong federation and sought to do something constructive about it. On the other hand, Mr Keating used the federal-state financial relations reforms that Mr Hawke proposed to undermine Mr Hawke's leadership. Mr Keating is an avowed centralist. He does not like the states. He does not like the Senate. So he will do and does everything that he can to undermine the state governments. He has done more in the last two years than any other Prime Minister in the history of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —He used it to bring down the former Prime Minister.

—He did indeed. The real thing that the people of Australia must understand is that the government knows that it cannot abolish the Senate and it cannot undermine the states through referendums or any democratic process. So this federal government under Mr Keating, who is an avowed centralist, is using every surreptitious means possible to undermine the powers of the states. It is doing this in the areas of health, education and now land management by using the power of the purse to rip tax funds off Australian citizens and then to hand the money back to the states in the form of tied grants. Again, we have an example of it here in this bill.

PARA.TAB: The main point of my contribution tonight is to inform the Senate that what Senator Gareth Evans has told us tonight is not true. The federal government is already using native title as a Trojan horse to intervene in many other areas. There is a document floating around the building—my colleague Mr McLachlan may have tabled it in the House of Representatives in October—which is a landcare agreement in which the Commonwealth has put a condition that the state government recognise the existence of native title, or some other such clause. That is an example of an agreement that has absolutely nothing to do with either the Mabo High Court decision or native title.
Question put:
That the amendments be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

—Have you got something worked out?
—It has been discussed with Senator Chapman's side, as I understand it, and I think it is acceptable. Might we report progress for a few minutes in order to resolve this. I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That, if the Senate is sitting at midnight tonight, the sitting of the Senate then be suspended til 9.00 a.m. on Saturday 18 December 1993.
(2)That on Saturday, 18 December 1993, the sitting of the Senate be suspended from 1 p.m. till 2 p.m. and from 6 p.m. till 7 p.m.

While we might have nurtured some hope originally that there might be very rapid progress which would have enabled us to finish sometime tonight or in the early hours of tomorrow morning, it is clear that, with the best will in the world and the most cooperation that is possible—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your incompetence.

—That is not very charming or polite, nor very accurate. It is clear that we will not be able to get there tonight and we will have to pick it up tomorrow. I think the mood is that maybe we will all perform a little bit more cheerfully and expeditiously if we get some sleep and pick it up again at 9 o'clock. That is the intention.
—I understand that this is a deal between the government, the Democrats and the Greens, and they have the numbers and that is what is going to occur.
—How do you know?

—I understand that that is the case. As we said earlier, it is the family at work. This is what they want to do, and that makes up the numbers. So they have decided that the parliament should sit on Saturday, apparently. I do not know what consideration they have given to the staff in this place. I asked earlier whether they had made inquiries—
—Why didn't you think of that when you wasted two hours before dinner? Why didn't you ask then?

—I did actually. I asked earlier what arrangements had been made in relation to the convenience of the staff of this place, the working hours. But why are we sitting on Saturday and not on Monday, for example? What do those opposite expect—Hansard to go until midnight tonight and be back here at 9 o'clock in the morning? We have done that every day this week, except Wednesday which went until 8.30 p.m. Have those opposite taken that into account?
—Crocodile tears.
—Senator Evans says `crocodile tears'.
—You should have cooperated.

—It is not a question of us. This is the government's program. It has decided to bring on a bill the day after the Senate is supposed to be up and to debate 250 amendments. It is the government's incompetent program. You couldn't manage a chook raffle, you lot!

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think those interjections are unhelpful.
—It is no wonder the country is in so much trouble.

PARA.TAB: Government and Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on both sides!

—I know that those opposite have no interest in senators getting home to families this weekend, but what about the staff of senators? Have they made any arrangements for that? No, of course they have not. We understand that, after 7 a.m., there are no seats on any planes until Monday; does that concern those opposite about staff? What arrangements have they made? Nothing; no arrangements at all. Why have they decided to finish at midnight?

PARA.TAB: Last Thursday, again with their friends the Greens and the Democrats, they decided to sit this parliament until 2 o'clock in the morning. Apparently, it was all right last Thursday to sit until 2 o'clock in the morning. In fact, if we had pressed the matter, we would have sat a lot longer. But not tonight; they have decided to sit on a Saturday. Have those opposite had consultations with the staff in this place? Have they spoken with the Hansard people; have they spoken with the clerks; have they spoken with the attendants; have they spoken with the transport people? Have they given any consideration to the wellbeing of the workers in this place?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wasting time now.
—Has Senator Burns done that? Any consideration at all?
—Hero of the working class?

—No; no consideration at all. Let it be quite clearly understood that there is no need to debate this bill tonight. We all know that we get poor quality legislation by behaving in this way. A day after the Senate was supposed to rise, 250 amendments were put down and expected to be debated sensibly. It is crazy stuff, and those opposite know it is crazy stuff. They say, `That's well and good but, furthermore, we'll make the parliament sit on Saturday'. Parliament has not sat on Saturday for over 30 years for very sensible reasons: because we cannot expect the workers in this place to work from Monday to Friday and then to sit through Saturday as well. What do the unions say about this? Did all the unionists opposite consult the workers? No, not one of them consulted the workers. They have no interest at all in the workers. What do they propose if this legislation is not finished tomorrow?
—Sunday.

—The minister says we will sit on Sunday. Why could the government not have set down an orderly sensible program for this parliament? We made an effort. We put down a rule that was planned to give this parliament orderly programming and what response did we get for that—cooperation? No. In fact the government cut out all the democratic processes from the House of Representatives to indicate its pique. That is all the government did.

PARA.TAB: This bill and the IR bills, to which we had over 200 amendments, under the rules that this Senate had decided were not going to be debated in this way because this year we were going to try to have a sensible process, but this government would not do it. It could not plan for an orderly parliamentary process at all. It is a hopeless situation.

So what are the arrangements for the staff? I ask the minister to tell us what he has done? Has he consulted with Hansard? Has he consulted with the clerks? What is their attitude to it? I understand that the staff in this place were deeply distressed earlier this day about what the government is expecting of them due to its incompetent planning. Has the minister made arrangements? Will he get up and tell us about that? No, of course he will not.

Anyway, as I said, the numbers are there; the deal has been done. If the government, the Greens and the Democrats decide that we will sit until 12 midnight tonight, get up and come back in the morning, we will be here. The government will not beat us that way. The government wants us to sit on Sunday and Monday. Why should not the Australian people at least expect the parliament to be run in a sensible, orderly way? Why should the Australian people have to put up with this form of legislative process?

Let us hear the Greens and the Democrats. They are part of this. They have had their morning of consultation. This is the consultative process. All of them are just happy that this place has become a rubber stamp. `Keeping the bastards honest' used to be the cry of the Democrats. Now they are just simply another faction of the Labor Party. `You don't understand consensus politics', they say to us, `We are with the government and through consensus we will work out jointly with the Labor Party how we want to run Australia', and the Greens will be bought off by this process as well. Throw the Greens a crumb or two and they will come into the process as well—consensus politics.

They are all part of the family—the Labor Party, the Greens and the Australian Democrats. Only one side, the coalition, is prepared to stand up to this government and fight for what is in the best interests of the Australian people. We will continue to do it even through intolerable circumstances, which is what this minister is seeking to impose on us. So let us hear it. What arrangement has the minister made for the staff in this place?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am appalled to see the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) just sit there smugly. He thinks it is all part of the game. I want to make it perfectly clear that we were not in any way consulted other than being told that this was a program that had been agreed to by others. It is no wonder that John Dawkins threw in the towel. He could not stand there any longer watching this government lurch from disaster to disaster.

PARA.TAB: The minister has the cheek to say that one of the reasons why the program is so dramatically behind schedule is because of a lousy, rotten filibuster on the industrial relations bill. We all know how the government's incompetence on Mabo enabled the ACTU payback bill to be effectively disguised from the Australian electorate, and all we were doing was making absolutely sure, as best we could in this process, that the electorate well and truly understood that this government is not interested in micro-economic reform, not seriously interested in labour market reform; the government is simply interested in doing deals.

The high priestess of backroom deals, of course, is party to that same process. To come in here as a whitened sepulchre and claim that somehow consensus ought to take over from parliamentary processes, I think is the height of insult to us all. Let us be perfectly clear; we are wanting to debate this bill. We have not in any way filibustered today. What has happened is there has been—

TALK.START.PARA: —Two hours before dinner; what was that?

—If the minister remembers, we have been on notice to debate Mabo for some days. It was so dramatically urgent that what did we get? We got a whole series of Mickey Mouse bits and pieces that were intruded in order to enable the government to have yet a bit more time to cobble together some sorts of amendments which seem to have fallen over anyway. That is why I think we all find it galling in the extreme that Senator Kernot is saying, `What we want to do is get it right'.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite were serious in any shape or form about getting it right, they would have, firstly, referred it to a committee; and, secondly, they would have tried to put down a sensible legislative program, instead of trying to ram it through close to Christmas when everyone has other commitments, everyone is well and truly at the end of their tether, when all we expect is the sort of light-headedness that we get from the other side and obviously a cynical lack of interest in the process from the Australian Democrats.

So let us be perfectly clear; there is only one party that is responsible for the current state of affairs, only one party that will be responsible for us sitting over the weekend. We will be here as long as it takes and I am sure others will be too. But in no shape or form do we accept any responsibility for yet another disaster.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like Senator Gareth Evans to respond to why we cannot come back on Monday. What is the difference between Monday and Saturday? The other thing I would like to know is, if we are to sit on Sunday, will there be some provision for some of us to go to church? Some of us have conscientious objections to working on Sundays. I want the minister to consider that.

PARA.TAB: For example, Senator Campbell, one of the younger senators, has a very young baby and young wife and some of the other senators would like to go home a week before Christmas. This is the time of Christmas; it is the time for family, and now we are working one week out before Christmas when the younger people should be enjoying their children, enjoying the spirit of Christmas, Christmas trees and church celebrations and we will be confined in here, not because we have to but because the government and the Democrats were not ready to go ahead with this bill till 4 o'clock.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were ready.

—Senator Kernot may have been ready but the government certainly was not. There was a filibuster up till 4 o'clock; divisions were called when they were not necessary, and then Senator Kernot comes in here weeping crocodile tears saying, `We have been ready to go on this'. Senator Kernot may have been ready to go, but the government certainly was not.

PARA.TAB: Last night, if Senator Kernot had listened to one of my contributions, I gave the Democrats a little friendly advice because it was Christmas. I said to Senator Bell, from Tasmania, that where I thought the Democrats were going wrong was that they were getting their directions from the government, they were in this wonderful consensus with the government, but they ignored their own constituency. They should be out talking to their constituency and finding out what their constituency wants and then come back here and stand up for it. But they have taken a short-cut—short circuited the system—and the government is telling the Democrats what the Democrats' constituency should want.

They have got it completely wrong. They are getting so tied up with the government that there is very little difference. They are blending into the government. It is a pale shade of white going into cream and there is very little difference now between the government and the Democrats, and they are going to pay the electoral penalty for it.

One of the Democrats' former leaders did stand up. He had a principle and a direction and we knew what the Democrats stood for. We knew where they were going. They were a little different but we knew where they were. But now they are getting their riding instructions from over there and they are not looking after their constituency. They are doing what they are told. When the master's voice speaks, they do exactly what they are told.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly what all governments do.

—I am sorry but that is the way they are being perceived in the electorate. I think that the Democrats are making a grave mistake and I think they will be tagged as part of the government. They have had their little run on the budget but now they are falling into the trap of being so close to the government that no-one can see the difference.
—I have been asked to respond to several questions. I will try and do so.
—You will need leave, Senator.
—No, I am closing the debate.
—No—
—I am closing the debate, Mr Deputy President! You gave me the call. I get up and I am closing the debate. I am answering questions. You gave me the call; I am not seeking leave.

—Order! Sit down! We will have one president in this chamber at a time and it happens to be me at the moment. Senator Evans, you asked for the right to respond to a question, as I understood it, and that is why I called you. I thought you were going to seek leave. You did not do that, so I call somebody else and you can close the debate later on.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I was asked a series of questions, as people often are in the course of procedural debates. I chose, in the absence of anyone else standing, to get up and respond to those questions. I chose to do so and I chose to do so in good faith. I did not seek leave; I do not seek leave now. If you choose not to call me, that it is your prerogative and I accept it, but it is quite inappropriate, I suggest, under the circumstances when I am called properly after all the points that can conceivably be made have been made. To continue a debate on this kind is to absolutely guarantee that we will be sitting over into Sunday, which is something that none of us wants to see happen. Let us have a bit of sanity prevail and let us get back to the substance of the debate.

—When Senator Evans does finally get the opportunity to close the debate, in full and proper time when everybody has had the say they want to have on this matter and when he has perhaps calmed down and any substantive projectiles—
—Why don't you get back to the substance?
—I have to listen to the spew that comes out of the mouth of this ocean of factional vomit that I have to look at here every day and if I want to have my say on something, I will.
—Gracious to the last.

—Yes, gracious to the last. We all have to put up with different remarks that people want to make and Senator Evans has got a bit touchy. A bit of calming down time for him might be quite good and anyone who wants to look after his interests might like to take projectiles away from his table.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to raise with the minister and get a response to is this. When Senator Hill was putting some points to the minister about the consideration that he has given to the staff in this place—I will not go through all those again—he was interjecting over the table. Senator Hill was making the point about the transport arrangements and the minister is well aware of, as I understand it, the difficulties in getting not just senators home—we can look after ourselves in one way or another—but the staff of senators who happen to be here. Senator Hill was asking what arrangements the minister had made. What was the minister's response in interjecting over the table? It was: `Well, pass the bill tonight'.

I want to hear two things from the minister. Firstly, does the minister consider that that is genuinely an appropriate response when dealing with such an important matter of legislation? The way he wants to get it through is by setting up such a timetable of inconvenience, not just for us but for everybody else, that he will in that way try to blackmail people, in a sense, into giving in because of the inconvenience it creates to the staff in this place and to our own staff.

Secondly, since the minister says, `Well, we hoped we could get this through and that there would be some sort of orderly debate. It will be all right and we can finish at half past 5 in the morning or perhaps 6 o'clock and people can get on these planes that start at 6.55 a.m.', when he is making those remarks and responding finally, perhaps he would like to address his mind to, and in his comments tell us, why it was that it was not until around 4 o'clock that we could get a proper list of the government amendments in the order in which it wanted to deal with them?

Senator Evans cannot come into this place and say that we have been holding the government up on this debate, that the delay in this is all our fault. We have been discussing a whole range of things, listening to his people babble on just to fill in the time so he could get his act together. What he has forgotten to mention as one of the key reasons in the delay here, one of the reasons we are here tonight and probably going to be here on Saturday and perhaps Sunday, is that whoever is responsible for the conduct of this bill in this place—I take it to be the minister—has not managed to get it altogether, simply has not managed to get it done so that we could deal with the amendments in an appropriate fashion. He was not able to do that until some time around 4 o'clock today. Now he is in here at 9 o'clock, four debating hours later, saying, `This is going to take a lot longer than we thought', and presuming to blame those of us on this side of the chamber. Perhaps he will address his mind to both those matters when he does have the chance to respond.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President—
—Order! Senator Evans, that is a most inappropriate comment. Your inability does not add to the colour of this chamber.

—Since the minister has asked for questions—this seems to be an extended question time—why is he trying to ram this bill through before Christmas? Obviously the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made a promise that he would have this bill by Christmas. But the minister has actually held up the Senate, as everyone else has said today, until about 4 o'clock when he brought in his hand-written notes of the proceedings for the bill. I would suggest they were hand-written notes, not even with a thumbnail dipped in tar but maybe with dirty hands attached to it.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has broken every promise since the last election. I suggest that he break the promise he has made to have this bill by Christmas, in the same way as he has broken every other promise, and keep his record intact. He should leave it lying on the table until February and let us have an investigative look at what is happening to this legislation which the government is trying to foist on the Australian people. The minister should wake up to himself. Australia deserves a lot better than the minister is trying to give us with this legislation. It stinks.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of important points that need to be discussed at this stage of the debate on the minister's motion. The first is that the government, the Democrats and the Greens go around this country trying to tell people that the opposition in the Senate is being obstructionist. They know that that is not the case. They tried to have people believe that we held the budget up when in fact the reality was that the government got its budget in faster time this year than it ever has before. We know that next year it will get its budget even quicker because the Democrats and the Greens have already signed off on it. It is amazing that they have not signed off for the 1996 budget as well.

PARA.TAB: Earlier last week and the week before, we debated the industrial relations legislation. The government, the Greens and the Democrats again went around saying that we filibustered and that we took a long time, but, again, it was the government that had a stupid, shoddy piece of legislation that came into this chamber. It has now brought in more than 200 amendments. The government cannot blame the opposition if it brings in shoddy, badly-drafted legislation which requires government amendments when it gets into the Senate.

Now we have the Native Title Bill. We were promised back in July that we would have it in August. Then the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) promised to have it in September, then October and finally we got it just before Christmas. The minister needs to inform this chamber and the people of Australia why we need this legislation before Christmas day. Is it because Santa Claus is going to bring it and drop it down everyone's chimney? Do we have to have it passed so that everyone can get a copy of it in their Christmas stocking? What is the relevance of Christmas day? What is the importance of getting it finished now?

We are back here on 1 February. We know that this is a piece of legislation that is fraught with problems. That is demonstrated by the fact that we have before us in excess of 200 amendments. The attendants are coming around and we are receiving another amendment as I speak.

This legislation is a disgrace and the process is a disgrace. Because people will read this debate in the future, I seek leave to incorporate, not all of the running sheet because it is a bit of a mess, the first three pages of the running sheet we are using so that people can understand the shoddiness and the way the government is running this program. We were presented with this scribble at 4 o'clock this afternoon and I want to show the people of Australia how disorganised the government is. I know from previous incorporations I have made that it is technically possible for Hansard to incorporate this and I seek to do so, so that it stands as a monument to how disorganised the government's program is and what a hopeless, ad hoc piece of legislation this is and why, of course, this legislation does not need to be passed before Christmas.

This legislation could of course be dealt with far more effectively if it went to a Senate select committee, was properly discussed through sensible procedures and then dealt with properly in February when we can all come back and have a proper community debate about it and deal with it not on a Saturday—the first Saturday this Senate has sat for 34 years, and possibly the first Sunday in history.

It is absolutely crazy for senators to be here on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday. None of us can make proper decisions under those circumstances. None of us would expect any other Australian citizen to work the hours this chamber works—the hours the clerks, the transport officers, the Hansard reporters, the people in the library have to work. That is the case for people all throughout this building. Probably for each one of us in this chamber there are two or three outside. We are going to ruin their weekend, their last weekend before Christmas, because, basically, this government won the election in March that it did not expect to win. It has been cobbling together pieces of legislation ever since and this Senate always has to fix up the mess. We should not have to fix up the mess. We should deal with legislation in a sensible way.
Leave granted.
The running sheet read as follows—
