TALK.START.PARA: —The alternative to the proposal put by Minister Evans is that the Senate adjourn at midnight tonight and return to sit from nine until midnight on Monday, and, if not finished, on Tuesday, Wednesday and so on. At least that would mean that the staff, our families, all of those connected with our transport and those to whom we have made commitments for this weekend would find such commitments honoured. In the event of the alternative being accepted, the burden of those who have spoken, especially about the staff, would have been listened to by this government.

PARA.TAB: I put this question to the government: what if we do go ahead with the proposal that is before us? If we sit until midnight tonight and then from nine on Saturday morning until midnight, it is my estimation that we will not finish. We will then find that, for the first time in history, the Senate will be tempted to sit on a Sunday. I will not sit on a Sunday. If the government gets the vote because I am not here, it can be reversed.

We have sat until midnight on nine days out of 10 in the last sitting fortnight—fair enough; it is the last fortnight leading up to a break of about six weeks. But it is impossible for us to be sure that this debate can be concluded by midnight on Saturday. I therefore put the alternative—I do not put it with a great deal of rhetoric; I just put it simply—that, on the face of it, it is a better alternative to sit until midnight tonight and then sit from 9 o'clock on Monday morning, and then on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and so on until this has been properly debated and determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans in his address accused us of filibustering on the IR bill. He should go right now and talk to Senator McMullan. We cooperated with him, we did not even touch 70 per cent of the clauses, and we agreed to the program. I am glad that Senator Burns has come back into this place. I want to know why the government is operating this place in total contravention of its own IR legislation, which it passed last week with the help of those ratbags down the other end of this place. I want to know the answer to that. Senator Burns sat there and screamed across this chamber at us last week.
—I never did.

—Senator Burns did—he screamed and screamed and screamed; he never stopped—and Senator Murphy and Senator Carr were alongside him. Now Senator Burns has come in here and supported the greatest abuse. He ought to be ashamed of himself. When Senator Evans replies to us, he should tell us why he is operating this chamber in contravention of the government's own bill.

—I came into this place on 1 June last year, and my first three weeks in this place were the last three weeks of the sittings. Except for Wednesdays, I think we sat until well after midnight every night of those three weeks. After my first three weeks in the Senate, I wondered whether any sanity ever prevailed in this place.Lo and behold, at the end of my first sittings, coming up to Christmas, we finished at 6 o'clock in the morning to catch a 7.10 a.m. flight to go home just one week before Christmas.

PARA.TAB: I remember talking to Senator Faulkner in the corridor just after he became Manager of Government Business in the Senate, and I distinctly remember him standing outside my office door and saying, `The one thing that we will not be doing while I am manager is sitting until all hours of the morning'. I think Senator Crane was there when Senator Faulkner said that we will not be sitting until all hours of the morning. Not only that; he is now trying to bring in another arrangement which says that we finish at 8 o'clock at night, which I guess means that we will intend to finish at eight but still go until all hours of the morning.

In Senator Evans's motion he has proposed that we sit until midnight tonight and then start again at 9 o'clock in the morning and sit until midnight on Saturday night. Like my colleague Senator Teague, I will not sit in this place on Sunday. I will not be here. I know that my colleague Senator Boswell feels the same way. There are still a number of people in Australia who believe that this parliament should not be sitting on a Sunday.

Unless we can get some sort of an undertaking from the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, that there is no intention whatsoever for this Senate to sit on a Sunday, this government deserves every condemnation that it would receive from all of the Christian churches throughout Australia. Considering Australia's history of this Senate never sitting on a Sunday, they would have every right to condemn this government for even suggesting that we should contemplate doing business in this chamber on a Sunday.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thing that I find abhorrent about the proposed sitting schedule is that we were confronted tonight with a series of amendments by the government, and just five minutes ago with some extra ones by the Greens, and that this timetable now does not give us the opportunity to consult with our constituents and with the interest groups around Australia in their normal working hours and in their normal working arrangements so that they can respond.

PARA.TAB: I have not yet had time to digest the amendment that the Greens have just put on the table, but I note that it relates very importantly to the fishing industry and to offshore and onshore interests, and I know that this is an issue that has to be debated comprehensively. How do we deal with checking this through the departments of fisheries? Senator Evans walked in here at 5 o'clock or 6 o'clock tonight and threw down a whole series of issues that have constitutional import for the states. It is their right and their prerogative to give us advice, which should happen on a routine, normal working day. If Senator Evans had given us those amendments this morning at 9 o'clock, we would have had the opportunity to discuss them with our state colleagues and get advice, but we cannot do that on a Saturday. I find that totally objectionable.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't do it on a Sunday either.

—We certainly cannot do it on a Sunday. We should be working in order to meet the proper requirements. This proposal would mean that people throughout Australia would be called in for additional work at undue times and with undue inconvenience. It is a shocking and disgraceful abrogation of responsibility on the part of the government.

—I think honourable senators will recall that before dinner, in the committee stage of this debate, I made a comment that it was clear that there was a majority of senators who wanted to have this measure determined. Under those circumstances, I indicated that we should exercise our rights under the standing orders and the procedures of this place to ensure that all of the clauses, all of the amendments and all of the details of the legislation are properly explained so that senators are able to review the legislation, and that we ought to then sit on Monday, Tuesday and, if necessary, Wednesday to look at them.

PARA.TAB: The proposition that is before us at present is to sit tomorrow. Quite legitimate concerns have been expressed about the staff of this place and about our own staff—a number of other people who are not actually in this chamber. I think it is reasonable to assume—though I would not necessarily bet on it—that the government has had consultations with the representatives of the staff. I do not know that.

What happens if we have not got to the end of the program by tomorrow night? Do we sit on Sunday? Do we adjourn until Monday? What happens? Senator Teague has made his point. When that possibility was put forward, I told a couple of people that we would be suspending sittings and, come Sunday, there would not even be a Lord's Prayer because the sittings will have been suspended. I thought that we could have the Lord's Prayer and perhaps half an hour of bible readings, and perhaps every senator should start off their contributions with a verse from the Bible—the book of Job would probably be the one.

I put it to the Senate that my preference would be to move an amendment to omit `Saturday, 18 December 1993' and to insert `Monday, 20 December 1993'. I do not know that that is the majority view. I am not going to move such an amendment. From informal discussions, there are a fair few for it and there are a fair few against it. It does not seem as though such an amendment would be supported, so I will not move it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the Senate that the practice of the Senate is not to call the mover to close the debate if other senators indicate that they wish to speak. It is a principle which has been endorsed by the Procedure Committee, of which the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, the President and the Deputy President are all members.

—The basic difficulty with the kind of proposition that Senator Harradine advances is twofold. One is the huge problem of getting any transport in and out of Canberra in the Christmas week for senators, even more so if the House of Representatives were to come back to endorse the bill that was passed. There is a huge difficulty in that respect, far more so at this time of the year than any other time of the year.

PARA.TAB: Associated with that is the fact that quite a number of senators have other really quite substantial commitments next week which were made in an entirely reasonable expectation that next week would be free. Those commitments include, in a number of cases, overseas visits—not in my case, I hasten to add—and family holidays and things of that kind have been prepared, which simply makes life very difficult. Moreover, a not irrelevant consideration is the cost to the taxpayers of transporting people out of Canberra and back in a situation where that well may be able to be avoided.

The second thing that I want to say is that it does need to be appreciated that, provided we do not waste too much time with procedural wrangles and carry-on of the kind that we have been engaged in for all too many hours today, it is perfectly possible to move through and debate properly the issues involved in this legislation within a reasonable time. I say that because the much maligned running sheet that honourable senators have before them makes the situation clear—and there has been an acceptance on all sides that that is an appropriate way of grouping the issues. It involves not 250 separate debates on 250-odd separate amendments. There are just 39 cognate debates proposed on the running sheet that honourable senators have in front of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still have the separate issues within them to deal with. Don't kid yourself.

—It is my understanding that quite a number of the amendments that are listed in the different amendment sheets and that have been incorporated in the running sheet will not in fact be pursued. So it is quite possible to have a sequence of 39 separate, substantive debates on 39 separate, substantive issues in the time that we have available.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, I genuinely thought, because of the discussions that I had had and the cooperation that I had had with the leaders on the other side in a number of private discussions earlier in the day, that there was a real willingness on the part of those opposite to cooperate in debating, in a measured and expeditious way, the matters in issue. I also know—it as not appropriate to retail in this place private conversations—that it is the case that it was thought worthwhile in the discussions I had with those leading this debate on the other side to spend the time on getting the running sheet right, getting the amendments right, getting the paper flow right, in order to avoid much more substantial time wasting and difficulties in the chamber.

I am doing my best to organise this material in a way that it is able to be dealt with in the time available. I did, in a wild feat of optimism, believe that it might be possible—if we were prepared to sit very late tonight—to finish this and get out of here by early tomorrow morning, which would be an optimal result for absolutely everybody. It obviously did not prove to be the case. Under those circumstances, we took an early opportunity to make clear what the intentions were.

If we do sit until midnight tonight and get quickly back to the substance of this bill, as I hope we can; and, if we do sit from 9 a.m. tomorrow and do sit until possibly late tomorrow night, it ought to be reasonably possible to deal with those 39 packages of amendments, all of which, so far, people have indicated a willingness to debate and to vote upon together. It ought to be possible to do it.

There are difficult and serious issues; they are complex issues. They have to be debated and some hours have to be devoted to them. but it ought to be possible in that time. If we set ourselves the target of doing it by tomorrow night, some of the problems that are being intimated need not arise.

I am not going to track back over the reason why the legislative program is as it is. We obviously have had difficulties all this session; we debated for only five hours actual legislation in the first three weeks of this session. There have been obvious problems in the conduct of this program in recent weeks. There are obvious problems with the fact that, quite apart from this Native Title Bill, we had nine major packages of legislation to somehow deal with as from yesterday afternoon through to today. They are all matters that those opposite wanted to debate and that they spent a lot of time contributing to the debate on. And that, together with the desire to get things in an expeditious fashion, has created the problem we have. But it is a soluble problem; if we would just shut up and get on with the business of debating this substantive legislation, we can solve this particular problem.

Finally, as to the implications for staff, unhappily, it is only on a very selective basis that we hear concern for the staff in this place. We do not hear concern for the staff when people speak on the adjournment with sometimes multiples of people speaking for up to an hour or an hour and a half after this place gets up. We do not hear concern for staff when people do want to indulge themselves in debating endlessly pieces of legislation that simply do not need it.

Of course, the interests of the staff in this place would be much better served if we could debate reasonable hours and get our legislation finished in a reasonable time. But if the staff is asked what its preference is as between this week and coming back next week, I would be very interested to know what its response is. A great many people would very much like this session to be concluded, completed and for us to be out-of-the-way and out of their hair so people can get back to some degree of normality in their lives in this place.

I did raise with Senator Sibraa the problems involved in the mechanics of this place—the staffing, the personnel issues—that would be associated with having to run into tomorrow, which I hope very much can be avoided. I know that he, as the President of the Senate, who has been voted for by a majority of senators to exercise that role, which he does with great distinction, is concerned about this and has been taking every measure that he possibly can to minimise the staffing resources that will necessary to service tomorrow. That might lead to some inconvenience. I think that we all ought to be prepared to put up with that inconvenience if we are serious about recognising the position of our staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Sunday?

—I hope very much that we can avoid running through the weekend, running into Sunday. I respect the consciences of those senators. Clearly, not everyone in this place has the same concerns, but a number of individuals do. It may be possible, if we do go into Sunday, to deal with that by pairing arrangements of a generous kind, or something of that sort.

PARA.TAB: I simply conclude on the point that I hope very much indeed we can avoid running over that long. I hope very much that we conclude this matter by a reasonable time tomorrow. Despite the size and complexity of the bill and the issues that are involved in this legislation—I have discussed this with those leading the debate for the opposition; they have conceded this point, even if they are not prepared to do so publicly in this chamber—the size of this debate is manageable if we exercise a bit of self-discipline and get on with the substantive issues, as I now propose that we do.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed.
Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (3)Clause 4, page 6, table containing outline of Act, after the entry relating to Part 10, insert the following entry:

SPEECH.PARA: " 1OA Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title:
This Part provides for the appointment of a
Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title.".
After Part 10, page 84, insert the following new Part:

PARA.TAB: "194A.(1) As soon as practicable after the commencement of this Part and after the commencement of the first session of each Parliament, a joint committee of members of the Parliament, to be known as the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title, must be appointed.

SPEECH.PARA: "(2) The Parliamentary Joint Committee must consist of 10 members, of whom:
(a) 5 must be senators appointed by the Senate; and (b) 5 must be members of the House of Representatives appointed by that House.

PARA.TAB: "(3) The appointment of members by a House must be in accordance with that House's practice relating to the appointment of members of that House to serve on joint select committees of both Houses.
"(4) A person is not eligible for appointment as a member if he or she is:
(a) a Minister; or
(b) the President of the Senate; or
(c) the Speaker of the House of Representatives; or

SPEECH.PARA: (d) the Deputy-President and Chairman of Committees of the Senate; or
(e) the Chairman of Committees of the House of Representatives.
"(5) A member ceases to hold office:
(a) when the House of Representatives expires or is dissolved; or
(b) if he or she becomes the holder of an office referred to in a paragraph of subsection (4); or
(c) if he or she ceases to be a member of the House by which he or she was appointed; or
(d) if he or she resigns his or her office as provided by subsection (6) or (7), as the case requires.

PARA.TAB: "(6) A member appointed by the Senate may resign his or her office by writing signed and delivered to the President of the Senate.
"(7) A member appointed by the House of Representatives may resign his or her office by writing signed and delivered to the Speaker of that House.
"(8) A House may appoint one of its members to fill a vacancy among the members of the Parliamentary Joint Committee appointed by that House.
"194B. Subject to this Part, all matters relating to the Parliamentary Joint Committee's powers and proceedings must be determined by resolution of both Houses.
"194C. The Parliamentary Joint Committee's duties are:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)to consult extensively about the implementation and operation of this Act with:

TAB.TAB: (i)groups of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders; and
(ii)industry organisations; and
(iii)Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments; and
(iv) other appropriate persons and bodies; and

PARA.TAB: (b)to report from time to time to both Houses on the implementation and operation of this Act; and
(c)to examine each annual report that is prepared by the President of the NNTT and of which a copy has been laid before a House, and to report to both Houses on matters:

TAB.TAB: (i)that appear in, or arise out of, that annual report; and
(ii)to which, in the Parliamentary Joint Committee's opinion, the Parliament's attention should be directed; and

PARA.TAB: (d)At the end of 2 years after the commencement of this Part, to inquire into and, as soon as practicable after the inquiry has been completed, to report to both Houses on:

TAB.TAB: (i)the effectiveness of the NNTT; and
(ii)the extent to which there are recognised State/Territory bodies; and
(iii)the appropriateness of powers of delegation exercisable by the Registrar under this Act; and
(iv)the extent of extinguishment or impairment of native title rights and interests as a result of the operation of this Act; and
(v)the operation of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund established by Part 9; and
(vi)the effect of the operation of this Act on land management; and

SPEECH.PARA: (e)to inquire into any question in connection with its duties that is referred to it by a House, and to report to that House on that question.

PARA.TAB: "194D. This Part ceases to be in force at the end of 5 years after the Parliamentary Joint Committee is first appointed.".

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of these amendments is to introduce a provision for a parliamentary joint committee on native title, which was recommended by the Senate committee in the course of its deliberations. It will contribute very usefully to the continued oversight of the process under this bill. There are plenty of precedents for statutory committees being created for important policy areas. This is another appropriate one.

PARA.TAB: The difference between amendment No. 44A—the form of the amendment which I now move, which is circulated on a separate sheet of paper—and the amendment No. 44 in the sheet that was previously circulated is simply that we have added an additional subclause (d), which sets out the areas that the committee might usefully address in reviewing the implementation of this legislation. It also deals with the effectiveness of the tribunals and the extent to which they are recognised state and territory bodies and so on.

One issue we have said it would be appropriate for the committee to review is the effect of this act on land management. There is an intention to acknowledge the reality that state and territory land management issues are a very crucial dimension in the effective implementation of this legislation. Their interests must be very much kept in mind in the implementation of this legislation over time.

That is the intention of this provision. I believe that it is uncontroversial. It was the subject of at least a minimal degree of bipartisan support. Accordingly, I hope that it can be quickly agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment could properly be entitled `Let's shut the gate after the horse has bolted'. During the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, Democrat senators were suitably embarrassed at the range of concerns that were raised that had not necessarily occurred to everybody.

PARA.TAB: Senator Reynolds said, `Why don't we have a committee to look into this'. There used to be jokes about that sort of thing. When a problem cannot be resolved, the worst way to get around it is to have a committee. Senator Reynolds, who had a bright spark idea, said, `Let's have a joint parliamentary committee to oversee the operation of this act. Then as these problems come up, we'll sort them all out'.

That should really only underline that what some people want to do is pass this legislation when they are not aware, for example, of its consequences on land management; they cannot even hazard a guess. Presumably, the Democrats would not have suggested that there be an inquiry into the effect of this bill on land management after two years if they knew what the answer was. Despite the fact that they do not know the answer, they are happy to say, `Let's give it a run'.

They also want to look at the appropriateness of the powers of a delegation exercisable by the registrar. Is that not something that we ought to be able to sort out now? Should we not sort that out before we give the registrar those powers? Why do we say, `We will look at it in a couple of years'? It seems all too easy.

The coalition is saying that it is not a bad thing to monitor legislation and see its practical impact. Heaven knows, people would say that we should do that far more often than we do. But one could make the case very easily that the establishment of this committee is a Linus blanket to the Democrats and the Greens, who say, `Don't worry. We know that you know about these problems and we know that you know a parliamentary process is being trodden on. We know that this bill is going through without appropriate consideration to the detail of the matter. We know that it could have consequences far beyond those that we now perceive'.

If that were not the case, if everybody understood what the bill meant and there were not any problems with it—in other words, if parliament had a clue what it was doing—we would not have about 200 amendments to a bill that has only 200 clauses. That in itself should tell us that we are now sailing in very dark waters.

We are not too sure of this bill's impact on, or its interaction with, state legislation and how it will all pan out. Instead of someone turning on a light, they are saying, `Let's look at where we will arrive in two years'. It is really quite a disgraceful way to respond to the very large concerns about the detail of this bill.

I do not say that in terms of the substance of the principles of the bill. The committee would not necessarily show there was one better way to respond to Mabo No. 2; that is another matter. Let us assume for the moment that there is only this way. We do not agree with that point; we think there are other ways. We think our way is preferable. But we are now talking about this response.

I am not saying that the government is expecting the committee to cast light on the substance of this response. It is saying, `We are not too worried about the detail. The committee can fix it up later'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.

—Senator Spindler interjects, `That's not true'. But it begs the question: if the government were sure that this legislation was right and that it was the appropriate and most principled way to go and that there were no unforeseen, hazardous consequences to this bill, it would not need a watchdog.

PARA.TAB: We are not talking about, for example, the establishment of the National Crime Authority, which has a joint parliamentary committee to oversee it. We have very good reason for having a joint parliamentary committee to oversee that authority because of its extra police powers. We are not talking about the joint parliamentary committee that oversees ASIO, for example, because of its activities. It needs to report back to the parliament in some way without coming back into the full and open parliament. This is not that sort of system.

We have a bill. Everything will operate in public and be above board. Those who support this proposal are in effect saying, `It's all too hard. We want this passed by Christmas because either the Democrats, the Greens or the government will chicken out. They do not have the stomach to hold with this until February. Therefore, we cannot give this the proper detailed consideration it should have. So we will establish a joint parliamentary committee, which will make everybody feel better because it can report back every now and then about what happens and the consequences of this bill'.

The government should be concerned now about the consequences of this bill. Senator Spindler should be worried now about the effect of this act on land management. He should want to know now the answer about the appropriateness of the delegation powers of the registrar. He should be concerned now about a whole lot of other matters.

We do not say that this committee is a bad thing. If the government is going to pass this bill, fly blind and sail in the dark; if it refuses to turn on a light and use the proper parliamentary process to try to get the detail of this bill right; if it insists on having this bill in response to Mabo No. 2 and it absolutely refuses to get the detail right, perhaps this committee might be very helpful.

We say that a far better course of action would be for the government to get it right in the first place. People who have come in with concerns and gone away half happy thinking, `That is a nice suggestion; the parliament will have a committee to look at it', have been sucked in in a monumental way. Once this legislation is passed and has the force of law everything is going to happen according to the bill. The committee is not going to change the bill. It is not going to rush in here in March and says, `Whoops, we made a mistake, let's fix this up.'

The consequence is that once this bill becomes valid things happen. Land grants are made. Property changes hands. People lose rights and people gain rights. What the government is saying, in effect, is, `Let's have a look in two years and if we don't like what we have done we will worry about it then'. I think it is absolutely disgraceful. I would be very pleased to hear both from Senator Spindler and Senator Chamarette as to why they think this is an appropriate way to deal with the unforeseen consequences of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone has displayed a lot of creative talent in ascribing to us various motives and reasons for this provision. It is simply one which will enable us to monitor the provisions of the Native Title Bill. No-one denies that we are dealing with a very complex piece of legislation. No-one would claim that we can foresee every possible consequence, or that we can foretell that every provision in this bill is going to function as it is intended.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats, the Greens and the Aboriginal groups who are now in the gallery, have worked for the last 10 days to try to get this bill as right as possible. I have not seen Senator Vanstone contributing to this debate. She has had our 35 amendments since 9 December. She has not come to me and said, `Do you really think this will work? Could we do it in a different way?' She has not said boo. She has not suggested different ways of doing this.

I believe that the effort that has gone into this bill has been sustained and meticulous and we have tried to cover every possible base. Nevertheless, I think it is prudent that we provide for a parliamentary committee to oversee the operation of this bill and monitor it so that government can be advised of possible changes that might need to be made in the future. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister about the sunset clause. It ceases to be in force five years after the parliamentary joint committee is first appointed. How did the government arrive at the figure of five years? Five years seems to me to be a reasonable time to monitor how the bill is going, but that committee dissolves at the end of each parliament. I do not think five years is a very practicable period because the normal parliamentary term is three years. Could the minister tell us how he envisages it working?

—I think the view was that the crucial period in the implementation of this legislation would be the first years. During this period any bugs or flaws that did exist would be likely to show up. Five years is probably a fairly generous estimate of the time needed to scrutinise the implementation phase. It can always be changed if people think it is too long. The general principle of having sunset clauses for scrutiny committees of this kind—and, in fact, many other bodies—is a good one, as I think has been accepted on both sides of the chamber, because it forces us to reconsider the value from time to time of the particular organisational resource we have established.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Panizza is asking for an explanation, it is a pretty arbitrary figure that has been chosen, but it was thought to coincide with the period within which all likely possible bugs in the implementation would well and truly have shown up, including things like the implications for state land management. There might be some unforeseen consequence here or there. One has to acknowledge that possibility. It is important that we have a mechanism available to quickly respond to that. With a bit of accumulated expertise, people with an interest in the issue can respond to the problems and make appropriate recommendations to the government. If Senator Panizza wants to suggest any variation on that period we have an open mind on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some concerns about the idea of a joint parliamentary committee. I see it as unlikely to achieve much. I think that many of the problems will become highly politicised. I feel that this committee will result in enormous costs to the Commonwealth especially if it runs for five years. Senator Short has already outlined tonight many of the costs that the Native Title Bill will create. In comparison with the costs that are going to be foisted on the states, I think that this is a lesser cost. I would like the minister to outline exactly how much he thinks it is going to cost to run a joint parliamentary committee like this for five years.

—I am not in a position to give an estimate of that. I do not imagine that there would be substantial secretarial resources involved in this. It may be a half time job for one secretarial person. I do not know. We would have to take advice on that. Then there are the costs of moving people, out of sitting periods, to committee hearings from time to time to take evidence. Senator O'Chee could probably make his own estimate from a quick reading of the Senate accounts about the cost of comparable committees over the years. I do not imagine it would be a major cost.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps another important aspect of this is the demonstration effect that is involved in implementing a committee of this kind. It is a demonstration of seriousness of purpose on the part of the parliament in responding in an ongoing way to the implementation of this very important legislation. There are some things that are spelt out in skeletal form in the legislation, like the creation of the land fund and so on. It may well be that there will be considerable interest in the way in which that part of the legislation—which will take some time to gear up—operates in practice. Opinions may differ about this. It was a unanimous recommendation of the committee, I think, and certainly one that seemed to the government appropriate to accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —To save a long and ongoing debate, I invite Senator Spindler to stop dragging out that dreary little argument that he raises. He said, `Where was Senator Vanstone? My 35 amendments have been out for nine days and she hasn't come to see me.' He seems upset that I have not come around and said, `What about this amendment? Could we help you here and improve it there?' I think we need to keep things in perspective. Their people, but for the last election, could meet in a phone box.

PARA.TAB: It is not my responsibility, nor anybody else's, to come around and help Senator Spindler fix up his own incompetent amendments. Let us get this into perspective. If one has an interest in a bill, one does not rush around every minute of the day asking Senator Spindler what he thinks about it. Lord spare me, one would go insane. If one has an interest in a bill, it does not necessarily manifest itself by one running around to Senator Spindler, saying, `Oh, Senator Spindler, what do you think of this?' Senator Spindler could save his breath by not raising that tiresome argument again. If he keeps raising it I will keep getting up and responding. He is just one member of this place elected by the same percentage of the population as the rest of us. He is just as entitled to his views as we are. If he believes that he is entitled to put out some amendments, photostat them and circulate them, and that we will come running to him, he sadly misunderstands the perspective of this. He could save his breath.

Senator Kemp raised a point with me a minute ago. He may wish to speak on this. The minister may have a simple response. I notice that the parliamentary joint committee is going to be made up of 10 members—five senators and five members of the House of Representatives. What are the arrangements as to the representation on that committee of government members, coalition members, Democrats and Greens to be appointed by each house?

As it stands, as Senator Kemp pointed out to me, we could come back here in February, want to set up a joint parliamentary committee and, by force of votes of the government and the Democrats, fill it with Democrat and government members. The way Senator Spindler has been arguing, he would say that if we have not been around and asked him what we think of a joint committee we have no right to sit on it. He would just fill it up with Labor people and Democrats. It is a reasonable question and I would be happy if the minister would respond to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that the organisational precedent for this was one of the more recently established joint parliamentary committees inquiring into the Australian Securities Commission. There has been no discussion of which I am aware about how the composition of the committee would be determined. That is a matter for discussion between the parties. I am sure the great diplomacy of my good friend the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) will produce a result that is reasonably acceptable.

—The practice, as I understand, has been to come to some type of agreement, and that has generally happened. But, as Senator Kemp pointed out, what happens if we do not agree? Is it force of numbers then? The normal practices are that we agree and we say, `Look, we'd like to have five government members and five non-government members'. That is the normal practice and I see that it says that is what we have to do. But if we cannot come to some sensible person's agreement, what happens then? Is the committee not appointed because it cannot be done in accordance with the usual practice or do we just go to a vote of this place?
—Democracy will prevail.
—I would appreciate the minister putting his answer on the record.
—I just have.

—This committee will monitor the impact of this bill and look at unforeseen consequences. The committee, on the basis of its monitoring, will presumably make reports and recommendations to the government. We may well be faced with the dilemma that the committee finds a whole host of problems and the government runs roughshod over those concerns, as it is riding roughshod over the concerns of people today. Can the minister give an assurance to the chamber that the recommendations of this committee will be looked at seriously?

—I think our good faith in this respect is demonstrated by the fact that some of these amendments pick up all the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which was established to look at the terms of this bill and which brought forward recommendations. Obviously, as always, no government will commit itself in advance to the implementation of any committee's report about anything. But we would expect the government to take very seriously indeed a report—whether it is done on an ad hoc basis on particular issues or whether it is the two-year review proposal that is also built into this—of a committee constituted in this way. That is as much as I think Senator Kemp could reasonably ask me to say at this stage.
—The minister has written that five will be senators and five will be members. Why has he not also put in here that five will be government members and five will be non-government members?

—I understand that this is just a legislative precedent. For statutory committees one does not necessarily go into the same degree of detail, in the terms of the statute itself, as one would in a resolution constituting a committee. No doubt this will need to be supplemented by such a resolution in due course. I think that is the normal practice and precedent when one is talking about the statutory creation of committees.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, it simply has not been the subject of discussion and consultation. I think it is appropriate that that occur before we go down that particular path. We certainly undertake to go through a process of consultation about that before the committee is established, which I hope will be some time early in the new year.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 5 and 6.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans indicated in relation to a question put to him earlier that the debate on clause 6 might be the appropriate point to respond. Is that correct?

—It is in relation to 6A. But since we are in a twilight zone, pending Senator Chamarette's moving of new clause 6A, I am happy to respond now to the question Senator Vanstone raised earlier. Senator Vanstone asked me earlier on what the implications of section 10(3) of the Racial Discrimination Act might be for those provisions of the legislation which relate to the possible vesting of native title in a corporate body. Senator Vanstone was referring to the provision of the Racial Discrimination Act, which talks in terms of the law containing a provision. It authorises property owned by an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander to be managed by another person without the consent of the Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander.

PARA.TAB: The short point in reply is that the provisions in this bill that do provide for that form of management of native title certainly do not provide for such management to occur without consent; rather, the land will continue to be fully managed by the native titleholders and it is intended that those holders will wholly control in turn the body corporate. I think it is appropriate to debate this further when we get to the provisions about body corporate, but to the extent that it raises questions about the Racial Discrimination Act's application, that is the answer. These provisions are wholly outside any possible application of 10(3) of the RDA.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to leave the substantive debate on this until we come to the question of the—
—I don't think there is much more to say, is there?

—Fair enough. With the greatest of respect, the minister is getting a bit like Senator Spindler. He thinks that what he has to say is the essence and truth of everything and if only everyone else would shut up everything would be okay. Just every now and then the minister is perhaps mistaken.
—I was just drawing your attention—with your consent—to the terms of the relevant provision which you didn't have in front of you.

—I understand that. I am not wanting to take long. If the minister lets me commence to say what I want to say without interrupting, I might be able to do it a bit more quickly. I think it is worth raising at this point that, because of the amendment that the Greens want to move, the minister has a concern with the Racial Discrimination Act and he might therefore like to turn his mind to section 10(3). I draw the minister's attention to that now and outline the concerns that we have so that when we do come to the point of debating this, we do not then have to postpone consideration because the Greens have not had a chance to consider the point. Section 10(3) of the Racial Discrimination Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a law contains a provision that:
(a) authorizes property owned by an Aboriginal or a Torres Strait Islander to be managed by another person without the consent of the Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander; or
(b) prevents or restricts an Aboriginal or a Torres Strait Islander from terminating the management by another person or property owned by the Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander.

I think that needs to be looked at in relation to the holding of native title by a corporation—not by consent, by the fact of this act. It is not a case that people can intermittently say, `We don't want you to hold our land or our title in a corporation'. There is no choice about that matter. So it is a function of the Native Title Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no.
—I see puzzled faces. People who might not agree might like to consider that before we get to that point.

—I clarify, in case there is any uncertainty about this, that there is no provision that compulsorily requires native title to be vested in a body corporate. It is just an organisational option that is available to a group of native titleholders should it so choose voluntarily that particular form of organisation. As we all know with blocks of flats and all the rest of it, we might have some common body corporate administering on our behalf, but we are all members of it with an equal say and we voluntarily participate in that particular process. I do not know whether that is the best possible analogy, but it is an example of the voluntary nature of what is proposed here. Those provisions in the bill, when we get to them, that deal with body corporate have to be understood as simply creating an organisational option. They do not force anybody to do anything.

—I direct the minister to the provisions of clause 53(1) and ask whether that does not actually require the tribunal to order, in effect, that the title be vested in the body corporate, irrespective of any objections by individuals.

—I am sorry. There is a subsequent amendment, as I understand it, which will be moved which makes clear that this will be optional in the way that I described it. I had thought that was incorporated in the text of the bill at the moment. That is something about which there has been a policy agreement, but it has not yet got there. That will be the product of a further amendment to be moved later on.
—Which we do not have yet? Do we have that now? Do we have it or not?

—I am not sure precisely what the status of that amendment is. It is some distance down the track. I have not turned my mind directly to it. There are Greens and Democrat amendments which bear upon this and I think that was one of the matters that was subject to further discussion by the advisers. Our scheme was for this to be sorted out by regulation, but I think the preferred approach now is to do it in the terms of the statute. —I have one small question. Senator Alston raised this matter initially. TALK.START.PARA: —These are questions about the detailed operations, I understand, of clause 53. We are not at clause 53. The only way that clause 53 came into the debate is because I was asked a question about the possible application of the Racial Discrimination Act to unspecified provisions of the act. We were about to debate the Racial Discrimination Act, so it was not an unreasonable question and I sought to answer it.

PARA.TAB: There is a question that has been opened up about bodies corporate. At the moment, in short, the bill provides that the title has to be vested by the tribunal in some body corporate, but the nature of that body corporate—whether it is a company or a trust, and the way in which it is put together—is left to be sorted out by regulation, with all the issues associated with that about personal succession and the rest of the issues that Senator Panizza mentioned. That is an interesting question about which there is something of a division of opinion. Some discussion is going on, I am advised right now, to try and reach some agreement because there are different views within the Aboriginal community about how best to do that.

There is a degree of flexibility and obvious voluntariness about it because of the way the thing is constructed at the moment and what was intended to be incorporated in the actual regulations that will spell this out in detail. The question is whether there is a greater degree of voluntariness or optionality about it being of the non-corporate kind. That is something that is being sorted out. The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—The minister has responded to the question but I remind the committee that it is clauses 5 and 6 that are before us and I ask that contributions be confined to clauses 5 and 6.
Clauses agreed to.
Proposed new clause 6A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 6, page 7, insert the following new clause:
``6A. (1) Nothing in this Act affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.
``(2) Subsection (1) does not affect the validation of past acts by or in accordance with this Act.''.

SPEECH.PARA: The relationship between this piece of legislation and the Racial Discrimination Act has a very interesting history. If it had not been for the Racial Discrimination Act, then possibly the Murray Islanders would not have been successful in obtaining the High Court decision in June 1992 because of its interaction with the actions of the Queensland government. Also, if it were not for the Racial Discrimination Act, then this legislation would not be being pushed through the parliament at this pace at this point in time.

PARA.TAB: The High Court decision of June 1992 excited very little attention in the mining or pastoral industry because it was such a conservative decision. Basically, it held some good news for Aboriginal people, which was that it recognised the legal lie of terra nullius and acknowledged the existence of native title and prior occupancy of Australia by Aboriginal people.

The bad news though, from the point of view of justice for Aboriginal people, was that the High Court decision also said that valid acts of state and federal governments were able to extinguish native title and, of course, had done so for 200 years. It was only the realisation that Australia is becoming a signatory to the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the existence of the Racial Discrimination Act of 1975 that caused the question mark of compensation to native titleholders to cause anxiety and concern to enter the commercial side of our community. This led to the clamour for certainty and validation.

The Greens feel that legislation based on the good news—the recognition of native title, the exposure of terra nullius as a lie and the effort to bring about reparation and justice—would have been a far more worthy basis for this present legislation. Nonetheless, it is that clamour that has been coming from the various interests in our community which are concerned that they may have to make reparation to native titleholders for the actions of the last 200 years that has led to this bill being pushed at the rate it has been.

In order to validate any titles that have been in doubt because of the action of the Racial Discrimination Act, then this bill is required and the Racial Discrimination Act has to be suspended because in actual fact native title rights are being removed by that validation process. That is the way in which the Racial Discrimination Act has been incorporated in this legislation, initially in the preamble as a special measure, and that the legislation has not been held to be in subjection to the Racial Discrimination Act.

Despite the fact that the Racial Discrimination Act is enabling the validation of titles, it is important that the rest of the bill should not have the unintended effect of denying Aboriginal and Islander people protection against existing discriminatory laws, either state or federal. During the time when the doctrine of terra nullius was in force, a large number of discriminatory laws were passed. These laws are still in existence and could be used to authorise further discriminatory acts in the future. In many instances this could just confirm dispossessions that occurred under terra nullius and allow for similar dispossessions for Aboriginal people.

Therefore, the concern that has been caused by the possible overriding of the Racial Discrimination Act has been a matter of considerable debate during the time that this legislation has been prepared. Proposed clause 6A relates to the inconsistency between this bill and the Racial Discrimination Act and is intended to provide that nothing in this bill affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.

While it is the parliament's intention that the bill should be a special measure within the meaning of section 8 of the RDA, if the bill is held not to be a special measure there is a risk that provisions of the bill may be construed as overriding the Racial Discrimination Act. Proposed clause 6A ensures that the bill, like all other laws, will be interpreted as not affecting the operation of the RDA and will thereby implement parliament's intention. Subclause (2) ensures that the validation of past acts by or in accordance with this act are not affected. That is the reason why this amendment is being proposed by the Greens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette is right in saying that there has been a long and intense history of debate, discussion and consultation on the relationship between this bill and the Racial Discrimination Act. The government has been rather reluctant to try to find explicit language to deal with this question. We have been concerned on the one hand that such are the benefits for Aboriginal people in the legislation that it might be construed as discriminatory against non-Aboriginal people. We think that particular anxiety is covered off, however, by squarely acknowledging that the legislation is, almost in its entirety, properly regarded as a special measure. We have said as much in the preamble.

PARA.TAB: The concern was that if we overemphasised the specific need for continued consistency with the RDA, perhaps that might somehow be put at risk, or other unforeseen consequences may arise. Nonetheless, after discussion with the Greens, the Democrats and representatives of leading Aboriginal groups—all of whom were very concerned given, as Senator Chamarette has said, the whole long history of the role that the Racial Discrimination Act has played in creating some semblance at last of justice for Aboriginal people in this country that there be no misunderstanding about the basic intent that the RDA continue in effective operation—we are willing to accept, as I previously foreshadowed, this amendment. It makes clear that the Racial Discrimination Act will apply to the provisions of this act and conduct carried out under it. But also, of course, this provision could not in any way affect the validity of past acts which are validated by the Native Title Bill. That is made clear by subclause (2).

This does seem to be an amendment which satisfies the concerns that have been expressed.There has never been any doubt about our good faith in wanting the RDA to apply. We have just been concerned about possible unforeseen technical consequences flowing from its application. I think those concerns are met by this drafting. Accordingly, I thank Senator Chamarette for her amendment and accept it accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I am intrigued that such a simple proposition, which one presumes has been put to the government constantly over recent months, has until now been rejected. I presume that is because the whole point of the government's reluctance was that there may well be unforeseen consequences. In other words, there may have been unintended breaches of the Racial Discrimination Act which were designed to allow for other actions after balancing competing interests, and the government did not want a situation where those acts in good faith were struck down.

PARA.TAB: One example which springs to mind is validating titles which might have been granted contrary to the RDA or ensuring public access to beaches, even if native title was granted in respect of that area. Is the minister saying to us that he is now prepared to accept this amendment because of the political persuasiveness of its advocates, or was it because he has recently had legal advice that contradicts all of what presumably led to the government's reluctance to date?

Perhaps, in answering, the minister will also indicate to the committee whether the acceptance of such an amendment would mean that the quite clear discrimination in the act in favour of assessors—`as far as practical' I think is the expression—who are either Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders would seem to be a clear discrimination in favour of that group. Is the government saying that that would not be affected?

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that things which are clearly discriminatory in favour of Aboriginal people are covered by the special measures provision. We believe that the reference in the preamble, which will remain of course, to the act being intended to be seen to be a special measure `for the advancement of protection of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders' will be sufficient to cover those sorts of situations. Equally, we believe that the drafting of subclause (2) of this amendment is sufficient to cover the concern that has been around about the possible impact of the RDA on validation of past acts.

PARA.TAB: As to the other specific matter that Senator Alston raised on the question of access to beaches, there is I suppose a question mark which does still exist in one's mind. I am being perfectly straightforward and frank about this—if Senator Alston is interested in listening to the reply; I am not sure that he is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I was acknowledging the graciousness of your reply.

—I thank Senator Alston. On the question of beaches, the bill specifically provides that, notwithstanding the possible existence of native title so far as a particular stretch of beach is concerned, the principle of public access shall override that. It is not inconceivable that that might possibly be construed as being a discriminatory act against Aboriginal people in breach of the RDA.

PARA.TAB: If that is a problem, the parliament will just have to deal with that when it arises in an explicit way. But at least we will know that it is a problem and it will not be purely speculative in the way of so many of these phantasms and spectres that have been conjured up.

TALK.START.PARA: —See how we go, eh? Is that the approach?

—Senator Vanstone can respond that way and be chirpily cynical, and grumpy, and all the rest of the things that she is so good at. But I am trying to respond, in a very frank and direct way, to concerns that have been expressed by a number of different people from a number of different perspectives. There have been concerns expressed by the mining and pastoral industries and there have been concerns expressed by Aboriginal people that maybe the pro-Aboriginal things would be ruled out by the act.

PARA.TAB: The only other issue I can think of which has any likely bite about it is the provision in the act about beaches and guaranteeing public access. We are determined, as a matter of public policy, to preserve that principle of access to beaches. We believe that that is okay and we would be able to live with the legislation, but in the event that a court somewhere at sometime holds otherwise, that is a problem we can deal with at that time.

I am just explaining why there was a degree of reluctance to be more explicit about the RDA. It has always been a matter of fine judgment. Having regard to, but not being determined in our response by, the advocacy of Aboriginal groups, our belief is that the risk factors, if you like, associated with having a clause like this are not so great as to outweigh the utility of having a clear and resounding demonstration in the body of the legislation itself, not just the preamble, that we really do value the RDA and want to give it effective operation.

At the end of the day, I think it is important that this parliament reaffirms the role that the Racial Discrimination Act has played. It really has been one of the most seminal and important pieces of legislation in the history of this country. It is the one thing, as Senator Chamarette has said, which has given a bit of leverage for Aboriginal people to fight for justice in a whole variety of contexts. Basically, having fully considered this, I agree with her that it is appropriate that it go into the text of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it follow from that that the minister is conceding that, where a situation arises, such as beaches and perhaps other as yet unidentified apparent exceptions that need correction, the government will legislate on a case-by-case basis to override the Racial Discrimination Act?

—I am conceding that it may be necessary for the joint parliamentary committee and the government and the parliament to consider that option. I do not think it is a likely issue that will arise, but it is a possible issue. I have to concede it is a possibility, just as in question time in a number of specific contexts that were raised earlier about the possible application of laws of fiduciary duty, we have to acknowledge that at least it is a possible conclusion that a court could conceivably come to at some time and place. If that happens, I am stating very clearly right now what the government's policy priority would be. It is that which is incorporated in this bill; namely, that issues like public access to beaches be given primacy, and that would require legislative adjustment.

PARA.TAB: I honestly do not think we have to anticipate problems of this kind. It is just a matter of recognising that, again, in something as complex as this, that may conceivably have that kind of implication. That is why it has always been a matter of fine judgment; that is why we have judged one way up until fairly recently but, for the reasons I have spelt out, that is why we have come down now on the other side—because, honestly, we do not think that risk is very great.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very concerned at the implication for beaches, and I do not think the minister should just seek to wash it aside with weasel words and future impossible considerations. It is a very real threat for all of Australia, and it has major implications. I ask the minister what specific representations were made on this issue by groups such as the Northern Territory government. Are there any conflicts in this particular area that will impact, because of the operation of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act, Northern Territory, on this specific clause and how it will be implemented?

PARA.TAB: Similarly, given that the government has recently undertaken a very important inquiry into the coastal zone resulting in a report by the Resource Assessment Commission in which the interests of indigenous people were very specifically addressed in a full chapter, I would have thought this was a matter on which the government would have taken not only legal advice but also political advice because the dispossession of beach areas right around Australia would have an impact on any local community, on local government in those particular communities and, very specifically, on the tourist industry. I am concerned that the minister has obviously taken the Greens' amendment on board in this regard, without such a critical analysis or appraisal.

Would the minister also clarify for me whether this is part of a series of other consequential amendments that flow from this particular one, and what will the import be of any subsequent amendments that arise later in our consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although there are quite a number of other amendments moved by other parties which refer to further references to the Racial Discrimination Act, it is the government's intention to accede only to this particular clause here. We believe that this accomplishes everything that people want to accomplish in terms of getting overt recognition of the role of the RDA, and we do not need to repeat that in various other places throughout. So Senator Tambling should not assume, simply because things have been moved by way of amendments and they still appear on the running sheet, that they are going to be accepted by government. That position has been made clear. This proposed new clause 6A is the important one; it is the one that does the job—and I think that has been acknowledged.

PARA.TAB: I just remind Senator Tambling of the terms of 197(2) of the bill. It states:
A law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory may confirm any existing public access to and enjoyment of:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) waterways; or
(b)beds and banks or foreshores of waterways; or
(c) coastal waters; or
(d) beaches; or
(e)areas that were public places at the end of 31 December 1993.

There is a very clear and explicit intention that the Commonwealth itself or states and territories, as the case may be, act to preserve these rights of public access. To the extent that that might intrude on some bits and pieces of native title in some locations, I think it is overwhelmingly likely that, if the point were ever made about the role of the Racial Discrimination Act in that respect, a court would hold that that is a reasonable restriction on the enjoyment of the native title in question—the fact that it has to be shared with the public in the context of public access.

PARA.TAB: In the event that there were ever to be some different holding by a court, it is a matter that could be relatively easily and quickly addressed by the parliament, and I have no doubt it then would be. I think that is the point that is understood. I would appreciate it if Senator Tambling did not import any more substance into my words tonight than I have obviously given them. It is not a case to generate some synthetic indignation or some synthetic anxiety. It is not a real problem. If it ever became one, it could be very easily fixed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take exception to having this labelled as `indignation'. I think it is a very rightful concern that affects all Australians with regard to the access to all of their beaches. Whilst I appreciate the import of other aspects of what the amendment seeks to achieve, the minister did not comment on the issue that I addressed with regard to consultations or discussions in this area that the minister has had with either the Northern Territory government or, for that matter, other state governments. It has a very obvious consequence in those areas. We do not want to create a situation that will give rise to even more legal debate about the effectiveness of the bill and whether or not key elements are unenforceable in this particular regard. The minister also did not comment on what consideration was given in this part of the bill to those recommendations that were put forward by the Resource Assessment Commission's report into the coastal zone inquiry, which is also currently before the government.

—I am not entirely clear on what the relevance of the RAC report would be, given clear policy decision by the government to preserve coastal access and so on in the way I have just described as is set out in the bill. As to the question of consultation on the whole issue of possible impact of the RDA, that has been the issue that perhaps has been the subject of more consultation, more discussion between the Commonwealth, state and territory governments than almost any other in the whole course of this legislation being on the table. There have been a number of different views expressed on both—
—And do they still have their concerns?

—It is a matter of fine judgment. I frankly acknowledge that for all the reasons that I have frankly and fully set out, because the Racial Discrimination Act cuts both ways. It operates to protect Aboriginal people against discrimination and it also operates to protect non-Aboriginal people against discrimination by pro-Aboriginal clauses in some contexts. One has to be, from both sides of the argument, very conscious as to what the implications are likely to be. We have been conscious. We made the judgment that this particular clause, on balance, has a useful declaratory effect without having any significant downside risks associated with it.

—I may not have made the Greens' point sufficiently clear when I moved this amendment. I presented the positive aspects of the inclusion of this clause in the bill which I felt were important. However, I should also point out that there are negative aspects to leaving it out. Without this clause, the bill itself that we are debating now becomes racially discriminatory. I ought to point out that all the rights that are being taken away in this legislation belong to Aboriginal people. They do not belong to anybody else. So there is no ground for non-Aboriginal people to be expressing concerns about it. It is because Aboriginal people have acknowledged that validation of existing titles is a reasonable issue for the non-Aboriginal community to address that they have allowed this particular bill to include that. Without a reference to the Racial Discrimination Act, other aspects of this will be discriminatory. So I cannot speak in stronger terms when I say that this legislation would be very flawed without such a reference.

—Section 10(3)(b) of the Racial Discrimination Act would appear to expressly outlaw any law which contains a provision that prevents or restricts the transfer of management of property owned by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. Presumably that makes it clear that it ought to be possible to transfer native title from a body corporate to individual holders. Given that that would now be an overriding provision as a result of proposed new clause 6A, could the minister indicate what section of the Native Title Bill would enable that transfer to take place, if that were the wish of the individual holders?

—I indicated earlier that the body corporate provisions of the bill were under further consideration—and I did that in detail in answer to a question from Senator Panizza. One of the matters in issue is the transferability of the interests backwards and forwards between body corporates and individuals.

PARA.TAB: My advice is that, quite apart from considerations of that kind, the most direct answer to Senator Alston about the possible application of section 10(3) of the Racial Discrimination Act to any of this is that section 10(3) is about management of property, whereas the whole issue in terms of body corporate is not about management of property but about simply being a vehicle for holding the title in question. That is why I had a sneaking suspicion my reference to body corporates for blocks of flats was an inappropriate example. Indeed, it is a particularly inappropriate example because body corporates for blocks of flats, by definition, are engaged in management functions on behalf of the individuals.

It was a very bad example because I am reminded that the intention of the body corporate provisions here is simply to have a convenient available reservoir, if you like, for the actual titleholding in question and for the convenient maintenance of that title over time. It is not intended to be a managerial body. It is just intended to be a titleholding body. I think that probably is the best immediate answer to that concern. That probably answers Senator Vanstone's concerns also, if that is right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does not proposed section 53(6) of the Native Title Bill, which provides that any agreement made by the body corporate in relation to the native title binds the common law holders, mean that the body corporate could agree that management rights be exercised by other than those common law holders?

—The body corporate is itself proposed to be completely a vehicle for the wishes, aspirations and decisions of the native titleholders themselves. However the body corporate were to act, it could only be on the basis of the actual decisions taken, the preferences expressed and the desires of the current individual native titleholders. That is my understanding. But if there is any need for further clarity, that is, again, one of the combination of issues that is being looked at overnight. It was the one substantive area of the bill that we did not have complete time to sort out in discussions over the last 24 hours.
—Oh, I see.

—Senator Campbell can say that. He is the kind of genius I know who does these things on his ear. If we had been facing the prospect of reaching this particular clause by later tonight, as I hoped originally would be the case, I would have devoted some attention to that over the dinner break to try to get it right. But in the event, quite apart from other events intruding on the dinner break, it became apparent that we would have time to deal with this properly. It really would be helpful if we could defer further consideration of that until tomorrow and the opposition can see how we have addressed some of these issues. (Quorum formed)
—In view of the concession by the minister that this is a matter that needs to be separately addressed at a later time, can I, therefore, move:

PARA.TAB: That further consideration of the amendment be postponed till a later hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston does not move that with my support because this particular amendment does not bear upon the body corporate issue.

—Of course it does. This amendment is all about whether the RDA has primacy. If we identify one area where the minister says that work still needs to be done to ascertain whether, in fact, individuals will be able to exercise their rights in accordance with the RDA or whether, in fact, they will be told that the body corporate will do it for them, that is a very live issue. If the minister does not currently have the answer, I would have thought the sensible and reasonable thing to do, in the minister's usual spirit of magnanimity, would be to allow for due consideration, at least on the minister's part, so that we can come back and have a sensible discussion tomorrow.
—It is not my amendment; it is Senator Chamarette's amendment. Senator Alston ought to be asking her about this one.
—Does the minister join me in requesting it of her?

—No, I do not think it is necessary. What I am telling Senator Alston is that it is the intention to make clear in the relevant provisions about body corporates that there is an option as to whether the native titleholders will have the title vested in a body corporate or whether they will retain it in themselves and perhaps simply have a body corporate as an agent to conduct various functions on their behalf. That is the intention: to create a voluntary and optional relationship on these matters.

PARA.TAB: As I said in answer to earlier questions, the drafting is in the process of being sorted out. I am told it has just about been sorted out. I have told those opposite the background and given them the explanation. The draft will be there tomorrow. It is the clear intention to address the issue in that way.

There is an answer anyway to the point that Senator Alston was expressing about the operation of section 10(3) of the Racial Discrimination Act. The answer is one that I have already given and it is not contingent upon this drafting exercise. That answer is that section 10(3) of the Racial Discrimination Act is about discriminatory impact on management. Since it has never been intended that the body corporate exercise itself a managerial role but simply be a repository for the title, the question, as I have just said in my last contribution, simply does not arise about the applicability of 10(3). So there is no Racial Discrimination Act question, as we understand it. To the extent that Senator Alston is asking me corollary questions about how the body corporate thing will work, I am giving him an advance indication and he will see the amendment early tomorrow, well before we reach it in the proper place in the bill.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Order! The amendment that is before us is that a new clause 6A be added to the bill. That is Senator Chamarette's motion. But now Senator Alston has moved that further consideration of this matter be deferred. That is the question before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the minister saying that he unilaterally offers to us the proposition that proposed section 53(6) of the Native Title Bill simply does not allow a body corporate to enter into any agreement in relation to management decisions?

—The object of the Racial Discrimination Act is to deal with situations where land is being managed for Aboriginal people by someone else who is not controlled by those Aboriginal people. That is why it is a problem. There is a potential discrimination in that area. That is why the Racial Discrimination Act deals with it.

PARA.TAB: It is the case that the body corporate can enter into agreements of the kind that are spelt out in 53(6) but, in doing so, they are acting completely at the direction of the native titleholders as the agent of the native titleholders, as I understand it. That is the reason why there is no question of the kind of management of the native titleholders of the kind that you are suggesting arises under the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act. It is not management of the native titleholders. Rather, the authority is running the other way. Thus those provisions do not apply in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans says there is no question. I would have thought there is no answer. Body corporate does not seem to be defined. In those circumstances, why would a body corporate in this act be any different from any other body corporate which clearly has a whole range of management responsibilities? Body corporates are the ones who arrange for lawns to be mowed, gardens to be tilled and all the daily functions of running a property. There is nothing on the face of it that would suggest that 53(6) body corporates are different animals. In those circumstances, I fail to understand why Senator Evans is prepared to simply take a stab in the dark and do what he has never been prepared to do to date—in other words, to explicitly acknowledge the primacy of the RDA—when he really does not know what the consequences will be.

—It is just a matter of misconstruing the concept of management. The kind of management issue that the Racial Discrimination Act is dealing with is where the interests of Aboriginal people are being managed by others in a way that may operate discriminatorily against their own interests. That is not the role of the body corporate as it is established here under proposed section 53. Under that proposed section, the role of the body corporate is to create someone who can act on behalf of the native titleholders.
—To do what?
—Negotiations with mining companies and things of this kind. There have to be agreements entered into. The mining company has to sign something with somebody.
—Management?

—It is not managing the native titleholders' interests; it is exercising their interests in performing functions to other external bodies or people, whether they be mining companies or people of that kind. The transmission belt runs the other way; it is from the native titleholders to the body corporate as the vehicle. We will make it an optional vehicle. At the moment, it is a compulsory vehicle. The transmission belt runs from the native titleholders to the body corporate in order to do various things—basically, just to hold the title—but, maybe on occasions, to be the formal vehicle for communications, agreements or whatever with mining companies or other outsiders. The transmission belt runs that way.
