PARA.TAB: The problem that the Racial Discrimination Act deals with is when the interests of Aboriginal people are being managed by other people over them, possibly against their interests and their will, in a discriminatory fashion. The transmission is running the other way. It is Aboriginal people who are on the receiving end of control, direction and management by others. That is the context which can be discriminatory. That is why we need to have a provision in the Racial Discrimination Act to deal with it, but it is not the situation here where we are dealing with a transmission at will to produce results running the other way.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if there were a situation where the individual common law holders did not want negotiations to take place with the mining company and the body corporate decided that those negotiations should take place or vice versa? Surely that is a situation where the body corporate is acting against the interests of the individuals and the individuals should be given direct ability to influence the way their native title is used. The minister does not seem to want to use the term management because it embarrasses him. I would have thought that any body corporate negotiates with third parties to ensure that the title is protected and benefited and, in other ways, managed.

—A body corporate has no existence other than at the will and control of the individual native titleholders. That is the whole intention. It is simply a vehicle for the achievement of certain results at the direction—
—That's like saying a company could never act against the interests of shareholders.

—It is not to be assumed that we are talking about a company of a familiar kind. The nature of the body corporate is to be identified by statute. The role of it is to be exactly as I have described it. There is a question as to whether individual native titleholders should be obliged to accept a body corporate vehicle for holding the title and communicating their will to others. There is a view that there should be an option about that. That is a view that the government has accepted. That is what will be incorporated in the amendment being refined at the moment. It will be introduced at an appropriate time as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: I honestly think that I have done my best to answer the concern that Senator Alston has about the applicability of the Racial Discrimination Act to this situation. Under those circumstances, there is no need to defer consideration of clause 6A. Accordingly, Mr Temporary Chairman, if we have exhausted the other associated perceived problems, can we perhaps pass it and move on?

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the committee that the question before it is that consideration of this amendment be deferred.

—I speak in support of Senator Alston's motion. Those people who were listening earlier, when this matter was first raised, will remember the somewhat flippant way in which Senator Evans chose to deal with it as though it really were not a problem at all. As the night has gone on, we have been told that that problem has been spotted and something is being done about it.

PARA.TAB: The questions that Senator Alston is putting to the minister do not go to the amendments that the minister says he is providing, which we are going to see later. As I understand it, the minister is saying, `Don't worry about amendment 6A because it is all going to be okay and, in any event, the amendment that is coming will make the corporate representation a matter of choice'. But I think Senator Alston is going to other points as well. The minister might be able to help us, if we are so thick as not to get the point that he is making. He is saying, `This corporate body that people might be able to choose later or have to have now, isn't there to perform the management functions that it was intended to get at in the Racial Discrimination Act'. He says that all he wants this corporate body to do is to be the repository or place for the title to be held.

But he does not explain why, when we have a corporate body there, it does not have all the powers of a corporate body. Neither does he explain what access there is and what means there are to ensure that the wishes of the native titleholders are complied with. The minister just wipes that away and says, `Don't be silly; this is not a sort of corporate structure as any other corporate structure; this is a corporate structure that will always act in accordance with the wishes of the people on whose behalf it holds the property'. But he does not draw our attention to where in the bill we see that. He does not draw our attention to that at all. The minister just says, `What was intended to do with the RDA was this'. What the minister intended and what the plain meaning of the words are might be two quite separate things.

In particular, I invite the minister to help us out if we cannot see the point. Where does it say in this bill that it is ensured that any corporate body that does hold title—by matter of choice or whatever, when the government gets its other amendment fixed up—will always, in every capacity, act in accordance with the wishes of the people who would otherwise be the native titleholders? Where does it say that in the bill? Help us out.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that it is in the nature of the bodies corporate that that relationship exists.

—I wish to speak against deferring consideration of this amendment until a later time. I believe that the questions that are being raised are very valid, very useful and quite appropriate for discussion. I believe that they may be more appropriately raised when we discuss the amendments to this aspect later on in the Native Title Bill debate. I am sure that I am not the only one who wishes to proceed at a faster pace and get to some of those other aspects. But the problem will not be solved by failing to accept this amendment and to put in place a clause that relates the operation of this bill to that of the Racial Discrimination Act.

PARA.TAB: It may well be that there are other aspects, as we go through the amendments, which we have to take into account as they relate to this particular clause. I do not think it is inappropriate to do that. I do think that it is inappropriate to delay consideration of this clause because there may be other aspects that come up later that have a relationship to it. As I believe that this is the foundation stone of this piece of legislation, and it would be a discriminatory vehicle without it, I would like to speak strongly in support of moving this amendment and having further discussion which, no doubt, will relate to aspects of the Racial Discrimination Act and its relationship with this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to what the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) said earlier—`You do not have to worry; that is the nature of the body corporate'—there must be thousands of shareholders around Australia who are not satisfied that the corporation has acted in their interests at all and that there are suitable opportunities for them, on each occasion a management decision is taken, to have their say. That is simply not the case. Quite clearly, it is not the case. All the minister says is, `Oh, well. That is the nature of the corporate process'. There are millions of shareholders around Australia who would say that the nature of the corporate process only backs up the point that we are raising—namely, that by having native title held in a corporate body only puts at risk the opportunities for the native titleholders to ensure that their titles are managed in the way that they want that to be done.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans should come back to that point. I do not deny what Senator Chamarette says about having this debate on other clauses as they relate to this matter. I understand the point you are making there. It is just that now this point has come up we may as well resolve it. If you have satisfaction in the corporate process of representing the shareholders and think it is appropriate to leave it at that—
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Senator Vanstone, address your remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Mr Temporary Chairman. Through you, I wonder whether that is what the minister thinks. In any event, perhaps he could address 53(5) which indicates what is going to be set out by regulation, not by the wishes of the native titleholders in the areas covered by each of these corporations. A whole manner of things will be set out here and the native titleholders, presumably on each occasion, are not going to be able to say, `We do not want our corporation to do this; we want our corporation to be allowed to do that'. What does the minister say in relation to 53(5) and how that interrelates?

—We really are talking to death clauses 53 and 54, which are not strictly before us. But I will try to set the honourable senator's mind at rest. What clauses 53, 54 and 55 are doing is simply creating a framework that was intended to be filled in by subsequent regulations, regulations which would specify—
—We will see how we go and fix it up later, will we? Here we go again.

—No, legislation very often makes provision for matters of detail to be dealt with in regulations. This is no exception; and it is appropriate that it should be so. There does need to be a further consultative process—that is understood and acknowledged—about the kinds of body corporate that would be most appropriate for this kind of title. Whether it is best to have the trustee-beneficiary arrangement, something in the nature of a more familiar statutory corporate structure or a range of options—as subclauses 4 and 5 say—will be spelt out in regulations. The options and choices available will be spelt out.

PARA.TAB: One of the sorts of provisions that would be included in regulations is, for example, that the corporate body—whether with a trustee, director or a different kind of corporate structure—has to act in accordance with the views of native titleholders as determined by traditional meetings. We are not talking about straight majority vote in a native title situation but traditional forms of reaching consensus—and the views of the community group or the holders in question.

That provision is in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, or regulations under that. That is a familiar kind of provision and is exactly the kind of provision that one might think would be appropriate to be developed in regulations. It is flagged in subclauses (4) and (5) that the regulations would need to deal with these kinds of things. It is just not spelt out here. The bill is already 238 clauses long and it is desirable that some of these detailed implementation strategies be the subject of a further consultative process. That is the path we want to go down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have allowed these questions about bodies corporate because it appears to be the reason, in part, for Senator Alston's motion of deferment. Having heard a number of contributions on that point and the minister respond from his point of view, I ask that senators speak more strictly to the question of deferment, to which Senator Alston and Senator Vanstone have spoken and which Senator Chamarette has spoken against.
—The minister would be very familiar with the rights that attach to joint tenancy and tenancies-in-common.
—No.
—I thought as an extensive property holder and no doubt an academic and practical expert in property law at the Bar and elsewhere he would have all this knowledge at his fingertips.
—It was some years ago. I can be reminded.
—I am sure his extensive and constant reading on every imaginable subject would enable him to instantly recall those concepts, at least.
—I always got them confused.
—There is a right of survivorship with joint tenancy, is there not? One dies and the other gets the lot.
—Or is it tenants-in-common? I cannot remember.

—No, if a joint tenant predeceases the other joint titleholder, the former's estate dips out. The whole principle behind both those forms of holdings was to ensure that there was a fairer quality during the lifetime of the holders, so they were not overridden by another body such as a body corporate or an ordinary company.

PARA.TAB: In those circumstances, why would the act not go out of its way to provide expressly that a body corporate should reflect, as democratically as possible, the precise interests of individuals? Otherwise, one presumes that, in the same way as land councils are likely to get their hands on most of the running of native title claims, they could well be prescribed in due course as bodies corporate. There is nothing to suggest that a land council is synonymous with the individuals who might or might not regard themselves as belonging to it. In those circumstances, why will the government not amend the act so as to ensure that any body corporate has its powers and functions clearly defined so that it actually and directly represents the interests of all of its members?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly the kind of issue that we anticipate being addressed in the regulations. As I have said—and I will say it again—I would envisage a provision saying that, in situations where the option chosen by the native titleholders is to vest title in the body corporate, not just to have it as an agent, there would be something in the regulations to make it clear that the body corporate has to act in accordance with the views of native titleholders, as determined, for example, by traditional meetings.

PARA.TAB: If the honourable senator really wants to improve the legislation in these ways, it is always open to him to move amendments. But he has taken the view that he is just going to stand up and oppose things. We can have a constructive approach to this and we can work together through the normal legislative process, but somehow those opposite do not want to get into that business; they just want to stay in the negative business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have won a lot of cases by cross-examining without leading evidence, so why break a good record?
—The trouble is the honourable senator is not in court; he is in parliament. He ought to behave like a legislator, not a failed lawyer.

—We must defer this legislation until we get the matter sorted out. We cannot keep going through this bill, throwing out bits and bringing in another amendment to try to fix things up as we go. Not long ago I heard a news report which said that a meeting of a council of elders, I think it was, somewhere had just resolved to march on Parliament House tomorrow to demand that this Native Title Bill be rejected. According to the news report, they have also passed a resolution rejecting Ms O'Donoghue as their spokesperson.

PARA.TAB: I did not get the full details of the press report, but it seems that there is a group of Aboriginal elders—or some group of Aboriginal people meeting—who are very concerned about this Native Title Bill and want it deferred. They do not want it dealt with today. They do not understand what is happening, just as we do not understand what is happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gareth does not understand either.

—The honourable senator is quite correct; that is the point. We are dealing with these matters and suddenly we are waiting for an amendment. We are promised that certain information will come tomorrow; it may well come or it may not. We really cannot deal with these matters until they are examined properly. Perhaps we should start taking some notice of these groups of Aboriginal people who really do not want the bill to be dealt with. Perhaps Senator Spindler and the Australian Democrats should take some notice of these Aboriginal groups and many other people—
—We have.
—So why are these people marching on Parliament House tomorrow to ask us not to deal with this legislation?
—I wonder who they represent.

—As I have said, I did not hear the name of the group or the exact details; I just came in on the end of the broadcast. But I thought there were a couple of hundred people. Perhaps Senator Spindler might be able to meet with them tomorrow when they march on Parliament House to ask him to defer this bill. They will ask the honourable senator to do that for the same reason that we want it deferred: it has not been thought through properly. It is five past 11 at night and amendments are being drafted as we speak. For those reasons, we need to ensure that this legislation is deferred so that we can get the information we need for the bill to proceed on the right course.

—I support Senator Alston's motion to defer this clause. The more we discuss it, the more that things come up, and I think there are better ways of doing this. Senator Alston mentioned the situation of joint tenancy as opposed to tenants-in-common and body corporate. I can see good reasons for maintaining joint tenancy. The idea of joint tenancy was set up so that property could pass between spouses or between unrelated people without being caught up in death duties. Senator Evans said that he was drafting an amendment, which we might see tomorrow, going to the matter of individual ownership as against body corporate. The more we discuss this, the more points come up. I think it would be a sensible idea to accept Senator Alston's suggestion that we defer on this and move on to the next matter.
—I have been listening to this debate on the monitor in my office. I would also like to see this particular clause deferred until tomorrow morning.

—I had wanted to ask a question by way of clarification but, if it is the desire of this chamber to defer consideration of this clause until after we have dealt with the body corporate issue, I am happy to oblige in that regard.

—I am grateful to Senator Chamarette, and I trust that Senator Evans is also grateful. At the same time, I ask whether he could indicate how the whole of section 53 is not particularly discriminatory because, on my reading of it, white Australians who own land are entitled to do so in their own names, whereas that is not the case for Aboriginal individuals.
—Would you mind taking yes for an answer and waiting until we get to it tomorrow. I will consider it overnight.
—I am simply asking Senator Evans to address that matter as well. Unless he hears what I am asking him to address, even he would find it difficult to provide an accurate answer.
—I hear what you are saying.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative; consideration postponed.
Clauses 7 to 9 taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 10

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some explaining to do here because this amendment—
—It is in the wrong column.

—Yes, and it is also on a sheet marked `2A', and has been called `amendment 3' by the clerk. Also, it relates to clause 10, not clause 11. The reason for the change is simply to make it more appropriate because clause 10 actually relates to the extinguishment of native title. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Clause 10, page 8, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:
Effect of subsection (1)
"(2)An act that consists of the making, amendment or repeal of legislation on or after 1 July 1993 by the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory is only able to extinguish native title:
(a)in accordance with Division 3 of Part 2 (which deals with future acts and native title); or

TAB.TAB: (b)by validating past acts in relation to the native title.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment simply means that state law passed on or after 1 July 1993 which provides for the extinguishment of native title has no effect. The amendment is necessary because of the behaviour of some of our state governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I thought, this amendment is clearly designed to ensure that states can no longer be responsible for land management decisions. It is aimed directly, because of the time frame of legislation introduced after 1 July 1993, to strike down the Western Australian traditional usage legislation and to provide that native title can only be extinguished on a case-by-case basis by compulsory acquisition.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought it is, therefore, simply a very blatant attempt to outlaw state solutions to impose, in a way that the government is always fond of doing, a national solution irrespective of the differing demands at state level, irrespective of the clear constitutional rights of states to make their own arrangements and irrespective of whether, in so doing, they actually benefit those Aborigines who might be affected by it. In those circumstances, this is a clear example of the centralist tendencies of the Democrats, and the opposition will have no bar of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fail to see the need for this amendment when clause 10 says quite simply: `native title is not able to be extinguished contrary to this Act'. It is a very simple statement. It means that only in relation to this piece of legislation can native title be extinguished. This proposed section is really reinventing the wheel. It is superfluous because it goes on to restate the same in perhaps a more detailed manner—
—It spells it out.

—I do not think it does. It is not as explicit as the simple statement: `native title is not able to be extinguished contrary to this Act'. That means that it cannot be extinguished by any state act or by any other act. It can only be extinguished by the Native Title Bill. So if we say that the Western Australian legislation extinguishes native title, then it would be in contravention of clause 10 without the Democrats' addition. I think it just adds to the general verbiage of this bill and it is ineffectual because it is already stated in clause 10.

—There is a sense in which clause 10, which will become clause 10(1) under this draft, does do the basic job, together with the language in division 3, part 2, clause 22. To that extent, I think Senator Ellison may not be that far from the truth. Nonetheless, this amendment does it even more clearly and even more explicitly.

PARA.TAB: It puts absolutely beyond doubt that, once we are in this situation, native title cannot be extinguished except in accordance with the provisions of this act. What that basically boils down to is compulsory acquisition. That is the only basis the future on which that will be able to occur. This really spells it out beyond any room for disagreement—

TALK.START.PARA: —It makes them think they have had a big win.

—It does not do any harm to be generous on occasions. I know that is foreign to Senator Ian Macdonald's nature, but generosity is not foreign to ours. It is appropriate to add a little bit of extra clarity and I think we ought to pass the amendment and move on.

—This is a quite terrible amendment for Western Australia. We have a situation in Western Australia where at least 40 per cent and upwards of 80 per cent of the state is subject to native title claim. The state government of Western Australia, which was elected in a landslide election victory in February this year, had before it only a few weeks ago a piece of legislation that dealt with this matter.

PARA.TAB: The Democrat amendment, quite blatantly, not only tries to stop the democratically elected government of Western Australia dealing with land title matters, which it has done ever since federation, but it does it retrospectively.

Western Australia has a democratically elected state government, elected in a landslide victory, just like South Australia. I remind the Senate that not one single Democrat was elected in that election. In fact, its vote was absolutely abysmal. Most of the candidates lost their deposits—very similar to the result in South Australia.

These Democrats, who get less than five per cent of the vote across Australia, come into this place and move an amendment not only to take over land management control from Western Australia but also to strike down Western Australian laws retrospectively. The people of Western Australia need to know what these people are about.

Senator Kernot lives in Brisbane sometimes and then comes down here and wants to make laws—with the help of Senator Spindler, who lives in Melbourne—to retrospectively strike out laws passed by a democratically elected government in Western Australia. It needs to be very clearly put on the record that this is what the Democrats support. The Democrats would like to see Western Australians' lives ruled by these geniuses over here in Canberra, 3,000 miles away.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell these Aboriginal people from Western Australia that you want to extinguish their native title.

—I would tell Aboriginal people and all other people from right around Australia that we do not want them to have their lives ruled by these social engineers and centralists from Canberra. The concept of a retrospective piece of legislation going back six months to overrule a democratically elected state government is absolutely outrageous. I look forward to voting against it.

—I presume that the purveyors of all good things in this Senate, the Democrats, took part in that inquiry. Earlier I said that the reasons there could not be a Senate select committee hearing were that it would take too long, that we would have to go too far from Canberra, and that it was very difficult to get to remote areas of Western Australia and Queensland. The point is that the committee recommended that it not have a Senate select committee hearing because it was too hard to get into those areas, yet Senator Kernot is prepared to sit in this Senate and move an amendment that retrospectively takes away the laws passed by Western Australia for remote areas of Western Australia where she is not prepared to go.
—Where they don't know her.

—That is right, and she is not prepared to go there. I could have lived with this amendment if at least it started when the act was assented to, but, no, it has to be retrospective to 1 July. As Senator Campbell said, it is a blatant exercise to take away the rights of Western Australia, yet those from Canberra are not prepared to go over and see for themselves. There are not too many native title claims in Melbourne, Brisbane, Canberra or Sydney, but in those areas of Western Australia that produce Australia's export income there are a lot of them under the hammer. Senator Kernot would prefer to use the Brisbane line of `it's over there—a long way away'.
—There are a lot of good Aboriginal people over that way.

—There are some mighty good ones—the Champions family in Kalgoorlie, the Ozies in Derby, the Donaldsons in Kalgoorlie and the Gubberan tribe. All of those are very good people and people for whom I have a lot of time and a lot of respect. Those from Canberra are not prepared to go over and talk to them; they just want to write them off. I reckon we are getting into the depths of despair when we pass this sort of legislation to override a government that was elected in a landslide victory.

—As I see it, if we did what Senator Panizza said—that is, in place of 1 July 1993, insert `as from the date of operation of this legislation'—it would not make any difference. As I see it, this amendment does not make any difference at all to the legislation. As has been pointed out by Senator Alston and confirmed by Senator Evans, this amendment really is not necessary.
—Some Aboriginal people feel it is for clarity, for certainty.

—That may be their view. I am voting on it and, having looked at it and having listened, it is my view—and I am no lawyer—that it makes no difference. It is no good talking about land management issues. I am sorry about that but, frankly, in this particular special circumstance, we as a federal parliament are dealing with a matter which, I acknowledge, is essentially the right of the state—and that is the land management question. This is a special occasion. I believe that we are doing it properly, as we are entitled to do it, under 51(xxvi) of the constitution. The people of Australia in a referendum decided that. I will not repeat what I said before the suspension of the sitting for dinner about that matter. I do not see any reason to vote for this particular amendment. I feel that it ought to go to the vote now.
—With all due respects to my friend Senator Harradine, this is where we really start to get to the crux of this bill.
—I am voting against the amendment.

—I know. I am not being critical. I thought a little bit was off, but I will not go into that. I will address the fundamental problem of this bill and why I believe it will not stand up constitutionally. I see that Senator Evans has left this place. It is this part of the legislation where we transfer, by Commonwealth statute, the right of land management. The implications of that go far and wide. We have already heard the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) threaten not to supply landcare finances to states that do not comply with what the Commonwealth wants them to do—the typical process of thuggery and threat and bash and whack.

PARA.TAB: The question that I want to put to Senator Kernot is: why does she hate the states so much? Why is she so anti-state? When she gets back to Queensland, a few people will be reminding her that the processes of land management in Queensland—like Western Australia and the other states—belong firmly and properly in the hands of the state. On than question alone, this bill should be thrown out of this place. It challenges the very basis of federation. If Senator Kernot wants to blow this federation apart, she should continue down the line in which she is going. I can tell her right now that, as a Western Australian, I do not want to blow the federation apart.

TALK.START.PARA: —I like my state.

—So do I, and I will fight for it. As has already been mentioned here tonight, where are the Democrats in Western Australia? Western Australians woke up to the Democrats. They knew that the Democrats were anti-Western Australia; they were absolutely opposed to their having the control and the management of their own destiny. As far as I am concerned—and I am sure my colleagues in this place feel the same way—the process of land management must stay with the states. It is a question for the government as to why it wants to go down the line of really shaking the very foundations of this federation.

PARA.TAB: When our forefathers set up our constitution, they deliberately left the land management process in the hands of the states. On those grounds alone, not only should this amendment be defeated, but also the whole bill should be defeated. This bill will do no good for the people it supposedly helps while the government is taking this draconian approach.

While we are here, we might ask Senator Gareth Evans how many consultations he had with the government of Western Australia about these matters. Why did he lock Western Australia out of these consultations? They are very valid questions. The government chose to go down a certain path which isolated one state in this Commonwealth. Gradually, the other states have come out against the Commonwealth. They will wake up very soon to how the Commonwealth is trying to interfere with their legal and proper processes. As such, I certainly cannot support this measure. But I ask the minister why the government did not have proper consultations with Western Australia in terms of this legislation and, in particular, the matter of land management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak again because I have not had time to look at this amendment. It was not one of the amendments put in Senator Spindler's list in the committee report. I am indebted to Senator Spindler for the time that he put into it. This is a late addition.

PARA.TAB: I want to say two things. Firstly, the principle of applying a law in a retrospective fashion is abhorrent; it has to be. It means that what was legal yesterday and what people did yesterday in the belief that it was legal can be made illegal today. We start on the basis that it is an entirely undesirable principle of law to apply. In fact, notable totalitarian regimes in recent history have employed it quite effectively. I have an absolute abhorrence of applying a law retrospectively.

But I appreciate that this argument might be raised. The Mabo decision came in June 1992 and the common law recognised native title. By backdating this law, we are not necessarily creating a new law because we are just recognising the Mabo decision in a retrospective fashion. That might hold some weight, but on balance it does not quite get up.

Division 3 of part 2 of the bill talks about future acts. I do not think it makes any reference anywhere to, for instance, the Racial Discrimination Act. That occurs in division 4, but not in division 3. In his judgment, Brennan J said that a state government could extinguish native title as long as it abided by the laws of the Commonwealth—notably, the Racial Discrimination Act—and it acted constitutionally. The High Court was saying, `There is native title, but it can be extinguished as long as it is extinguished properly'.

Brennan's judgment was regarded as the leading one. Two of the other judges, whose names escape me for the moment, followed his judgment on that point. This does not retrospectively apply the Mabo decision. If it did, it would recognise that one could extinguish native title in accordance with the Mabo decision. I do not believe that division 3 of part 2 of this act, on its own, reflects the Mabo decision. Taken in isolation, I do not think it covers all those points.

The problem that this amendment runs into is that it applies specifics. The simple sentence that is in the present clause 10 says `in accordance with this act', and in one broad brush it encompasses the whole piece of legislation. But this narrows it down to division 3 of part 2 of the bill. That is where it runs into trouble. Quite frankly, it does not survive the criticism of it because of its retrospective effect. It is not retrospectively applying the law in accordance with the Mabo decision.

Further, it is an attack on the states' ability to constitutionally deal with land management. It is a fact that land management was reserved by the state governments at the time of federation. They ceded powers to the Commonwealth. (Quorum formed)

We reached the stage where the states had not ceded land management to the Commonwealth at the time of Federation. That might sound legalistic and a very dry argument but, nonetheless, it is one which carries weight and one that must be acknowledged. It is a constitutional argument and one which cannot be infringed. If it is, then the law is bad.

I say that this amendment takes this whole clause into more troubled waters. During the course of the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional there was evidence that the interference by the Commonwealth in respect of state jurisdiction in this area could cause constitutional problems. In fact, clause 7 says, in a rather vague way:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act is not intended to affect the operation of any law of a State or a Territory that is capable of operating concurrently with this Act.

The expression `capable of operating concurrently with this act' is rather vague. Does it mean that general laws pertaining to land management could operate but, as soon as they cross over into the native title area, they are inconsistent with the Commonwealth? But this bill may have consequential effects in respect of state land management systems. That is where the Commonwealth goes beyond the field it intends to cover .

PARA.TAB: This clause is a classic example of the Commonwealth overstepping the mark in relation to state jurisdiction. It is doing it in a retrospective fashion. I think this clause is ill-conceived. I will conclude by asking the minister whether he has had any considered legal advice on the operation of this clause and the application it might have in relation to state laws on land management. If that advice has been obtained, can we have the benefit of it?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are conscious of the central thrust of clause 10. As I have already said, this amendment does no more than really further clarify what would otherwise be the operation of clause 10. The impact of clause 10 on state regimes that do purport legislatively to extinguish native title is quite considerable. That is clearly what its impact is. There is no apology for that because we had hoped that it would be possible to get consensus nationally about this and we would all move together in the same way and not have a situation where a state does move to extinguish native title otherwise than through the proper process of compulsory acquisition. That has happened and it is necessary accordingly—and I do not think this is any news to anybody—to act in order to exercise our responsibilities as the guardians and protectors constitutionally of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, the responsibility that we were given by an overwhelming referendum mandate in 1967.

PARA.TAB: It is not our intention to intrude unnecessarily on state land management regimes. We have said that over and over again. We think land management is a proper state function and appropriately enjoyed to the maximum possible extent. It is only when the exercise of that function trespasses into constitutional territory that is properly the Commonwealth's protective responsibility that it becomes necessary to act in this way.We believe that the constitutional authority of the race power is enough to get us here in this instance. We would much prefer to have got there on a cooperative basis without the necessity to have any overriding effect. But we believe that constitutionally, as I said, the job is properly done.

I say something in response to Senator Crane's suggestion about non-consultation with WA. It is just not true that WA was not consulted. Premier Court was at the COAG meeting. He chose to walk away from a deal that remained an acceptable outline to the rest of the states. His officials came to several meetings—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell the truth about it.
—What is Senator Campbell saying?
—Paul Keating pulled out of the deal, not Richard Court.

—There was no willingness on the part of Western Australia to stay with state cooperation and state implementation. Do not let us wash out that dirty linen again, except to acknowledge that there was consultation and lots of discussion with officials both before and after the COAG meeting. The problem was that simply there was no acceptance, on the part of WA, of the need for a national approach or a willingness to accept native title in its full rigour. That is the problem that we have dealt with and that is one of the reasons we are passing this legislation. That is not news to anybody and this is one of the clauses—
—Don't tell lies to the Senate.
—I ask that remark be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—Please withdraw that remark, Senator Campbell, as it is unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Gareth Evans stops misleading the Senate about the state government of Western Australia—
—Order! You have been asked to withdraw Senator Campbell.
—I said if he stops misleading the Senate I will withdraw.
—Senator Campbell must withdraw unconditionally.
—I withdraw.
—I have nothing more to add under those circumstances.

—I believe that the legislation passed by the WA government is the best reason that can be furnished both for clause 10 in the bill and for the Australian Democrats' amendment. It may be true what Senator Harradine says; that is, that the further clarification that our amendment provides is legally and constitutionally unnecessary. But I think it is important not to lose sight of the main purpose of this bill, which is to confirm native title, in turn, confirmed by the High Court decision.

PARA.TAB: It is absolutely essential to ensure that one state cannot make a mockery of the judgment and of legislation that for once and for the first time in our history provides justice for Aboriginal people across this nation. We cannot have this subverted—no matter how much some senators would like to do that. I believe it is absolutely essential. Although the Democrats' amendment may be a clarification, it is one that puts on record the purpose of this legislation. It puts on record the essential justice that is provided by this legislation for Aboriginal people. The power has been provided by the 1967 referendum, which ensured that the Commonwealth has the power to provide such justice for Aboriginal people. It must not be subverted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. That was a disgusting reflection on my state and I ask that it be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—There is no point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans said that Western Australia would be consulted. I thought tonight would be an opportune time to quote from the Hansard of Western Australia.
—Oh!
—Do you like the truth or not? Mr Grill, the former Minister for Primary Industry in Western Australia and now Deputy Leader of the Opposition—
—And the next Leader of the Opposition.
—He is probably the next Leader of the Opposition. Mr Grill was trying to convince Mr Court to come over and talk to Mr Keating. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will be left with Federal legislation which will have little or no impact on other States, but will have a huge impact on Western Australia. This State will be left with a land title system which could well be in chaos. I have outlined some of the ramifications, there are probably others, if this legislation fails to get up in due course.
Mr Minson said:
What do you suggest we do? If we let the Federal legislation go ahead, it will be disastrous.
The report continues:

Mr GRILL: The Minister should indicate today or sometime this week that he is prepared to hold up this legislation and hold further talks with the Federal Government about a suitable form of legislation.
Mr Court: Have you tried talking to the Federal Government?
Mr GRILL: The Premier has been advised and he knows what the ramifications will be if this legislation—
that is, the Western Australian legislation—
fails. They are as I have spelt out.

Mr Court: I know what the ramifications of the Federal legislation are. Do you know what it is like trying to deal with the Federal Government? It has not been the slightest bit interested in the concerns that we have raised. It has taken the easy way out. It said that it will get the majority of States to agree to its proposals and it will not worry about addressing Western Australia's problem. I had Tickner come to my office and he said that the media wanted us to meet but we would have to fill in half an hour. I told him that we had to work something out—
in other words, work something out about the legislation—
but he treated the exercise as a joke. In other words it was all being done in Canberra.
Mr GRILL: I agree that to some degree this Government has been excluded from that debate.
Further on, the Hansard report continues:
Mr GRILL: The Premier should rethink this legislation. He leading into waters which he has not chartered.
Mr Court: It is not a bad shot.
Mr GRILL: I am not a centralist any longer.
Mr Grill is a good friend of mine. He tried to get me to join the Labor Party once, but he was wrong there. The report continues:

When I first joined the Labor Party, I was a centralist, but having been a Minister in successive Labor Governments it is very difficult to be a centralist in Western Australia because we have not been dealt with fairly.
That is Mr Grills speaking. The report continues:

The Federal Government has not been sensitive to our needs, and by and large on many issues we have been ignored. We need only look at the national institutions in Australia today, which must number well over 100, but not one of them is housed in Western Australia. However, even though I am not a centralist any longer, I am really concerned about the mining industry of this State. Many people like to make a whipping boy out of the the mining industry.
That is the Greens with their agenda. The report goes on:

In the past, environmentalists have endeavoured to do that, and they continue to do that, I thing wrongly, becuse the mining industry has little environmental impact in the operations and, where it does, the rehabilitation processes are pretty good these days. The mining will be the casualty of this legislation, and the Premier knows that. He knows that he is heading into troubled waters, and he understands that the risk of the failure of this legislation—
that is, the Western Australian legislation—
is that we will be stuck with hostile Commonwealth legislation, into which the Premier has had no chance to make any input. We will be stuck with chaos in our land title system.
Mr Court: You got that part right—a hostile Federal system. That is a good summary of it.

Mr Grill replied: `It is time to start again. At least we might have a 50 per cent chance that that will be the case in due course'. That is what Mr Grill, the former Labor Minister for Primary Industry in Western Australia, had to say. Senator Chris Evans has now come into the chamber. He knows Mr Grill fairly well. I do not think he will disagree with the words that I have just read out. That puts paid to Senator Gareth Evans's assumption that the government consulted with Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are a different breed from Kalgoorlie.
—Yes, I take that as a compliment because although I am not quite in Kalgoorlie, I am not far from there. Mr Campbell is in Kalgoorlie.

PARA.TAB: The point is that Mr Keating is the one who walked out of the negotiations. He thought that he would get the populous states first—such as Victoria, New South Wales and others where there was no native title to be claimed—and he then thought that he would take Western Australia by storm, but he was wrong. I think that Senator Gareth Evans had better withdraw his remarks that Western Australia was properly consulted, otherwise I will get Mr Grill to ring him tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in complete accord with my colleagues who have pinpointed the way in which this bill grossly intrudes onto what have been traditional states' rights. It is clear that the intention of this amendment is to override the Court bill, but that is not the only bill in the nation dealing with native title at the moment. I wonder whether Senator Kernot, who is bringing down an amendment with such far-reaching consequences for the federation of this country, or Senator Gareth Evans could tell me whether this would have the effect of overriding the Victorian bill, the draft bill that Mr Fahey has brought down in New South Wales and the bill that I know Mr Goss has brought down in Queensland. What would be the impact of this amendment on those particular bills? If we are going to pass an amendment like this, I think we are entitled to see whether we are overriding bills in virtually all the states. I would ask Senator Gareth Evans or Senator Kernot to provide the chamber with that information.

—My understanding of the operation of the New South Wales, Victorian and Queensland bills is that effectively they provide for not much more than validation of the kind which is clearly contemplated as appropriate under this legislation. As a result there is no question of their being overridden, struck down or declared inconsistent in any respect.

—I wanted to deal with the issue that Senator Gareth Evans raised earlier with respect to the matter of consultation with the Western Australian government. I would like to see this matter resolved once and for all. While the Australian Democrats and the government senators say that the WA government did not want to consult, we say that it did.
—They voted for it.
—I am sorry, Noelene?
—Excuse me, Madam Chair, Senator Campbell means it in a most derogatory fashion.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—Order! You should refer to people by their proper title.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interjector?
—You should refer to any senator by his or her proper title.
—She was interjecting; that is all.
—Excuse me, Madam Chair, could you ask Senator Campbell to refer to me by my proper title?
—She was interjecting constantly.
—That is beside the point. Senators should refer to other senators by their proper title. I ask Senator Campbell to do so.
—Senator Kernot. I do not know whether they get Sylvania Waters out in the Aboriginal communities but that is beside the point.

PARA.TAB: The matter of consultation with the WA government is an important issue because both the members of the government and Senator Kernot are misleading the people of Australia in relation to that matter. I would be pleased if the minister were to put before the Senate the facts as to the dates and times that the officers dealing with native title legislation from Western Australia were contacted by officers from the federal government in relation to those consultations.

I am aware of one specific example where a meeting was, I think, held in Brisbane back in either June or July, where the Western Australian Premier's office was contacted less than 24 hours from the time of a meeting being called to discuss an early draft of the legislation. That is the one example I remember, and I am sure there are others, but I will get the information from the premier's office and put it before the Senate, if Senator Evans does not.

On that particular occasion, the Premier's office was contacted, and it was actually physically impossible for the officers from Western Australia to get to the meeting in time. There was a consistent pattern of behaviour from the federal government's officers which basically ensured that the Western Australians were kept out in the cold. That may or may not be the case, but I prefer to accept the word of the Western Australian government over and above that of this government. Perhaps Senator Evans has been misled by the Prime Minister again on this occasion. Perhaps Senator Evans was trying to tell the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Frank Walker's meeting with your Premier?
—Frank Walker has met with the Premier and so has the Prime Minister on a couple of occasions. But the point I am making—
—Five hours talking about the bill and a week later, without any advance notice to us, you introduced your own.

—I am quite happy for that information to be put before the Senate. The other issue is the one Senator Spindler raised of whether or not the people of Western Australia want their own legislation to deal with this issue in their own way. Senator Spindler obviously knows better how to run Western Australia than the people of Western Australia or the government of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: But in a survey contacted by the Roy Morgan Research Centre on 8 December, a statistically valid survey by a very renowned and credible research organisation, Western Australian citizens were asked, `In your opinion, should the federal government's Mabo legislation be allowed to overrule the WA state government's Mabo legislation or not?'. Sixty-six per cent of those people surveyed agreed that the Western Australian state government's Mabo legislation should not be overruled, and 27 per cent agreed with Mr Keating's proposal—a phenomenon result, but Senator Spindler probably knows better than those people.

It is astounding that someone who calls himself a Democrat should think that the people of Western Australia are mistaken on this matter. They have seen the way this federal government behaves. We heard Senator Evans saying earlier that he thinks that land management issues are the correct concern of state governments, essentially, except if they get it wrong—except, essentially, if they do not do something the Commonwealth government does not want them to do. That is the position taken by the Democrats.

One would think from the way the Democrats behave in these matters that they do not just do their consulting in dark rooms and the hallways of Parliament House with the government; they actually spend most of their time sitting in the caucus room with the government. Perhaps it would be a lot more efficient and practical and sensible if the Democrats, instead of just signing off on next year's budget, actually sat in on caucus meetings. Perhaps they should join one of the factions of the Labor Party—not be the fourth faction over here—and go to caucus meetings, because they have blindly gone along with this government's taking over control of land management issues in Western Australia.

I make the point to the Senate that the people of Australia will sooner or later pass judgment upon a federal government that so blatantly overrules not only the legitimate actions of a democratically elected government in Western Australia but also the wishes of the Western Australian people which are published almost every week in opinion surveys. It is astounding that the Democrats should ignore the views of the Western Australian people, but I am sure that the Democrats genuinely believe they know better and that they would prefer to run Western Australia from here in Canberra, 3,000 miles away.

As I said by way of interjection earlier, Senator Kernot did not want the citizens of Western Australia—the Aboriginal communities—to have a say on this bill. She would prefer to have the discussions take place in ministers' offices late at night doing political deals over here in closed rooms excluding the Aboriginals of Western Australian

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the Aboriginal people from Western Australia.

—Aboriginals who have come over here from Western Australia are a unique group of people. When I have travelled to Roebourne, Cosmo Newbury or Warburton, or up to Carnarvon or Geraldton, or out to Kalgoorlie not many of the Aboriginals that I see can afford to buy a first class air ticket across to Canberra.

PARA.TAB: There is one thing that the people of Australia have done—they have given this parliament the resources to ensure that representatives like Senator Kernot can fly out to Kalgoorlie, Roebourne and Cosmo Newbery and talk to the Aboriginals on the ground. But Senator Kernot has decided not to. She knows better. She does not want a select committee; she wants the parliament to rush this through before Christmas. She does not care about their views, she does not care about the citizens of Western Australia and she does not care about the Aboriginals of Western Australia. Senator Kernot stands condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the question I asked the minister previously. I know he gave me his considered opinion but I did not know whether that was the considered opinion of the advice that had been obtained. I take issue with the contention that it is not the Commonwealth's intention to unduly interfere with the states system of land management.

PARA.TAB: In the dissenting report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and I refer to page 57, there is a quote from the Commonwealth submission to that committee which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth requirements need not add another layer to the approval processes in a State. The integration of existing processes with those required by the Commonwealth Bill is envisaged in the provisions for Commonwealth recognition of approved State bodies and processes. In this way the Commonwealth Bill can adapt national standards to the particular laws and procedures in a State.

That is clearly saying, let us not have two systems; let us have one system and it will all be ours. It will all be the Commonwealth's way and the state will then have to comply with the Commonwealth. This is exactly the point that I made earlier. One might think by looking at this bill that the states will have to comply with Commonwealth law on only one or two matters touching on native title, but the consequential amendments, and the consequential changes to land management in the states, will have a cumulative effect. At the end of the day, we will have largely Commonwealth control over land management in the states.

PARA.TAB: That may well be the motivation behind the Commonwealth bill. I know the preamble purports to talk about social justice and other lofty ideals—and quite commendable ones, too. But when one looks at the effect of this bill, I query whether there is perhaps another agenda—that is, a Commonwealth agenda to mutilate and debilitate state control over land management. So in view of that quote from the government submission, I ask the minister whether or not that is a clear exposition of the Commonwealth's intent to make one system of land management in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made absolutely clear that it is not the Commonwealth's intention. We fully recognise the appropriateness of state control over land management. There are just certain limiting cases, and one of them is when states seek to act in a way that is completely discriminatory and against the proper protective role in relation to Aboriginal people, and that is what is in issue here.

PARA.TAB: This particular legislation has been acknowledged, appreciated and understood by the other states to be a cooperative venture—a product of a consultative process. There is only one state that is acting manifestly against this spirit, and Western Australian legislation destroys, as it purports to do, with a sweep of the legislative pen the concept of native title, turning it into a statutory title, which is far less effectively protective in its character, which is subject, for all practical purposes, to ministerial whim to the extent that its exercise is something which we just cannot consciously and conscientiously live with, given the responsibilities that we have, as a Commonwealth, under the constitution, to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country. We make no apology for seeking to exercise that responsibility in a way that the opposition has failed to do.

We do not want to interfere with land management generally. We are certainly not interfering with rights to compulsorily acquire land, which is properly the subject of native title; that is a proper incident of land management. We are not in any way seeking to undermine that. The object of the exercise is, as we have described it and as I have described it tonight, to give a little justice to some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who have been denied it for over two centuries in this country.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Kernot's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.
